DEBATE.TITLE: STUDENT ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1994Cognate bill:COMMONWEALTH RECIPROCAL RECOVERY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 24 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill will make a number of amendments to the Student Assistance Act 1973. The act provides the legislative basis for the Austudy scheme and for the Austudy-Abstudy supplement scheme.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The assistance for isolated children scheme and the Abstudy scheme

PARA.TAB: The bill will give a legislative basis to the assistance for isolated children scheme and the Abstudy scheme. Currently, these schemes are not legislated and are administered under guidelines approved by the government. The schemes are, however, covered by the debt management and special appropriation provisions in the Student Assistance Act.

The assistance for isolated children scheme provides assistance to the parents of children who are isolated from normal educational facilities, whether because of geographic isolation or disability.The Abstudy scheme provides assistance for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students for educational purposes.

Decisions made under the assistance for isolated children scheme and the Abstudy scheme will become reviewable by the Student Assistance Review Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in the same way as Austudy decisions.

The provisions for the assistance for isolated children scheme will commence on 1 January 1995. The provisions for the Abstudy scheme will commence on 1 January 1996. These commencement dates will allow sufficient time for the drafting of the necessary regulations to set out the rules for the schemes.

The bill will extend the debt management regime under the act to include the Aboriginal student support and parent awareness program, the Aboriginal tutorial assistance scheme and the vocational and educational guidance for Aboriginals scheme.

The bill will decriminalise the existing requirement to advise the department within seven days of a change of circumstances that may affect entitlement. Instead, there will be a charge of $10 a week, up to a maximum of $1,000. The period for notification of a change in circumstances without penalty will be increased from seven to 14 days. A number of minor changes will also be made to the debt management provisions.

Several changes will be made relating to the repayment of benefits under the Austudy and Abstudy schemes in relation to eligibility for financial supplement. The taxable income thresholds for the compulsory repayment of financial supplement debts will be varied so that they are equivalent to the thresholds for the higher education contribution scheme. The amendments are necessary because of amendments to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 last year.

The bill will provide for the dependent spouse allowance under the Austudy scheme to be indexed in accordance with the all groups consumer price index. The bill will also make a number of minor amendments to the act.

Additional revenue of about $1 million annually is expected from the introduction of a charge for failing to inform the department of a change in circumstances likely to affect entitlement to assistance. The purpose of the measure is, however, not to attract revenue but to serve as an incentive for clients to inform changes in their circumstances so that overpayments can be avoided. On this basis, it is expected that there will be savings of about $2.5 million a year through the identification of changes that would otherwise have gone unreported and so led to overpayments. The other provisions in the bill have no significant revenue implications.

I should perhaps mention that the indexation of the dependent spouse allowance under Austudy does not constitute a change in government policy and so will not involve any additional expenditure above the forward estimates. The major administrative change in the bill is the establishment of the Abstudy and assistance for isolated children schemes on a legislated basis. This does not, however, require any change to the scheme rules and is therefore revenue neutral.
I commend the bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: COMMONWEALTH RECIPROCAL RECOVERY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

This bill seeks to facilitate the reciprocal recovery of debts arising under the Social Security Act 1991, the Student Assistance Act 1973 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. These three acts are the main Commonwealth statutes dealing with income maintenance. Each provides that an overpayment may be recovered by making deductions from a person's payments, whether the overpayment was incurred under the same act or one of the other acts.

PARA.TAB: The bill proposes to amend the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act to enable their payments to be adjusted to recover debts associated with an overpayment under another act. These associated debts are penalty charges incurred by a person who has incurred an overpayment and who is dilatory in arranging a repayment regime with the relevant department or voluntarily breaks an agreed repayment arrangement.

The Student Assistance Act already provides for the recovery of associated debts under the other two acts. An amendment is, however, needed to the Student Assistance Act to take account of a new charge to be introduced into the Social Security Act by the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993.

I would add that only a limited amount of a person's income maintenance payments is withheld to recover a debt. Further, the rationalisation of the debt recovery provisions in this bill will not lead to an increase in the level of deductions from a person's payments. The government is very aware of the need to balance a debtor's need for adequate income maintenance with the responsibility to recover debts to the Commonwealth as expeditiously as possible.

Turning to the financial impact, the bill will provide enhanced recovery procedures for debts to the Commonwealth arising from income maintenance overpayments. These debts amount to about $1 million in a full financial year. I commend the bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Student Assistance Amendment Bill and the Commonwealth Reciprocal Recovery Legislation Amendment Bill, which we are considering in tandem this morning, are essentially mechanical bills and as such are not controversial. As the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) has pointed out, the Student Assistance Amendment bill extends the scope of the 1973 act by establishing a legislative basis for the Abstudy scheme and the assistance for isolated children scheme and extends the debt management regime under the act to unlegislated student assistance schemes.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Reciprocal Recovery Legislation Amendment Bill seeks to facilitate the reciprocal recovery of overpayments covered by the three main Commonwealth acts dealing with income maintenance. These acts are: the Social Security Act, the Student Assistance Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The changes being implemented by these new acts seem to be no more than an effort at good housekeeping by the government. That is something which we are happy to encourage.

I enter only one caveat. I would like some reassurance, which I think the minister did give in his second reading speech, that where students or other beneficiaries have been found to have obtained an overpayment, they will at least be given the chance to make repayments by instalment rather than having to make a full payment immediately. I do not believe that the desperation which gives rise to seeking a loan under these circumstances should be compounded in such a manner.

In fact, when dealing with supplementary loans we can see that considerable inequities can befall people who are forced to accept this sort of assistance. Whilst on the one hand it enables students to get twice the amount of money that they would under Austudy, by converting the grant into a loan, it also means that the most needy students end up being the students with the most debts. My office handled one such case recently. A single mother was trying to better herself and thought that the supplementary loan would give her more assistance. She thought that she was converting only half of her Austudy grant when in fact she was losing it in its entirety.

The department then compounded her problem by giving her too much money all at once—which she promptly used to pay off debts and then had virtually nothing for months—while offering no explanation that she could understand. She says that the government offers poor students carrots and then leaves them with the stick. She advises other students not to have a bar of the supplementary loan scheme. In relation to these provisions, for example, clause 29 of the Student Assistance Amendment Bill provides:
The minister may in writing determine guidelines to be complied with by prescribed officers in the exercise of powers under sections 12S, 12U and 12VD.

SPEECH.PARA: But when one turns to the other bill before the parliament, the Commonwealth Reciprocal Recovery Legislation Amendment Bill, one finds that clause 4, for example, provides that social security overpayments may be recovered by deductions. But on reading the legislation there does not appear to be in relation to these overpayments and the recovery thereof guidelines which exist in the other legislation. If there are no legislative provisions in the bill itself or some administrative arrangements such as guidelines, whether formally proclaimed by way of the legislation or proclaimed by way of fiat from the minister, that leaves open the possibility that an entire overpayment could be deducted in an immediate next instalment due or in subsequent instalments, leaving the recipient without financial support.

PARA.TAB: I note that the minister said in his second reading speech that that would not be the case, but I seek some assurance that that relates not only to student assistance overpayments but also to overpayments made pursuant to the social security provisions of these bills and the veterans affairs provisions as well.

I would like to take the opportunity to touch upon what we believe to be altogether inadequate assistance for students and particularly for students who come from rural areas of Australia. I think everyone in this country is now entirely sick of that meaningless phrase `the clever country'. It is perfectly meaningless because this is a government which does not reward cleverness. We have a scientific brain drain because this government does not think that science is important. My colleague the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) yesterday noted that the white paper proposals mean that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, CSIRO, our scientific jewel in the crown, is to get at least $60 million less over the next three years.

This government allocates a piffling $1 million each year for programs to help gifted children. Contrary to public opinion and a lot of popular opinion, gifted children do not just succeed anyway. They can also become drop-outs because the education system leaves them feeling bored and insufficiently stimulated or challenged. So a street kid in Australia can be a gifted child. A kid who has died of a drug overdose at 15 can be a gifted child. Perhaps the piece de resistance is that the government gives people less to study than it does to do nothing. In this connection I would like to read a letter that was written to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) recently and passed on to me by a young Chinese student who is a recent immigrant to this country. She says in her letter:

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Hewson,
I wish to raise two issues about Austudy to your attention. I believe the existing policy is unfair and stupid and is against Australia's national interest.

First, at present the payment rate for Jobstart for a single person over 21 is $293.40 plus $40 to $60 rent relief a fortnight from the Department of Social Security. The Austudy rate for the same person is $241.50 without rent assistance from the Austudy office. So there is a disgraceful gap of $91.90 to $110.90 per fortnight between a hard-working student and an unemployed person, who may be a professional dole bludger.

The dole and Austudy, as parts of the welfare system, both are provided for the purpose of maintaining every Australian a minimum level of livelihood with dignity and equal sharing of social wealth, based on Christian and humanitarian compassion. But Austudy fails.

PARA.TAB: With a heavy study loan, he or she is less likely to be able to do a part-time job to supplement the Austudy. A student has to pay $2,250 for HECS every year, over $500 for expensive books and study materials. Studying at the campus means spending more money on transport and food bills, while a dole bludger sits at home doing nothing.

How can you expect a full-time student to live on $120 a week with dignity? University residential full accommodation ranges from $130 to $180 a week. If a student chooses to live more modestly, a $120 won't go far either. $60 for rent, $40 for food, $10 for gas, water and electricity, $10 for bus tickets, full stop. No money for anything else. No hair cut, no toothpaste, no shampoo, no Coca-Cola, no telephone, no cinema, nothing. Then you become nobody, a uni. student. No wonder some students have to prostitute themselves by being a guinea pig in the medical school, or donating blood or sperm.

It is ridiculous that a government disincentives [sic] its young and elite population to undertake training for themselves and a better Australia. Shame, shame, shame! Without a well educated workforce, how will Australia maintain a technologically advanced country to compete against low-wage Asian economies.

SPEECH.PARA: How, indeed? The student then goes on in her letter to point out that there is a special Austudy rate of $293.40 per fortnight for those who have been on unemployment benefits for at least six months in the last nine months. She said that, instead of living on unemployment benefits of $165 a week, she chose to wash dishes for $195 a week last year—a difference of only $30.

PARA.TAB: What incenses her is that because she worked instead of going on unemployment benefits she is now penalised by getting the lower rate of Austudy for the next five years of her study. So she estimates that washing dishes, going out and getting a job, for $195 a week last year will cost her $6,747 over the next five years. She concludes her letter by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no difference between the two same poor students with the same financial difficulty. One has been working, another has been on the dole. The working one certainly deserves no less amount of Austudy than the latter one. . . with such a policy of stupidity, how can a clever country not be stupid, and how can a lucky country not run out of luck? It is against Australia's national interest.

This student, who is new to our shores, has written a very powerful condemnation of the present system of student assistance under this government. She echoes the complaints that have been heard daily in this country's electorate offices. The coalition electorate offices constantly deal with people who want to further their education but due to government regulations find themselves unable to gain any financial assistance so they can live whilst studying.

PARA.TAB: There are very many people who are on unemployment benefits who find themselves unable to study because they cannot get assistance. HECS deals only with student fees. People still have to find the $7,000 or $8,000 a year just to live if they need to live away from home, as do most rural students who wish to go on to higher or further studies in Australia. This is an acute problem at the present time for many country people.

I have been told, for example, of a Gippsland family where the man earns $40,000 a year and has five children. Forty thousand dollars is not a lot of money and is certainly not a lot when it is distributed amongst seven people. His oldest child is a clever girl who excels at maths and science. Because he earns the princely sum of $40,000, his daughter does not qualify for Austudy. The student assistance centre informed him that he should take out a second mortgage to pay for his daughter's education. So he consulted the bank manager. What did the bank manager say? He said,`That is completely out of the question. There is no way we are going to grant you a second mortgage.' Why? Because he did not earn enough money. His daughter has forgone her university ambitions and has now gone to work as a nanny. Is this the Labor government's idea of equity?

When it was announced by the Department of Employment, Education and Training last year that health care card holders would automatically qualify for Austudy, many of Australia's farmers, who have been earning zero incomes for the last few years, breathed a collective sigh of relief. For example, Mari and Richard Pietsch have a diversified farm at Inglewood on the southern Downs, which is 150 kilometres from Toowoomba. They made $1,900 last year after meeting the general operating costs of their farm. For the two years before that time, they had a nil income. They have two children. One is on the land and the other is a second-year student at university. They got a health care card and applied for Austudy on 8 February, the day after the department discovered that all its literature for the past six months had contained an `error'. The health care card provision was not meant to let farmers with assets over the threshold pass through this keyhole for Austudy.

So they were told that, contrary to all the DEET publicity material for the previous six months, the Austudy guide and the applications forms, they would still have to pass an assets test in order to obtain this educational benefit for their child. A few days later, they were refused Austudy on the grounds that their assets were too high. Mari and Richard Pietsch cannot understand why city people can tie up their money in large expensive houses or companies and get Austudy while they, with a nil income and assets that have only a notional value because nobody wants to buy them in the current era, cannot get Austudy.

I recently met some people from the country who have had their farm on the market for over five years without one prospective buyer coming to see it. People in this situation in the current rural crisis in this country thought that this government was doing something for them, only to have their hopes ripped away from them a few months later.

The government has tied itself up in knots trying to explain why it has reversed its budget provision that health care card holders could get Austudy without having to undergo an assets test. When a Department of Employment, Education and Training internal memo changed tack on 7 February this year, there was no public admission by the government. Even though no less than five documents disseminated to the public by DEET stated the reverse, it was not felt there was any need to make a public statement clarifying the situation.

Senator Schacht told us in the Senate estimates committee that the government did not wish to alarm people for no good reason. But plenty of people had reason to be alarmed, because they had made plans over the previous six months and students had embarked on courses, or were about to do so in January and February this year, on the basis of information provided to them by a government department that they would be able to receive Austudy.

The decision not to tell the public directly was an admission of guilt. It is also a most bizarre way of enacting government policy. I suppose that if there were a meningitis epidemic, in health terms it would be kept quiet because some parents would, to use Senator Schacht's words, `become confused by believing it will affect them when it will not'. The government has a duty of care in this case to students and their parents, and it has failed to demonstrate any care.

The government's excuse has been that the change of decision about the health care card does not affect many people. In the Senate estimates supplementary hearings in March this year, it was stated that only 20 people in the whole of Australia who would have got Austudy under the health care card provision would miss out on it. I challenge the minister and the government: if really so few people will be affected, why be so mean and renege on a promise which people have been relying on?

I foreshadow that I am looking at the technical provisions relating to this legislation. If it is at all possible to amend this legislation which will implement what can be regarded as the government's policy, on the basis of the documents provided to students and their families by DEET, we will be moving such an amendment when this bill reaches the other place. In the meantime, I move a second reading amendment in the following terms:

That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Government has broken its promises to rural and regional families to waive the Austudy assets test for health care card holders".
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Ms CRAWFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to speak on the Student Assistance Amendment Bill, which looks at the way in which we fund students and proposes to amend the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act to enable payments to be adjusted to recover debts. It also provides for a range of measures in relation to isolated children and programs such as Abstudy and Austudy.

PARA.TAB: I find it interesting that honourable members opposite who purport to work only for the individual believe that the government has no role. We have heard them constantly cite the demand of their own constituents, which they believe is to get government off their backs. Now we hear constant demands for health care cards for people on the isolated children's allowance. These are the same people who opposed bulkbilling. It is quite an extraordinary amount of hypocrisy for a party on the one hand to espouse this kind of philosophy and on the other hand to make demands on this government for a whole range of services. I find it quite extraordinary given that over a decade this government has enormously expanded the range of services to students.

I think nothing is more indicative of this expansion than the student retention rate. All of us know the figures. We now see somewhere in the range of 70, 80 or 90 per cent of students completing year 12, which is an enormous change from the beginning of the decade. While we recognise that schools, schooling and curriculums need to change, this provides an opportunity for young people to be skilled and to participate in the 20th century. Many children do so because they have access to Austudy, Abstudy and some of the other programs, such as the isolated children's scheme. They too need to be part of that wider range and also to have the same kind of legislative approaches as all of us have. The Student Assistance Amendment Bill provides a legislative framework for these programs and brings them all under the one aegis. That is particularly important.

What we must recognise today are the opportunities, the changes, and the demands the community makes and students as individuals make upon our secondary system. We have seen some quite dramatic changes in the way in which secondary schooling and national schooling as a whole are conducted. They become more and more important as almost a quarter of Australia's school children move interstate every year. The states that are still dragging the chain on the issues of national schooling and the development of a national curriculum are denying their own students the right to participate in Australia. Yet again, they are putting states rights ahead of the national framework and national demands.

We are seeing some quite dramatic changes in the way in which schools deliver their schooling and the way in which students are able to access it. Yesterday's white paper looks at other different ways. One of the programs it cites is the TRAC program, which has been sponsored by Jack Dusseldorf and the Evatt Foundation. It has enabled students to work a number of days a week to gain work experience and to have that recognised within the school framework. I am delighted to see that there are even students in this very Parliament House who are on that program. They are not here today, but they are working in a couple of places around here.

I think those changes are particularly important. All of us think we know about schools and schooling. All of us at some stage have been there, and we tend to think that schools are the same as they were when we were there. Of course, things have changed quite dramatically. The change in information technology is enormous. For example, students now have access to a whole range of computers, to information technology and to bulletin boards.

The other great change that affects our lives is the impact of the mass media. Students now spend 25 hours a week at school. They also watch 25 hours a week television. When it comes to the impact on students and their learning and experiences, I think we all need to recognise that change is here; that change is here to stay; and that the way in which children learn and the kinds of things that impact on children's learning are very different now from as recently as 20 years ago. They certainly are changing at quite a dramatic pace.

Students themselves are making different kinds of demands. We have seen the enormous range of demands made on the TAFE sector and also on universities. We have seen industry make demands on both universities and TAFE colleges to ensure that what they are offering is meaningful and real in terms of the 21st century in Australia. The expansion in TAFE has been dramatic. The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) has had quite a large hand in that, and we congratulate him on that. I know that people in the community are delighted to at last see TAFE taking up the challenge of moving into the 21st century. TAFE colleges have made quite dramatic strides in working with secondary school students as well.

Only last week I was at Balmoral high school, in Brisbane, where we launched the key competencies. There we have a school which is operating an enormous range of programs that are also part of the TAFE sector. I saw students editing videos and films which they themselves had made. For example, the work that is now being done in drafting through computers is amazingly complex.

I think all of us sometimes forget what children's lives are like. I grew up in a house with neither a phone nor a car. When I look around now and see people with their own laptops and mobile phones, all I can say is that the world has changed enormously. I think we all need to be aware of that. When considering the kinds of opportunities that we provide for children, we have to recognise these changes.

The kind of employment and the kind of world which children will face are very different now. We are led to believe that 70 per cent of the jobs that will be around in the year 2010 or 2020 are yet to be discovered. All of us who care about our children, our community and the direction in which Australian schools, schooling and education are moving have to be enormously conscious of the change.

The key competencies recognise that change is here to stay; that we need a range of skills to take us through life; and that schooling, including tertiary education, is simply another step along the way—it is not the beginning and the end. Gone forever are the days of people entering the work force in a particular company and leaving it 30, 40 or 50 years later.

The changes which this bill looks at are about enabling all children, irrespective of where they live or who they are, to be part of a whole legislative framework which makes the same kinds of demands on them as it does on other Australians who receive income support assistance. It does not matter whether children are isolated, by definition, and living a long way out. Isolation involves quite a different process now. Most areas do have some access to learning through such things as video and television. Particularly in Western Australia—for example, in Karratha—a whole range of apprenticeship programs, modules and so on, are delivered through television across the Kimberleys. So `isolation' takes on a different meaning, and people interact socially in a different way.

For Aboriginal people, there is an enormous change in their cultural life, the way in which society functions and operates, the visions which Aboriginal parents have for their children and the demands their children make. All of us would recognise that very many Aboriginal children have been left behind enormously. The kinds of figures we have heard this week in the housing for health promotion and the mortality rates of Aboriginals and so on are testament to that. We must act. It is incumbent upon all of us to act. The same is true in the education sector, where we see Aboriginal children who have been left behind. We see their failure to complete primary school, their failure to complete secondary school and their inability to work in English. This is something that we must work to change, and we must work with Aboriginal communities to bring changes about.

All of us have to participate and be able to participate in the 21st century. As we skill Australia's work force, we need to keep changing skills. The key competencies in eight areas that I mentioned recognise that. We all need to be able to communicate. Communication now is not simply speaking; it is an ability to use a computer to a particular level. If we are to have equal opportunity, all of us have to be able to do that. Communication is an ability to be literate and numerate in the dominant language of this culture, which is English. All of us need to be able to participate in that. It is a question of being culturally aware and socially aware, and of recognising the kind of society in which we operate. I think all of us would value the democracy in which we live and our ability to participate—indeed, the compulsory notion of our ability to participate—in the political processes of this country at all three tiers of government.

As we have seen in the Prime Minister's white paper of yesterday, there is a need for those three tiers of government to work together to bring about the kinds of changes in our community and our society that all of us want to ensure that we all have a fair go. We have seen the federal government take a role and take a stand in moving education programs along, as well as work with state governments to bring those kinds of changes about.

Certainly there are some concerns with the Student Assistance Amendment Bill; but I think we would all recognise that, with the level of income support available, poor students for the first time actually have access to education and an ability to access education. All of us recognise that income support is absolutely crucial and vital to students' access to learning.

The other important issue of access is making sure that we have institutions, courses and schooling available to people in areas where they live. When we look at the University of Western Sydney and some of the newer universities, we recognise that Australia's population is spreading and that if we are going to realistically offer access and equity to our students then we must deliver courses, programs and schooling in areas where students live.

So we see an expansion of universities, and certainly an expansion of the newer universities. TAFE has been particularly responsive. TAFE has been able to offer a range of outreach services, it has ensured that it has a range of campuses and it has been able to respond particularly to local and regional demands in providing the kinds of courses and programs that have been recognised and identified as being necessary in areas. I know it will continue to do that.

The whole issue of student assistance at times can be particularly vexed. We know and understand that some students believe they have entitlements to partake fully of their opportunities. All of us would hope that we can continue to expand these processes. Of course, part of enabling that to happen is ensuring that those people who do not have entitlements or who have been overpaid are penalised and made to pay, because then we will have more money for those people who are entitled to, and need to be able to access, education services to fully participate in the educational process: the training programs and the other kinds of services they want.

I commend this bill to the House because it is about ensuring that all people are treated fairly and evenly. It also provides a legislative framework in which to operate. All students—irrespective of who they are, where they come from or which particular aspect of student income and student assistance programs they access—are treated in exactly the same way. But once again I say to the House that students are our most important treasure. We must ensure that all of them have the very best education, and that means having the very best access to education and an opportunity to take advantage of that. That is exactly what student assistance provides for.

I think the numbers of students staying in schools, participating in TAFE, tertiary institutions and other training programs is testament to the fact that the community at large embraces student assistance. It believes in it and sees a role for the federal government in providing this kind of student assistance and doing it on a fair, just and equitable basis. So, as we move to the 21st century, we have to be assured that student assistance remains part of our income support programs across Australia and also becomes an integral part of providing for a whole range of students in a way in which they can access, develop and grow. None of us know the kind of jobs there will be in the 21st century, but we know that there is a basic number of skills and there is a basic level of competencies which all school children in Australia are entitled to have, and we must ensure that they have them.

While we have a national agenda which ensures those key competencies, while we have an agenda for national schooling and while we have a national agenda which looks at disadvantaged children in disadvantaged schools and ensures that they are treated in a special kind of way because of their particular needs, then I know that members in this House are assured that children have an equal opportunity to education and will continue to have that opportunity. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1994. This bill makes some minor amendments to the Student Assistance Act, on which the Austudy scheme is based. These amendments are as follows: firstly, to provide a legislative basis for the assistance for the isolated children scheme and for Abstudy; and, secondly, to extend the debt management regime under the act to cover other educational assistance schemes such as ATAS, the Aboriginal tutorial assistance scheme, and to decriminalise penalties that relate to a failure to notify change of circumstances in time to allow the department to alter payment to the recipients of benefits under the various schemes. I particularly applaud this latter amendment because the legislation can in certain circumstances have some unintended and unfortunate consequences for individuals who are perhaps less than fully aware of the requirements they have to comply with under the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The third amendment is to implement changes with respect to the repayment of benefits under Austudy and Abstudy in relation to eligibility for the financial supplement that applies. Finally, there is an amendment to ensure that the dependent spouse allowance which applies under Austudy is indexed and thus to ensure that those receiving that allowance are not effectively discriminated against with respect to the real value of that allowance.

These are generally housekeeping amendments in order to ensure that the act has an overall coherence and that there is logic and symmetry across the various components of the student financing regime that now applies in this country. I would like to take this opportunity to make a few comments on the question of student financing generally because it is a matter of some considerable interest to me and of particular interest to people in my constituency, because I have a very large number of students living in my electorate who attend mostly RMIT and the University of Melbourne but also some other institutions.

I look back on my experience. I lived for approximately five years on the forerunner to Austudy, the tertiary education assistance scheme, or TEAS. I was able to qualify under the independent status provisions, which were not a great deal different from the independent status provisions that now apply to Austudy. When I look back on my own experience, I wonder how students manage to survive under the current arrangements, complete their courses and go on to play a full role in the economic affairs of our society, given the restrictions that apply, the real incomes they have to put up with and the debt they have to carry into their post-education lives.

Back in 1978 it took me about six months to battle with the bureaucracy over my own qualification for independent assistance, and I was finally successful. For that six months I had no income and so built up considerable debt. For the next four or five years, I lived on an income that was extremely limited. It meant that I, along with many other people, was forced to live in what I think anybody would consider to be substandard housing. I spent very little money on clothes and other basic necessities. I was left in a position where scraping together an existence day to day was reasonably difficult. I survived okay. I am no worse for the experience, but there were many others in those circumstances who were worse off than I was. They had considerable difficulty putting together the requisite money to be able to survive and complete their education.

My parents were not wealthy, but they were better off than many. I wanted to be independent of them, and I was. By this stage I was in my early twenties and was long distant from that connection. By the time I left Melbourne University I had debts to the student loan scheme of roughly $2,500, which was a fairly considerable sum of money in the early 1980s. I also had other debts that had been incurred as a result of studying in higher education. It took me several years of employment before I was finally able to repay those debts.

This was at a time when the higher education contribution scheme did not apply. So I had no debts related to fees for studying at an institution. I repeat my observation that I wonder how those students who are now studying at places such as University of Melbourne manage to scrape by. I wonder what sorts of daunting prospects face them when they finally enter the work force, which is no longer necessarily immediately upon completing their course, and are, in some instances, faced with a mountain of debts.

Unfortunately, one myth that is prominent in many areas of our community, not the least of which is within the Australian Labor Party—and it dates back to the 1940s and 1950s—is that all students are the children of the rich, that the kids of ordinary people do not go to university, colleges of advanced education or their modern day equivalents and that, therefore, any notions of assistance to students means that ordinary workers are subsidising the children of the rich. When we look at the statistics—the origins of people who attended higher education institutions; the geographic and demographic distribution of those people; and the relatively small numbers of those people—we see that there was probably a fair amount of truth in that observation back in the 1950s. But it certainly is no longer the case now.

There is still something of a bias towards people from professional backgrounds. But we now have over 500,000 people in the higher education system, and a large number of them are from very ordinary and average backgrounds. A change in mind-set has become increasingly important within the public affairs of this nation to recognise that we are no longer dealing with institutions that cater for the children of the rich.

I add that, regardless of whatever other criticisms I may have of policy with respect to student financing in higher education, it certainly is to the government's great credit that the number of people in higher education has almost doubled in the 11 years that this government has been in office. The other point about the class origins of people in higher education is that, by and large, people from rich backgrounds do not qualify for assistance through schemes such as Austudy. There are some fancy mechanisms that people from well-off backgrounds can manage to qualify for because their parents are self-employed and can get them independent status perhaps when they should not, but they will always be a tiny minority. Efforts are always made to prevent that sort of thing from occurring. By and large, people from wealthy backgrounds do not qualify for the assistance. The assistance goes where it is needed.

The problem we now have, which is very clearly linked to the unemployment circumstances that yesterday's white paper is targeted towards, is that a recent investigation by the Australian Government Actuary found that 16 1/2 per cent of graduates would be unlikely to ever pay off their HECS debts and that the Commonwealth should write off approximately $376 million of HECS debts as bad debts. Degrees are no longer the automatic meal ticket that they once were for many people. For example, approximately half of law graduates are now unemployed six months after having completed their course. When I completed my law course, there was no consideration as to whether or not we would get a job. The consideration related to what sort of job we would get. That has changed even in an elite area such as law. It is doubly the case in some of the less prestigious courses offered in higher education institutions.

We are no longer talking about a gravy train that is there to provide people with huge incomes for the rest of their lives. Higher education will provide that for some but, for a growing majority, higher education will simply be a ticket to a relatively ordinary, average paid job in the work force eventually. That ought to be acknowledged in the structure of the higher education contribution scheme.

The justification for HECS that graduates are an economically privileged group and, therefore, that they should pay directly through their contribution for the source of that privilege is substantially weaker now than it was in the mid-1980s. It is still there to some extent, but it is questionable as to how much notice one should take of that.

There are a number of weaknesses in the current Austudy arrangements. The most obvious is that Austudy payments are significantly less than unemployment benefits. Students often have more costs. I agree that people who are unemployed have substantial costs due to jobsearch activities and the like, but students often also have substantial costs that are not covered by Austudy arrangements. For example, one of my constituents is undertaking a textile design course. She is very highly motivated, but she has been having financial difficulties. She is having extreme problems finding the roughly $1,000 a year that she needs to pay for materials, such as paints, that are relevant to her course. These are the sorts of things that many students have to deal with on an income that is lower than the unemployment benefit.

There is an obvious disincentive for people who are unemployed to return to study when the Austudy payment is lower. As the pot of gold is no longer at the end of the rainbow, as I have indicated, that disincentive is now magnified with the doubt as to whether going back to study and completing a degree, a diploma or whatever will substantially enhance that person's employability. That clearly is a problem that we need to address. Having incentives for people to upgrade their skills and get further qualifications to become more employable is obviously critically important to the employment prospects of people in this country. It is something that was central to the white paper released yesterday.

I still see in my electorate many of the problems associated with the low levels of assistance provided through Austudy. I see people who are very motivated and committed to performing well, getting their degrees and going onto bigger and better things, but who are literally struggling to pay the rent and afford the basic necessities of life. I ask the government to pay some serious attention to trying to lift the level of Austudy. The guidelines for independent Austudy are still too tight, particularly in a period of high unemployment. Many students who do not get parental support and who are genuinely independent of their parents are unable to qualify.

People who are on Austudy do not automatically qualify for health care cards. Yes, it is true that many of the services that are accessible to people on health care cards, such as dental services, are actually accessible in some institutions to students at those institutions. It is necessary to qualify that point.

Students who are working part time cannot claim self-education expenses as tax deductions even though, quite clearly, the costs that they are incurring with respect to their education are related to their ability to earn future income. Those who are on Austudy have the capacity to claim those expenses as tax deductions but there are many people who do not qualify for Austudy, who are by no means well off and who do not have the ability to claim self-education expenses as tax deductions.

Students do not get rent assistance. Particularly in inner city areas, such as the one that I represent, rental costs can be extremely high. I applaud wholeheartedly the initiative in yesterday's white paper which provides people who are eligible for unemployment benefits with the opportunity to receive up to $500 or $1,000 in advance in order to allow them to pay, effectively, start-up costs, such as costs for tools and materials. This initiative provides yet another gap between the effective level of unemployment benefits assistance and Austudy.

These problems are also exacerbated by the rapid and unregulated growth of fees on many campuses. It is extremely disturbing to see that some vice-chancellors have been promoting the notion that domestic students should be able to buy their way into our higher education institutions by paying full fees, even if their secondary education results do not qualify them. This totally misconceives the nature of the overseas student intake that occurs in Australian higher education. That notion would allow us to return not only to the bad old days but to worse than the bad old days because it would create a situation where people could actually get preference of position in higher education according to their parents' income, according to their wealth, rather than according to their academic merit. The tiny enrolments in private higher education institutions, such as Bond University, tend to suggest that there really is not much of a demand for this type of provision anyway. But that may not necessarily remain the case once we allow it to happen.

I was part of the very first intake in Australian universities who did not have to pay fees, courtesy of the Whitlam government. Unlike some in this place, I do not back away from supporting the Whitlam government's reforms in many areas, none the least being in the area of higher education. As far as I am concerned, when the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said to the media that the white paper is a Whitlamite adventure, he could pay no greater compliment to yesterday's white paper. Not everybody in the Labor Party thinks like that but I thank the Leader of the Opposition, and may he give us more compliments of that nature.

I regard HECS in some respects as a step back from the reforms that the Whitlam government introduced, but I would have to concede that the fears that I held for the impact of HECS have not come about to anywhere near the extent that I thought. Yes, it has acted as a disincentive for some people to enter into or to continue in higher education but nowhere near to the extent that I feared. But I would make that concession. I would also concede that HECS has provided a significant part of the funding necessary to ensure the massive expansion of higher education that has occurred in this country. Therefore, I fear that extensions of HECS, changes to HECS, could have those effects. I would much prefer to hold the line where it is although, as I have indicated, I feel that there is considerable scope for changes to Austudy.

The loan supplement that was introduced to Austudy a couple of years ago should be either substantially altered or abolished. This is because, in effect, students who are able to get a bank loan would be better off getting their full Austudy and the bank loan to take them up to the total amount available under the loan scheme plus a truncated Austudy. I am afraid that that is—and I hope the minister pardons me for saying this—something like the service that Waltons used to offer. I really think that we should have a close look at that scheme.

What worries me with students and debt—and it is something that has not been studied, to the best of my knowledge—is that the level of debts that many students are now taking into their post-education lives must be having an effect on their economic decisions. There are some students who would like to start businesses and the like but the number of debts that they are taking into that period of their lives must be adversely impacting on their economic behaviour.

I would like to finally comment on another problem—and the shadow minister probably will stop nodding when I say these things—which has recently surfaced in the states of Victoria and Western Australia, which also impacts on the ability of students to conduct their ordinary affairs and live a reasonable life and so forth while they are studying: the push to introduce voluntary student unionism. I speak with particular reference to the Kennett government's legislation which is basically designed to attack organisations that the Liberal Party sees as sources of political opposition. It has been dressed up in all sorts of civil liberties garb and stuff about rights of voluntary association and the like. In reality it is about trying to knock off organisations that generally speaking are run by people on the left of the political spectrum, but not always. Probably 20 per cent or 30 per cent, maybe more, of Australian student unions would be run at the moment by people on the right of the political spectrum, but generally a majority have been run by people on the left of the spectrum and that is what the Liberal Party and Jeff Kennett do not like.

Voluntary student unionism will force up the costs of many ordinary student services that students, particularly lower income students, rely on—such as student catering services that are subsidised. The higher costs resulting from the pursuit of an obscure ideological obsession that really relates to nothing other than political advantage for the Liberal Party would add yet another financial burden on the students. That has been shown by recent internal documents from the Liberal Party which indicate quite clearly that that is what the agenda is. In answer to a question I raised in this House a couple of months ago, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) referred to a leaflet which gave a Liberal Party phone number as a return phone number for students for voluntary student unionism. It is quite clear what the campaign is about.

I have participated in ballots with students at Melbourne university about voluntary student unionism. An overwhelming majority—two-thirds or thereabouts—supported compulsory student unionism. That was some time ago but I venture to suggest that equivalent ballots now would produce the same result. We also see that, through legislation, Victoria is deciding that certain activities currently done by student organisations can be the subject of compulsory fees without membership and without rights of representations, and certain activities cannot. The classic contrast can be drawn between sport and theatre. Student sport can and will be the subject of a compulsory levy which people who have no interest in sport will have to pay, but student theatre cannot be because student theatre has to be voluntary. This may give us cause to reflect on the philistine nature of the Kennett government, but it does indicate that we have a totally arbitrary basis for deciding that certain compulsorily levied fees for certain events and certain activities are okay and others are not. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure today to support my colleague the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) and others from this side in this debate because, again, these are initiatives that we are proud of. I was most interested to hear the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) and I must admit I am becoming increasingly wary when members of the opposition stand up and say, `We are not going to oppose this; it is only a housekeeping bill' and then they proceed to attack initiatives of this government.

PARA.TAB: I would remind the honourable member for Menzies that this year our government will contribute $3 billion to school education. That is something that we are proud of. It is an unprecedented amount that is being expended by a federal government on school education, and I would ask him to compare that to the record of the Kennett government in Victoria in particular and the Greiner-Fahey government in New South Wales and what their effect has been on delivering school services in those two states. Over the past 12 months in Victoria, and a longer period in New South Wales, we have seen an unprecedented attack on school education by those governments. When I talk about school education there, I talk about state education: the delivery of educational services to the ordinary children, the ordinary people of Australia.

Having been a teacher for some 30 years in the school education system of New South Wales, I know that children in remote areas, in country schools, are not taught at any less a level than those at any other school. As a matter of fact, the last school I taught in has an enviable record of regularly producing top students from the Hunter region. It consistently gets students into the top hundred of the higher school certificate in New South Wales. That is what can happen when there is a commitment from the staff to do their job.

Over the last couple of months I have had the pleasure of attending the openings of school facilities. At Maitland High School, formerly Maitland Boys High School, I had the pleasure of being present when a facility, towards which this government contributed $760,000, was opened by the state minister, although of course she did not have the courtesy to invite the federal minister to attend. The state government did not contribute as much as the federal government did, but it insisted on the right to open that facility. Then, only a couple of weeks ago, I attended the extensions to Dungog High School, to which the federal government had contributed $600,000. In a couple of weeks time, I know that the federal minister will be present in my electorate to open a science laboratory, which has been fully funded by the federal government, at the Hunter Valley Grammar School. In a couple of weeks, I personally will be opening a new home science facility, which has been funded by the federal government, at the Bulahdelah Central School. They are initiatives of which we are proud. Of course, when we extrapolate the openings of new facilities from all over the country, it indicates our contribution to school education.

I do not want to be chastened for not debating the legislation before us, so let me get back to the topic. Essentially, the Commonwealth Reciprocal Recovery Legislation Amendment Bill is about administrative management. It seeks to facilitate the reciprocal recovery of overpayments of benefits under the Social Security Act, the Student Assistance Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act. It sometimes happens that a person has incurred a debt to the Commonwealth under one income maintenance act but is receiving an entitlement under another. The Social Security Act, the Student Assistance Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act all need amendments so that overpayments by one department can be recovered by another. This means, in effect, that if, say, a person has received an overpayment of Austudy or any other benefits under the Student Assistance Act, including a late payment charge, and then is receiving some maintenance from Social Security, those overpayments can be deducted from his or her social security benefits; and vice versa. The same applies to overpayments made under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. In other words, debts will be portable.

The legislation is a means of recovering debts from people's failure to repay. It is only proper that the Commonwealth should have this right of recovery, just as the private sector does. It is important from an administrative point of view that the majority of these clauses of the legislation commence on 1 July this year. This means that a satisfactory lead time for procedures can be put in place for the new recovery arrangements.

I am sure that no honourable member of this House will dispute the need for such measures. Debts to the Commonwealth arising from income maintenance overpayments amount to about $1 million in a full financial year. Only about 72 per cent of Austudy-Abstudy overpayments are currently recovered, and this is a significant amount.

However, there is also the principle involved of personal responsibility, of personal accountability. I am sure that many persons who find themselves in the situation of having received overpayments—and it is not always their fault; they do not do it consciously—will welcome the opportunity for repayments that are managed for them in a mutually satisfactory way. We are not talking about a hard-hearted government with a Shylock mentality. Government agencies will negotiate with the person who has incurred the debt to work out mutually suitable repayment arrangements. After consultation, repayments will be tailored to individual needs.

The Student Assistance Amendment Bill proposes to extend significantly the scope of the Student Assistance Act 1973 which provides the basis for the Austudy scheme and the Austudy-Abstudy supplement. It also provides a debt management regime for unlegislated student assistance schemes. It is proposed that applicants for assistance under the Abstudy and assistance for isolated children scheme will be able to seek a review of departmental assessments by appealing to the Student Assistance Review Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It will also extend the debt management regime which I have outlined previously to include the Aboriginal student support and parent awareness program, the Aboriginal tutorial assistance scheme and the vocational and educational guidance for Aboriginals scheme. Debts incurred through overpayments of the Austudy-Abstudy scheme under a stay order of the AAT, or a court, or under the Data-Matching Act will now be recoverable.

I am also pleased to note that the legislation encompasses several commonsense changes. The dependent spouse allowance under Austudy will be indexed in line with changes to the CPI. Also, where currently it is an offence for a person who has been receiving Austudy and has had a change to his or her circumstances to fail to notify the department within seven days, it is now proposed to decriminalise this offence. A charge of $10 a week will be substituted. It is also proposed to extend the period from seven to 14 days. I am pleased to note that the minister will be able to issue guidelines for departmental officers to follow when they are deciding whether students who have obtained a supplement loan by fraud should have to repay it immediately rather than under the HECS type arrangements.

It will also be clarified that it is an offence if a person knowingly receives student assistance to which he or she is not entitled. The taxable income thresholds for the compulsory repayment of financial supplement debts will be varied so that they are equivalent to the thresholds of the higher education contribution scheme. The total amount of financial supplement payable to a student will be reduced where the student requests a lesser amount of financial supplement or where there is a reduction in the amount for which the student is eligible.

The financial impact of these measures may not be considered great. A saving of about $2.5 million in the first year is anticipated, and other changes do not involve additional expenditure. However, the saving of $2.5 million, added to the accountability and the responsibility of the individuals, I think is the underlying concept of these proposed changes. The indexing of the dependent spouse allowance involves no additional expenditure under the act, and the establishing of the Abstudy scheme and assistance for isolated children scheme on a legislated basis are revenue neutral.

The Student Assistance Act, which provides the framework for Austudy for lower income families to attend educational institutions, is one of the great achievements of this government. In 1992-93, it spent $1.438 billion on Austudy; 466,000 Australians received assistance.

The Social Security Act 1991 is, likewise, one of this government's more compassionate achievements and one which sets us apart from the opposition. It is enshrined in the principle of social justice and equity of offering a helping hand to our fellow Australians when they need it. The Veterans' Entitlements Act, passed in 1986, affirmed our commitment to the members of our ex-service community and their dependants. Subsequent federal budgets have continued to improve the range and quality of services to our veterans as a continuing recognition of a debt that can never fully be repaid.

The current legislation before the House is finetuning legislation. It in no way detracts from the underlying principles. It will enhance their effectiveness and their essential equity. I have great pleasure in supporting it.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the debate, I thank those who took part. It was quite a wide ranging debate when one considers that we are dealing with bills which are fairly specific in their intention. I will resist the temptation to discuss the higher education contribution scheme, Austudy supplement or Austudy in general. I will resist the temptation to talk about voluntary student unionism and even the new schools in the Hunter Valley, of which the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne) is obviously so proud.

PARA.TAB: Two matters raised by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) are relevant to the bills. On the question of repayment of debt by instalment, I am happy to confirm that the rate of instalment can be adjusted to suit the means of the particular person involved. Secondly, the honourable member for Menzies expressed some concern about the administration of debt recovery, given that we are dealing with a number of different acts here. The administration of debt recovery will be different, of course, because it is under different legislation. Officers of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, for example, will be using tabled guidelines under the Student Assistance Act. The Department of Social Security operates under secretaries guidelines issued under the Social Security Act.

The honourable member for Menzies should take comfort from what was said in the second reading speech on the reciprocal recovery legislation, which makes it clear that the rationalisation of debt recovery provisions in the bill will not be leading to an increase in the level of deductions from a person's payment. In other words, the government is quite aware of the need to balance a debtor's need for adequate income maintenance with his responsibility to pay debts due to the Commonwealth as expeditiously as possible. Notwithstanding that, yes, there will be different administrative regimes.

I should deal with some of the other remarks of the honourable member for Menzies, who took the opportunity to chide the government for what he regarded as lack of achievement of the objectives encapsulated in the phrase `the clever country'. I admire the capacity of the honourable member for Menzies to attack the government in such a way without blushing. Certainly he was a fine lawyer; he is obviously a fine member of the opposition if he can attack the government on its achievements in education and not blush at the same time.

I take this opportunity to remind the honourable member for Menzies and the House that when the government came to office in 1983 around one in three young Australians completed full secondary education through to year 12. Last year, it was a little under 80 per cent. Secondary retention rates have risen to an outstanding extent over the period that this government has been in office. Equally, I should remind him, as the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) did during his contribution, of the outstanding expansion in the higher education area that has occurred during the period that this government has been in office.

When we took office there were around 16 universities in this country, mainly in capital cities, to cater for a relatively small undergraduate population, dealing with those relatively few youngsters who went on to complete a full secondary education. We have revolutionised the higher education system during our period in government. The unified national system now has something like 38 member universities across the country. The undergraduate population has expanded to a very large extent and universities are now to be found across the country, not just largely in capital cities.

The honourable member for Menzies also really ought to understand what the government has achieved and what it has in mind in the vocational education and training sector. The commitment over a four-year period of an additional $1.1 billion from the government in growth funds will enable us to build a first-class vocational education and training system in this country, allowing us to develop the skills in our own population that we will need as the recovery continues.

I can remember the recovery of the early 1980s. As the recovery from the recession, induced by the former government, gathered pace, skills were simply not available for industry. As a result, this country had to use migration programs to import skills. With the development of the first-class vocational education and training system in this country, with a commitment of resources like $1.1 billion provided by this government in additional growth money, we have the opportunity to develop those skills among our own population. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made it quite clear in his statement on the white paper yesterday and in his remarks this morning that this is an important objective of the white paper program.

Certainly some of the political colleagues of the honourable member for Menzies in the Victorian government understand the importance of this, so much so that they are anxious to take credit for some of this additional Commonwealth money in their own economic statement, which was tabled in the Victorian parliament last week. In that statement the Victorian government claimed some $80 million of Commonwealth TAFE capital as its own. I certainly understand that it shares our objectives, so much so that it wants to claim our expenditure as its own. People, including the honourable member for Menzies, ought to understand that the TAFE system of the 1990s is certainly not the TAFE system of the 1960s or 1970s. It is a first-class system offering a range of opportunities that were simply not available a decade or two ago.

The honourable member for Menzies and the honourable member for Melbourne both treated us to some interesting anecdotal evidence on student assistance. I should point out to both the honourable member for Menzies and the honourable member for Melbourne that the question of aligning rates is something that has concerned the government for some time. It is not an easy set of problems because allowances are paid to different people for different purposes. On the one hand, unemployment benefit is intended to be assistance, for a limited term, to people out of work in the job search activity. Student assistance, on the other hand, is to provide assistance over the period of a course, taking into account family income and assets, essentially to give that student the capacity to undertake further study.

The Commonwealth student assistance schemes have provided over $1 1/2 billion this year to more than half a million students and the system has grown over 10 years or so. The government at the time of the early 1980s, for example, spent around $300 million on student assistance under a scheme which was certainly more complex than the present one.

The contrast drawn between the unemployed person over 21 and the over 21-year-old full-time student is the kind of contrast that students will often offer. Almost universally they will not mention that their capacity for part-time earnings is much greater under Austudy. They will not say that their capacity for earning without affecting benefits during university vacations is much greater than that of those on unemployment benefits, nor very often will they tell about their access to the Austudy supplement, which is a very good option for some students who might choose to use that to obtain funds for up-front purposes such as those as described by the honourable member for Melbourne.

I found the case of the father of five on an income of $40,000 interesting. I would be happy to look at the details that the honourable member for Menzies has outlined. We should all be aware that the cut-off point for a student living away from home is $42,487 before one takes into account deductions for other children. The deduction for the first child is $1,200, $2,500 for the next and $3,700 for children 16 or over. On the face of it, I would have thought that the family which the honourable member for Menzies described would have an entitlement under Austudy. As I say, I would be happy to look at the details. I would be surprised if the student assistance centre actually offered the kind of advice that the person writing to him has suggested he received.

Finally, the honourable member for Menzies has used the debate and his amendment as an opportunity to make a point about access to Austudy under the health care card. I remind him that it is a fiction to say—and it is a fiction that has been repeated in this House this morning and on other occasions—that it was ever the intention of the government to waive the Austudy assets test for any particular group of applicants. The situation arose as a result of a misinterpretation of the government system, and it was unfortunately repeated in a number of documents. It was not the government's intention to waive the assets test for farming families holding the health care card. The honourable member would be aware that already a generous assets test concession applies to farming and small business families. It allows a 50 per cent discounting of assets and, therefore, enables farmers to have assets of around three-quarters of a million dollars before withdrawal of assistance.

The government will not be accepting the amendment proposed by the honourable member for Menzies. Again, I commend him for raising this matter in such an unblushing manner. I say `unblushing' because no doubt he was at the occasion of the burial of Fightback at the Eagle Hawk motel a couple of weekends ago. He should remember that, had the opposition formed government in March last year and been on this side of the House now, under Fightback it would probably be legislating to remove $30 million from student assistance schemes. It would probably be now in the process of removing student assistance from some 30,000 students. Fightback proposed that some 30,000 students would lose Austudy, ripping $30 million out of the scheme. It is not a bad effort for the honourable member for Menzies to come in here and unblushingly complain about 20 individuals who have been inconvenienced when, at the same time, he knows that the opposition has just disposed of a policy that would have removed student assistance from 30,000 students.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

PARA.TAB: The proposals given effect to in this bill are founded on outcomes of the waterfront reform process undertaken by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, WIRA. The bill amends the stevedoring industry levy legislative framework and the Industrial Relations Act 1988.

The Department of Industrial Relations presently administers the following acts, known generically as `the Stevedoring Acts': the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee Act 1977, the Stevedoring Industry Levy Act 1977, the Stevedoring Industry Levy Collection Act 1977 and the Stevedoring Industry Acts (Termination) Act 1977.

The stevedoring acts establish and provide arrangements for the collection of a general levy and a special levy, which has three components. The general levy was used to fund industry employment arrangements and has ceased to apply. The special levy is used to repay loan obligations entered into to finance the stevedoring employers' contribution to the special one-off early retirement redundancy package made available under the waterfront reform program.

In addition, division 9 of part VI of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 provides for port conciliators and port and federal coordinating committees for the stevedoring industry. These arrangements were designed to support pre-reform industry employment. There are currently no port conciliators or coordinating committees.

The waterfront reform program was based on an in-principle agreement, IPA, negotiated between the government, stevedoring employers, unions and the ACTU, and implemented over a three-year period from October 1989 to October 1992, under the auspices of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority. As part of the reform of the industry framework, the IPA called for the restructuring of awards and agreements. A new award, the stevedoring industry award, was ratified in November 1991. The award included a skills-based classification structure which saw the former `waterside worker' classification replaced by `stevedoring employee', together with a wider definition of stevedoring operations.

The final report of WIRA incorporated a report on the review of the IPA conducted by the parties. The parties recommended changes to the stevedoring industry legislative framework and the Industrial Relations Act 1988. The changes in the industry reflected in the award, and the WIRA recommendations, have been taken into account in the bill.
The bill contains a number of amendments of a minor nature which are explained in the explanatory memorandum. The key principal amendments proposed in the bill are as follows.

The provision for a general levy in the Levy Act is to be abolished. The special levy will continue to be collected and applied to meet the industry's loan obligation until that obligation is fulfilled. On current estimates the loan is expected to be paid in full by late 1995. The amendments to the current legislation are not intended to change the application of the levy arrangements. In this regard and in the light of the cessation of the registration arrangements which had applied in the industry since 1977, the bill prescribes those stevedoring employees in respect of whom the levy will and will not be payable.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee (the committee)

PARA.TAB: The committee's primary role will be in relation to the special levy and the repayment of the existing loan. The committee will also retain certain continuing obligations as the successor to the previous industry body.

A revised structure of the committee will reduce the number of members from nine (9) to four (4), while retaining employer, union and departmental representation, together with an independent chairperson.

The committee is currently required to maintain registers of waterside workers consistent with the General Agreement of 1977 between stevedoring employers and the union (now Maritime Union of Australia). These provisions were part of the industry-based employment arrangements which characterised the industry prior to the reform program. The provision for registers was also relevant to meeting Australia's obligations in relation to ILO convention 137. At the completion of the reform program, all parties agreed that the registration system incorporated in the General Agreement of 1977 would cease to apply. The bill removes the requirement that the committee maintain a register of waterside workers for these purposes and in relation to levy collection, although the committee will establish a register of names of stevedoring employees, consistent with the convention.

I foreshadow that when we move to consideration of the bill in detail I will move a government amendment to make it clear that the register can be constituted by the time and wages records of stevedoring employers already maintained under the Industrial Relations Act 1988, or other relevant records. Let me say that it will be in accordance with assurances that I have given the House and will not impose any additional requirements on employers.
