The bill inserts sunset provisions in each of the stevedoring acts which will ensure that each stevedoring act is repealed when the committee's remaining functions have been fulfilled.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The IR Act: port conciliators and coordination committees

PARA.TAB: Since the move to enterprise employment in the stevedoring industry, the port conciliators

SPEECH.PARA: and port and federal port coordinating committees serve no continuing function. Accordingly, Division 9 of Part VI of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 is to be repealed.
Conclusion

PARA.TAB: The bill will have no significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. I commend this bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate on behalf of the opposition and say at the outset that the opposition will be proposing certain amendments to the legislation and in the event of those amendments being unacceptable to the government we will be voting against the legislation.

PARA.TAB: It is supremely ironic that the House should be debating a bill dealing with industrial relations only a day after the government's employment statement. The government has invested an enormous amount of the political and economic capital of the nation in the employment white paper that was brought down yesterday by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The government would have us believe that this represents a revisiting of earlier days when a former Labor Prime Minister, Ben Chifley, produced a white paper in favour of full employment. The government has committed billions of dollars towards an attempted solution of Australia's chronic unemployment problem. Yet almost unnoticed, almost silently as if deliberately by design, the government has been changing the industrial relations laws of this country in a way that makes unemployment likely to rise rather than fall, in a way that is likely to further complicate the workplace rules that prevent small employers taking on new staff, in a way that entrenches the rigidities of Australia's already very rigid industrial relations system.

The broad fact is that Australia has one of the worst unemployment levels in the industrialised world. I heard the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free), in his response to the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), talk about the capacity of the honourable member for Menzies to make allegations against the government without blushing. I never cease to be amazed at the capacity of the Prime Minister, in particular, to make claims about Australia's unemployment performance, to make claims about what his government has done to tackle that problem, without blushing. He would have us believe that we are like the rest of the world when it comes to unemployment. That, of course, is not true.

The Prime Minister would have to be the most selectively comparing Prime Minister this country has ever had. When it suits him, the countries that he compares Australia with are the dynamic economies of the Asian Pacific region. When it suits one purpose that is what he does. When it suits another purpose, he would compare us with the countries of Europe and of North America. When it comes to unemployment, we never hear the Prime Minister comparing Australia with the United States or with Japan. He says, `Our unemployment problem is like everybody else's.' It is not. The Americans have an unemployment level of 6 1/2 per cent. When we bear in mind the enormous urban underclass that the United States has in its major cities, particularly in the north east, we have an idea of how much better the Americans are doing with unemployment than we are.

One of the reasons the Americans do better with unemployment is that they have a far more flexible labour market. They have a capacity to regenerate and to come back and to recover. Because of the flexibility of the American labour market, when economic recovery begins, it is not the government that reaches back and picks up the people—it is the private business sector of the American economy that reaches back and picks up the people. The only way you reach back and pick up people is to have a business sector that has the right incentives to employ.

The right incentives do not only involve subsidies and taxation measures; they also involve the absence of anti-employment workplace rules. If there is one thing that this country excels at it is anti-employment workplace rules. We have just had an industrial relations act passed by this parliament, with the support of the Australian Democrats and the Western Australian Greens and in the teeth of the opposition of both the Liberal and National parties, which actually makes it less attractive for small business to take on new staff.

We are dealing here today with amendments to the Industrial Relations Act which in turn deal with the Australian waterfront, the stevedoring industry, which probably in a way is the Aunt Sally of industrial relations rorts in the industrial relations history of this country. There is no area of industrial behaviour so etched in the Australian consciousness and so associated in the Australian consciousness with abuse of privilege, union inspired rorts, bullying tactics and privileges being claimed and conceded by governments over the years as the Australian waterfront.

It is worth for a moment putting into perspective the claims made by the government that somehow or other it has wrought wondrous miracles over the last 11 years in improving the performance of the Australian waterfront. We keep being told by the government and by the Prime Minister that the last 11 years has been an unending, uninterrupted parade of economic triumph and economic success. We are told about the marvellous structural changes that have occurred. Unblushingly the claim is made that the Australian economy is now the fastest growing in the industrialised world.

The minister who spoke a few moments ago told us that the retention levels in Australian schools were much lower in 1983 than they are now, and he claimed that that was somehow the result of a deliberate government policy. The reason the retention levels were much lower in 1983 than they are now is that 11 years ago most young people thought they could get a job when they left school. They did not have embedded in their consciousness the belief that they had to remain at school because there was fundamentally no alternative. Of course there was high youth unemployment in 1983, but it had not been a decade-long phenomenon. Therefore, at that particular time, the expectations of young Australians were nowhere near as pessimistic. For the government to seriously and unblushingly say that the high retention rate is the result of an inspired, deliberate policy construct of its 11 years in office is absolutely ridiculous.

We keep getting told that the Australian waterfront is super efficient and that the reforms this government has brought in have been absolutely brilliant. In recent times, Australian waterfront costs have declined. Of course they have declined. It is the relative performance in that area that is important to our economic achievement. Over the last few years Australia's waterfront costs have declined by between five and 10 per cent. Over that same period, New Zealand's costs—remember New Zealand; the government always likes to knock New Zealand when it suits—have declined by 45 per cent, and that is from a base that was already lower than Australia's. Sydney's stevedoring costs are now up to five times higher than New Zealand's.

As I have said before, we do not compete against our past. There is no point in the government saying that Australia's situation is better now than it was 20 years ago. What matters is whether it is better or as good compared to the countries that are fighting for the same share of the same market. The reality is that this international competitiveness is a never ending race and unless we keep in front, we lose. There is no finish line. We have to keep in front of the other fellow the whole time. The government does not seem to believe that.

The port of Melbourne used to be placed 20th out of 40 on the score of productivity and performance. It has now slipped to 34th place. In the areas of manning achievements, turnover, movement of freight and so forth our ports still compare very poorly with ports in New Zealand, Europe, the United Kingdom and the Asia-Pacific region. Once again we find on examination that the government's unblushing claims of wondrous economic miracles are completely false.

I turn to some of the more specific provisions of the bill. Unless our amendments are successful, we intend to vote against this bill because, despite what the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) has said, it does endorse the maintenance of a register of waterfront employees. Stripped of all the verbiage, the maintenance of a register of waterfront employees is a reaching back to the dark ages of Australia's waterfront. It is redolent of the days when guaranteed employment was regarded as a right available only to the section of the Australian work force on the waterfront. There is no need to have a register of employees. We are told we must have this register in order to fulfil our obligations under an ILO convention. Are we to be increasingly governed by the illicit use of the international conventions to which Australia has become a party to justify the disturbance of domestic law?

This government boasts about the need for Australian independence. This government says we should become a republic because our present constitutional arrangements are an affront to full-blooded Australian nationalism. Yet in the 11 years that Labor has been in government, it has done more to pawn Australian independence than any government since Federation. It has done so in two ways. This government has put us in hock to the bankers of the world. When it came to power Australia's net foreign debt was $23 billion; it is now almost $200 billion—$23 billion to almost $200 billion while Mandrake from Blaxland has presided over the Australian economy and has given us all these wonderful reforms. We heard it all last night on television—how he was going to reach back and pick up people. He reached out and put us into debt to the rest of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the honourable member for Watson is paying attention to what I am saying. In 11 years the Prime Minister has taken Australia's overseas debt from $23 billion to almost $200 billion; he really has had to have been at it 24 hours a day. I do not think he was being paid any shift penalties, even although he was at it 24 hours a day, seven days a week for 11 years. Except for a very short period, he was either Treasurer or Prime Minister for all of that 11 years. Do we ever hear about what he has done to the level of overseas debt? No, never. We hear about all these fancy schemes to cure the problem that he created. Who created the chronically high levels of long-term unemployed in this country? He did—nobody else. This country has never had a pile of long-term unemployed such as that which has been generated over the last few years. The Prime Minister cannot blame the Fraser government for that. Indeed, some of the inefficiencies in the stevedoring industry—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! I am reluctant to interrupt. Would the two members on my right mind holding their conversation somewhere else. I am finding it difficult to follow proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were commenting on the honourable member's wonderful speech.
—I think you had better cease to comment so close to the chair, if you would not mind.

—In that 11-year period, this man's two great achievements—he is responsible more than anybody else—have been to hand over our financial independence to the bankers of the world and to progressively, in recent years, hand over our constitutional independence to the bureaucrats of the world. That is not a bad achievement for somebody who wants to be remembered as a passionate Australian nationalist—not a bad achievement at all. He has done more to throw away that national independence than any of his predecessors. We have the constant use of ILO conventions in a way that is not legally necessary, in a way that is not industrially required, and in a way that is absolutely unjustified other than to find a constitutional shortcut to altering the domestic balance of Australian law between state governments and federal governments.

PARA.TAB: In talking about this industrial relations measure I take the opportunity to record once again the opposition's contempt for this government and particularly for this Prime Minister who wraps himself in the apparel of national independence and national pride yet, in the same breath, on two critical fronts—our foreign debt and the use of international conventions—he has done more to pawn Australia's independence than any other Prime Ministers, Labor or Liberal. He talks about Ben Chifley and his 1945 white paper. I think Ben Chifley would spin in his grave at the thought that a Labor Prime Minister would hand this country's affairs over so comprehensively to foreigners, as the current Prime Minister has done.

When the chips are down, if we owe the rest of the world $200,000 million, we do not have much independence. We can have all the fancy speeches imaginable on Australia Day, but if we owe the rest of the world $200,000 million, we are not an independent, proud, nationalistically distinct political entity. I think it is one of the great frauds of the current Prime Minister of this country.

The opposition's principal objection to this measure is that it entrenches the concept of a register of waterfront employment. The minister indicated—I will return to this when we consider the bill in detail—in his second reading speech that he will tack something onto the end of clause 20 of the bill to try, in a tenuous way, to explain away the fact that he misled the parliament when he answered an interjection, not a question, from me. I am glad that he pays attention to what I say on these matters. He made it clear that the bill would not oblige the establishment of a register.

As I understand it—I am quite sure that the minister will be only too ready to correct me if my understanding is wrong—the minister intends to amend clause 20 of the bill. That clause states that the committee must—there is no choice; it must do it—establish a register containing the names of stevedoring employees. His amendment states that if the committee is satisfied that an employer of stevedoring employees is keeping the prescribed records in relation to those employees, the committee is not required to include the names of those employees on the register. In other words, there will still be a register, and a capacity for the committee to require the inclusion of all the names on the register.

The minister is saying that, because the committee can exercise a discretion and say, `Since you are being very good boys and keeping records, we will not ask you to put those names on the register,' in some way there is nothing compulsory about it. It is still very compulsory and it is not very optional.

We simply ask: why have a register at all? The only reason there will be a register is that the Maritime Union of Australia wants a register. Jenny George, Bill Kelty and Martin Ferguson wanted the Industrial Relations Act, so they got it. This is classic organ-grinder and monkey legislation. The organ-grinder is the Maritime Union of Australia, and the monkey is the Minister for Industrial Relations.

The Prime Minister spent $6.5 billion of Australian taxpayers' money yesterday. Today, the industrial relations minister is worsening the industrial relations circumstances of a key industry in Australia. He is contributing to the low productivity of the Australian economy.

While we are talking about this, we are reminded again of the unblushing claims of the Prime Minister that his brilliant micro- and macro-economic reforms have revolutionised and transformed the Australian economy. We are told about how more productive it has become.

The problem is that, a few weeks ago, the OECD looked at the Australian economy. The Prime Minister chose to dismiss the OECD's report as being Eurocentric, irrespective of the justification for that claim. He said it was looking at the Australian economy through European eyes. The fact that the draft report on the Australian economy had been run past the federal Treasury has either escaped his recollection or he has simply chosen to ignore it.

The real reason why the Prime Minister was niggled by that report and why he dismissed it as Eurocentric is the fact that the report made the rather interesting and damaging statement that Australia's productivity performance between 1987 and 1992 was only 60 per cent of the OECD average. In other words, our productivity went up by only 60 per cent of the OECD average. Of all the exams that the economic managers of nations must sit, none is more important and crucial than the exam paper entitled `Productivity', because productivity is a measure of how intelligently a nation uses its resources.

There was some very fine rhetoric in the Prime Minister's job statement yesterday about what a tragic waste of a valuable resource—indeed, our nation's most priceless resource; that is, the talent of our people—it is to have so many people unemployed. I could not help agreeing 100 per cent with the Prime Minister's statement.

There are human, financial and natural resources. We as a nation do not use them very efficiently or intelligently. Despite all the rhetoric, fine words and exaggerated claims, the brutal fact is that between 1987 and 1992, when the honourable member for Blaxland was for four of those five years the Treasurer of Australia and for six months of the other year Prime Minister of Australia, the most accurate measure of how efficiently we used our resources of people, minerals, produce of the earth and nature and our financial resources said that our achievement was only 60 per cent of the OECD average.

The OECD is not talking about Third World countries; it is talking about all the modern industrialised nations of the world, such as Japan, Germany, Britain and the other nations of western Europe. When Australia is put in league with all of them, we achieve 60 per cent of the OECD average.

We are not in front. There is all this talk. No wonder the Prime Minister said the report was Eurocentric. The Prime Minister is very good at that. If he finds an embarrassing fact, he tries to ridicule that fact with an insulting diversion. But a few people around are awake to it. When he was in Thailand, the Prime Minister tried to blow the report out of the water by saying it was Eurocentric and wrong. It is not wrong or Eurocentric; it just happens to be the truth.

I know that the truth is uncomfortable. When a country's productivity performance is 60 per cent of the OECD average and the government that has been running the place for 11 years is running out of a capacity to credibly blame the foreigners and former governments, I suppose its Prime Minister has to resort to cheap rhetoric and remarks in foreign countries. That is what the Prime Minister did.

What annoys me and the opposition about this bill and so many aspects of the government's approach to industrial relations is that the government's policies do nothing to lift the productivity of this country. At the end of the day, we will sink or swim according to our productivity. We will never have a big enough economy to hold our own on a head to head basis with the large economic groupings of the world. We can only do well if we perform on the productivity front.

The Prime Minister talks every day about the need for us to move into the Asia-Pacific region. He is right. We have been doing that since 1957 when John McEwen, the Deputy Prime Minister in a coalition government, trailblazed into Asia by signing the Japan-Australia free trade agreement. I say in passing that it would have taken more political courage to sign a Japan-Australia free trade agreement in 1957 than it would in 1994 to talk about the importance of Australia's association with Asia.

I do not think anybody in this House should ever forget the fact that we started the move into the Asia-Pacific region. John McEwen deserves more credit for trailblazing into the Asia-Pacific region than any postwar politician in this country. Let that not be forgotten.

Let me also say in passing that I did not agree with every policy that John McEwen advocated. There are one or two areas where, if we had been sitting around a shadow cabinet table together, there may have been a marginal diversion. But, on that score, he showed characteristic Australian guts. He was opposed by the Labor Party.

In 1957, the Labor Party opposed that agreement, which was the first positive step. This hypocrite, who is now the Prime Minister of this country, is saying, `I opened up Australia's eyes to the importance of the Asia-Pacific region. I was the first person who discovered that it was very important to Australia's future.' Once again, he does it with unblushing fraud.

We are unhappy with this bill. We will vote against it unless it is amended. It fails to address the fundamental challenge of any intelligent system of workplace relations in this country, and that is productivity. What will this bill do to increase the productivity of the Australian waterfront? The answer is nothing. Will this bill potentially make that productivity less? The answer is yes. Will this legislation do anything to make our industrial relations system more flexible? The answer is no. Will this legislation placate the union organ grinders so far as this government is concerned? The answer is yes. This country is very different from what it was 20 or 30 years ago. Many of the changes that have occurred over that time have been good, but a lot of them have been bad. A lot of the things that we are told by this government that it has achieved, of course, it has not.

I have pointed out how poorly we have done on the productivity level. I have pointed out the essential fraudulence of many of the claims the government makes about achievement in so many areas. The waterfront remains a glaring example of just how out of date this country remains according to international best practice. We may be doing better now than we were doing 20 years ago, but in relative terms we are still a long way behind the rest of the world. If we are to have that super-duper international best practice that the Prime Minister tells us time and time again is so absolutely essential then we should not be passing legislation like this. We should never have passed the Industrial Relations Act. We should not be putting a bill through this parliament that will actually discourage the average small businessman from taking on more staff.

These will be my final words on this measure. This bill and the Industrial Relations Act represent, yet again, a very simple fact: for the last 11 years the industrial relations laws of this country have been drafted by people who have no understanding of how the average small business in Australia operates. They have no idea that the average small businessman is simultaneously the managing director, the sales manager, the personnel manager, the chief accountant and the tea lady all rolled into one. They have this vision that small business operators have a personnel department that can fill out all the forms, answer all the questionnaires and keep all the records of discussions with employees. They do not know the realities of trying to run a small business and the sorts of pressures that bear upon small businessmen. Until they do, they will never solve the unemployment problem of this country. The solution to that problem lies with a resurgent small business sector. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to support the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, which the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) just spoke to and to which the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) moved the motion for the second reading this morning. This legislation continues the process of industrial reform as illustrated by the new Industrial Relations Act, which also has been referred to earlier today and which took effect on 30 March this year.

PARA.TAB: In the field of waterfront reform, which this legislation is principally concerned with, I think it is fair to say that this government has shown a great deal of courage in its policy moves, despite the occasional outburst to the contrary by those opposite. The process of reform on the waterfront is continuing at a steady pace thanks to the government's commitment to deal with this area in a thoroughly comprehensive and far-sighted manner.

The purpose of this bill is to repeal redundant provisions dealing with waterfront disputes and the general levy payable by waterfront employers. The bill will also reduce the size of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee and provide for that body to cease to exist when its functions are completed. The majority of the amendments reflect changes in the nature of employment on the waterfront.

As most honourable members are no doubt aware, unfortunately it is true that the Australian waterfront has had an unhappy history of inefficient operations compared to the world's best ports. Reform of the waterfront has been proceeding since the Weber task force on shore-based shipping reported in 1986 and found that one of the main causes of inefficiency was low labour and equipment productivity rates. The task force was followed by a comprehensive Inter-State Commission report, which was released in 1989. The ISC recommended a three-year reform package to increase productivity, which centred on changes to the way in which people were employed in the stevedoring industry, reductions in the work force and improvements in management.

Following the signing of an in principle agreement between employers, waterside unions and the ACTU in September 1989, a three-year program was introduced to reform the industry. Prior to the introduction of the reform program, stevedoring had a lot of problems in the industrial area. Employment was industry based. Employers drew on a pool of workers who enjoyed virtually a lifetime guarantee of employment. As a result, there was no direct link between employers and employees, and conditions of employment were standardised across the industry. These arrangements arose out of the history of the waterfront and the unions' successful fight to move away from the pool of casual labour employment arrangements that had characterised the industry for many years.

The manner of employment changed during the reform program so that stevedoring companies directly employed their work force with the changed aim to increase competition among the stevedoring firms and create a greater affinity between the employer and the employee. As employers could now offer different conditions of employment, there was greater incentive for employers and employees to negotiate changes that could improve productivity and offer rewards to both the company and its employees. The change was implemented through 108 enterprise agreements established by this government.

Another central plank of the reform program was the reduction in the size of the stevedoring work force through the provision of attractive retirement-redundancy packages. In the period between the introduction of the reform package on 1 November 1989 and its end on 31 October 1992, the work force was reduced by 4,479 people who took retirement-redundancy packages and 840 by natural attrition. An additional 265 people were recruited into the industry. The net reduction of 5,054 left a work force of 3,818 and represented a reduction in the work force of 57 per cent—and this is quite substantial—which was over twice the reduction anticipated in the 1989 in principle agreement. The retirement-redundancy packages cost a total of $413 million, of which the Commonwealth contributed $165 million, the balance being met by levies on employers and their customers.

The reform program resulted in considerable change in the stevedoring industry. I will now list some claims of performance improvement. The number of containers handled per person per shift has increased by 130 per cent. Annual savings from the process are estimated to be $300 million. Stevedoring charges have fallen by 20 to 25 per cent between 1990-91 and 1992. The time needed to load and unload a ship with an average container load has fallen from 44 hours in 1989 to 27 hours in June 1992. For grain terminals, costs have fallen by approximately 50 per cent. Ship turnaround time has been reduced by approximately 45 per cent. The number of containers handled per crane hour has increased by 57 per cent. So there have been substantial changes on the waterfront, despite what some people may suggest.

An international comparison of waterfront productivity was conducted by the Bureau of Industry Economics, which released its report in March 1993. The BIE made a number of provisos concerning the comparisons. It noted the difficulties in obtaining identical data from a number of ports and the difference that economies of scale can produce. For example, productivity indicators are measured in terms of a TEU, the equivalent of a standard 20-foot container, which is the type most often used in Australian trade. However, a number of the larger world ports, such as Singapore, deal with a large percentage of 40-foot containers, which are rated as two TEUs. It does not take twice the time to deal with a 40-foot container that it takes for a 20-foot container. The BIE also noted that stevedoring charges are not the sole cost of a port and that port authority charges in Australia are significantly higher than the overseas average.

The BIE found that average labour productivity in Australian coal terminals is more than 50 per cent higher than the overseas average. Although there was difficulty in gaining valid data for a comparison of labour productivity in relation to container traffic, the available information showed Australian ports to be significantly below the best. The BIE also found that the average crane rate for Australian container terminals was 20.1 TEUs per hour compared with 25 for Singapore and 29 for Yokohama, that labour productivity and equipment utilisation in Australian coal terminals is approaching, or is at, world best practice, and that productivity in container terminals is in some cases approaching world best practice in similar sized overseas ports, but there is considerable scope for further improvement in many Australian container ports.

There is some evidence to suggest that the very good rate of reform of the waterfront over the last few years has slowed somewhat recently. A Prices Surveillance Authority report found recently that the reduction in charges to users of the waterfront seems to have levelled off. The report also said that any further gains in waterfront productivity were not likely to match the previous rapid gains. The PSA is also reported as saying that charges may increase as stevedoring companies seek to restore their profits.

Another concern that I am sure all members of this House can remember was the recent dispute involving Australian Stevedores and stevedoring unions concerning the plan to retrench 55 more employees. This dispute came about when a merger between various stevedoring companies formed Australian Stevedores last year. One result of that merger was that 317 positions for employees were declared surplus, and the company sought voluntary redundancies to achieve the reduction in the work force. Enterprise agreements were reached between the employer and the employees in eight ports, but agreement was not reached in Sydney, where there was disagreement on four points.

In February 1994 Australian Stevedores announced that it had not announced sufficient voluntary redundancies and that 55 employees would be retrenched. The union's response was a national stoppage of stevedoring workers. This dispute was temporarily resolved when the Industrial Relations Commission ordered the parties to negotiate and the 55 employees to be reinstated. Negotiations to finally settle the matter are continuing, and the company has announced that an additional 37 employees will be dismissed.

Clause 4 of this bill seeks to repeal division 9 of part VI of the act, which establishes port conciliators and coordinating committees. These bodies have become redundant with the introduction of enterprise agreements in the stevedoring industry.

The Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee Act 1977 provides for the establishment of a finance committee to administer funds raised through levies on the industry to meet obligations that arose as a result of the previous industry based employment. For example, it administered long service leave contributions that were met from the contributions of all employers as there was no direct link between the employer and the employee.

The committee has largely become irrelevant since the change to enterprise employment but still has functions in respect of funds borrowed to finance the industry contribution to the retirement/redundancy payments made as part of the reform program. The repayment of this amount is financed through a special levy on the industry. Clause 9 of this amendment bill seeks to amend section 5 of this act to reduce the membership of the committee from seven to four and to ensure the continuation of the tenure of the current chairperson of the committee.

Part III of the act, which provides for the committee to refund funds paid by employers where such obligations would have had to be met by the committee had the employer not met them, and part IV, which requires a register of waterside workers to be kept, will be repealed by clause 12. This clause also provides that if the committee holds funds that it is satisfied relate to an obligation that an employer will have to meet in the future the funds are to be paid to the employer. Proposed section 26A, which will be inserted into this act by clause 20, will require the committee to keep a register of stevedoring employees. The minister has foreshadowed a government amendment to clause 20.

Clause 23 of the amendment legislation will remove the requirement for the committee to lodge an annual report, and clause 24 will insert a sunset clause into this act. Proposed section 32 provides that, if the committee is satisfied that it has discharged its obligations and liabilities, it is to inform the minister of this and is to prepare a scheme for the distribution of any surplus funds it holds and inform the minister of the scheme. If the minister certifies that obligations and liabilities have been met and any surplus funds have been distributed in a manner approved by the minister, and if a copy of such certification is published in the Gazette, this act will cease to have effect.

The Stevedoring Industry Levy Act must be amended by replacing references to `waterside workers' with references to `stevedoring employees' to reflect the current changes. Clause 27 will repeal section 5 of this act, which sets the rate of the general levy payable in respect of waterside workers. The effect of the amendment is to remove the general levy, which reflects the move to enterprise based employment. Proposed section 13 of this act, which will be inserted by clause 31, provides that this act will cease to have effect if the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee Act ceases to have effect.

Finally, the Stevedoring Industry Levy Collection Act must be amended to insert a definition of `stevedoring employee' to replace the term `waterside worker', as I have already noted in respect of the levy act. The amendment clarifies the groups of employees who are not covered by the levy but also provides that, if a levy were payable in respect of an employee immediately before the commencement of this amendment, the levy will continue to be payable in respect of that employee. The amendment legislation seeks to insert this definition by clause 41, and this means that this act will cease to have effect if the Stevedoring Finance Committee Act ceases to have effect.

Most honourable members would agree that, due to the changed circumstances on the waterfront, these proposed amendments are necessary to continue the process of reform in the stevedoring industry and hopefully to avoid a repeat of the events earlier this year. With regard to the general levy payable by waterfront employers, the amendment legislation will also allow the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee to carry on its role and to carry out its inherited obligations more completely.

These amendments are a continuation of this government's commitment to labour market reforms as indicated in yesterday's white paper tabled in this place by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I believe this government has an extremely good record in the industrial relations area. It always disappoints me to see the opposition continually oppose anything that this government has put forward in the industrial relations area. It is interesting that earlier the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was comparing Australia with America. He has probably had the opportunity to visit the US. I suggest that a lot of living conditions in the US are nowhere near ours in Australia. We have an obligation to the Australian people. The Prime Minister says we have to bring the people along with us, and he disclosed that in a very compassionate and caring manner. It is something that we on this side of the parliament really feel for.

Yesterday's white paper outlined provisions to help long-term unemployed people and youth unemployed. They are very important issues that we on this side of the parliament have a very strong commitment to. Amendments to acts such as those before us today are part of the ongoing process where things have to be reformed for us to keep moving. We cannot live in the past; we cannot live back in McEwen's days. We have to keep moving along, to move with the modern world and to look at international best practice.

The reforms on the waterfront that we have been talking about are very important to Australia. I know they take time to achieve but in the end I believe that, by the continuing perseverance by the government and certainly by the current Minister for Industrial Relations in a lot of the reform areas, we will achieve a lot of best practice and that is going to help Australians dramatically.

When we talk about Australian industry, there is no doubt that the small business sector is a very vital employer in our community, and it certainly does need every assistance it can get. The honourable member for Bennelong mentioned international bankers and the little tricks they get up to but, as I have said before, nothing is worse than when even our own local bankers in Australia do not always pick up the problems that small business have. Small businesses need a lot of help from their bankers.

The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) agrees with me on this, because he has followed me on this issue once before. It is right. We need to help small business as much as we can. It is not just governments that can do it. It is important that we as a government help small business as much as we can, but it is also important that bankers, who through deregulation have been given wonderful opportunities under this government—they have been given all the opportunities they wanted but, in my view, have not delivered—need to be encouraged as often as possible by people in this place to help small business as much as they can.

If we are going to achieve a lot of the goals that were put forward in the white paper released yesterday, we will have to make sure that small business picks up a lot of the initiatives contained in it. It is important for every one of us in this place to study what is in the white paper. We need to encourage those small businesses—and the larger businesses, as they are probably better placed to assist many of the long-term unemployed—in our local areas to pick up these initiatives.

There has been cooperation between the government and the ACTU with respect to some of the initiatives in the white paper, and obviously that cooperation will continue. There is a reference in the white paper to in-principle agreements on the training wage. That was reviewed by a high level ACTU negotiating committee, which will recommend to the ACTU executive the adoption of this initiative. Obviously, more discussions will need to take place between the relevant ministers and the ACTU.

We have received this support from the trade union movement to help people in Australia to gain employment after some rather difficult times, which I am sure would be a lot worse if those opposite were in government. When we go through tough times, as Australia and most other countries in the world do, we need to show some compassion to the people who need help the most. The industrial relations process ensures that people are looked after. The worse thing we can do to people when things are tough is to kick them when they are down. Unfortunately, that is the attitude the opposition continues to have to these matters.

If those opposite had half the chance, they would make people work for nothing. Thank God they have not had half the chance to do that in recent times. The cooperation between this government and the trade union movement has meant that we have been able to maintain reasonable wage levels in those tough times to ensure that members of the Australian work force and their families have been able to maintain some sort of dignity. The changes proposed in the white paper, which involve continuing cooperation between the government and the trade union movement, can only continue to help members of the Australian work force and their families to maintain a decent lifestyle. The amendments before the House today deserve the support of this House and the other place. I look forward to their being passed in this place in due course.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—I call the honourable member for Hume.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Now we'll hear a speech with some substance.

—I also thank my colleague the honourable member for Gippsland for his encouragement. I was very interested to hear the comments of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), who spoke about some of the great changes that have taken place on the Australian waterfront. I was pleased to hear him talk about the improvements and I was pleased to hear him make comparisons with some of the other trading ports around the world. I was also pleased to hear him say that there is room for to us make further improvements here in Australia through our ports.
—That is an understatement.

—As the honourable member for Gippsland has pointed out, that is an understatement. Unfortunately, the very bill that the honourable member for Oxley is supporting here today, the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill, goes precisely in the opposite direction of achieving further improvements in productivity through our Australian waterfront. This bill will take Australia back to the period before waterfront reform started in 1989.
—Rubbish!

—It is not rubbish. The honourable member for Throsby should be ashamed of himself. Anybody who has an intimate view of what has gone on in the waterfront over the last few years will know that one of the principles of waterfront reform is to establish enterprise employment through enterprise agreements. What does this legislation, which the government hopes will be passed today, do? It goes to the very heart of eroding the benefits of enterprise agreements, enterprise employment. How does it do that? It does it through the establishment of a register of employees of stevedores. That is putting us back in the position we were in prior to 1989 when everybody in the waterfront was employed through a pool—not through individual enterprises—and the union had full control over all of those people who worked on the waterfront.

PARA.TAB: I went down to the waterfront during that period and I have been again since. If I had asked a wharfie, `Who do you work for, brother?' he would have said, `The Waterside Workers Federation, of course.' He would not have said that he worked for Conaust, National Terminals (Australia) Ltd, Strang Patrick, as it was then, or whatever other stevedores existed in those days that no longer exist today. But if I went to the waterfront today and asked a wharfie, `Whom do you work for?' he would say, `Conaust' or `Australian Stevedores'. They are the only two left, due to all the government's reforms.

This legislation will go back to the period when everybody was on a register. There will be port pools. People who are no longer required for services can be paid through those port pools, establishing what we had prior to 1989. So, whilst the honourable member for Oxley put forward some very good points in his speech, which was well read—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well written by the department.

—Perhaps somebody in the advisers box could remember every word of it. This legislation will take us back to the situation of port pools and the establishment of a register. This is typical of what has happened on the waterfront for a long time throughout Australia's history. We have seen the Australian people pay out $430 million over the period of the waterfront reform process to entice wharfies to retire ahead of schedule through redundancy payments.

PARA.TAB: There were 4,500 wharfies who retired. On average $100,000 was given to every retiring wharfie over and above their superannuation, their sick leave and long service leave payments, et cetera. Every cent of that $430 million is being paid for by Australians, either through their taxes or through higher charges on the goods that they consume through the establishment of this levy which will pay for the remaining amounts over and above the taxpayer's contribution.

That amount of money was paid to get the unions to agree to change. As part of the process, those who did not take the redundancy package and kept their jobs as wharfies received average wage increases of 23 per cent. According to the rhetoric of some in this place, the average wharfie is a hard bitten, hard done by soul. But the average wharfie is earning several times more than the average Australian for working probably only 60 per cent as hard as the average Australian.

There are people in Port Botany and in the home state of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), who is at the table, who are working on the waterfront and who have a take home pay of about $92,000 to $94,000 a year. They do not work any harder than anybody else in society, and yet they are earning several times more than most other people in our society. So these people are not hard done by. Those who stayed received a 23 per cent pay rise and those who retired received a $430 million redundancy package which was paid for by everybody else.

Now we see the process of clawing back all the things that were negotiated during that process which cost this country so much. We are seeing through this legislation the power of the wharfies that was taken away during the period of waterfront reform slowly re-established. This is what this register is all about. We are masking the reason why we need a register by saying, `We must have this register because we have to conform with ILO convention 137'—I think that is right. Who is the ILO? It is the International Labour Organisation. Why should we take any notice of the International Labour Organisation?

For example, when the Country Women of the World has an international conference and carries resolutions, why do we not kowtow to those? Why do we not stand here in this House and say, `The Country Women of the World have made a recommendation that we do these various things; therefore, we will.' It is nonsense. The ILO's conventions have no more weight in this place than a convention of Country Women of the World has. We should not be kowtowing to the ILO or any other organisation, other than those based here in Australia, to govern our own country.

This government is masking its attempt to re-establish the power of the trade union movement on the waterfront through the need to keep in step with ILO convention 137. It does not fool most people, but unfortunately it seems to have fooled people on the government side, which of course is a fairly common event these days.

The whole purpose of what we have achieved on the waterfront is to try to make Australia's waterfront more internationally competitive. I heard the honourable member for Oxley and I no doubt will hear from the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) about how we have gone so far towards achieving this. Even though we have spent all this money, $430 million, and provided wharfies with a 23 per cent pay rise, and treated them like royalty, productivity levels on the Australian waterfront have declined over recent time. During the waterfront reform process, there is no doubt that crane loading rates improved by up to 50 per cent—no doubt about that at all. But it is interesting to note that in the latter portion of last year crane loading rates for TEUs per hour at Sydney went from 19.95 down to 13.8. The same thing occurred in Melbourne where they went from 26.75 TEUs per hour down to 18.8 TEUs per hour. What we see there is effectively a reduction in crane loading rates at two of our major ports, Sydney and Melbourne, of around 50 per cent. What does that mean? The wharfies got the $430 million and the 23 per cent increase in pay rates, and the productivity gains that were achieved in the process of forking out all of that have now been eroded. As a result, Australia really has not got that far down the track towards being internationally competitive.

It is interesting to note some TEU rates or crane loading rates for containers in other countries. If we look at Felixstowe for the same period as I just compared Sydney and Melbourne to, it had crane loading rates of 35.36 TEUs per hour. Auckland, New Zealand, had TEU crane loading rates of 30 per hour, compared with Sydney which had 13.8 and Melbourne which had 18.8. So we have not achieved one of the goals set through waterfront reform of making ourselves internationally competitive. It is fair enough to say that loading a container in Sydney is 2 1/2 times more expensive than loading exactly the same container in New Zealand. That is the sort of competition we are up against and that is the sort of failure that we have had despite the fact that we have forked out all of that money, provided the wharfies that remain with a substantial increase in their pay rates and given them, I think, a pretty fair deal.

The government, by masquerading it as a requirement to meet ILO convention 137, is doing this country a great disservice because there is no doubt at all that the net result of this will be, as the legislation says, the re-establishment of a register of waterside employees. What do we need a register for? We have enterprise employment now. We need the register so that the union knows who is on the waterfront, whom they are working for, for how much, for how long and all those sorts of things. It is a process of re-establishing what was there before 1989.

If the stevedore employers are doing what they are required to do by law, then they already keep a list of their own employees, which is privy to them but which can be provided to people from the industrial relations department, the tax man or whoever else requires it. So we do not need an additional list set up through this legislation. Indeed, why do we need the list? The list is simply there for the benefit of the Maritime Union of Australia. It wants to reintroduce a list because it wants to re-establish the job for life syndrome on the waterfront. That has been a fact of life on the waterfront for quite a long time now, but the threat has been that through the waterfront reform process that was going to be traded off. We saw in February of this year Australian stevedores go through a very costly and painful strike.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose fault was that?

—It does not matter whose fault it was. The real reason for having the strike was to reinforce the trade union's belief that the employer does not have the right to compulsorily retire or sack employees on the waterfront—back to the same old situation we had before. The reason why the MUA took on that dispute, and the reason why this legislation is going through the House today, is to reinstate the job for life for wharfies on Australia's waterfront.
—A payback.

—It is a payback. It is a payback by this government for the support that it got from the trade union movement during the last election. I note the minister has said that he is prepared to move an amendment which says that, if the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee feels it necessary, then it may reintroduce the register. If it feels the register is not necessary, it may not. Now that seems like quite a compromise.

PARA.TAB: At first blush it probably is. But when we go to the structure of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee that the minister is proposing it is quite possible that the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee will be completely dominated by wharfies, members of the Maritime Union of Australia. From memory, the chairman of it is appointed by the minister and there are two other people on it—an appointee of the Maritime Union of Australia and an employer of stevedores. People will say that is all right, that means there is one from the unions and one from the employers. But that does not necessarily follow. If, for example, a representative of the Federated Stevedores in Darwin happens to be appointed to the committee we end up with a member of the trade union, the Maritime Union of Australia, because Federated Stevedores is indeed a stevedoring business which is owned by the local branch of what was the Waterside Workers Federation in Darwin. So it is quite possible if we go down that route to end up with a committee fully dominated by members of the Maritime Union of Australia, the wharfies.

By making this compromise through this amendment that the minister has indicated that he will put forward, we could still end up, and indeed I would suggest we will most likely end up, with the reintroduction of a register. If we have the reintroduction of a register, it will take away all of the benefits that we have achieved on the Australian waterfront. It causes me a great deal of alarm and distress to see this legislation being put forward. I know it causes stevedore employers around Australia the same sort of distress. They are totally opposed, to a man, to this legislation because from their point of view there is no need for it; and from their point of view it leads to the reintroduction of the old habits and the old ways that this country fought so long against and paid a very high price to get rid of.

We propose that this bill be opposed. The coalition will not support it because we do not want to see the re-establishment of a register. Indeed, I am sure most Australians would approve of that view. We also oppose it because we do not like the way the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee is being set up. We do not like it because we think, as do those who have been involved with the waterfront for quite some time now, that there is no purpose in the future for the existence of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee. The whole process of waterfront reform was going to end with the axing of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee because there was going to be no need for its existence. The sole purpose of the existence of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee is to collect a levy to pay for the redundancies that have been forked out to retiring wharfies over the last few years. Once those redundancies have been paid for, there is no further purpose for the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee; therefore, its future is limited.

This legislation gives the future of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee a great deal more life. It means that it will not close down and it will continue on for goodness knows how long. That is, once again, against the principle of waterfront reform which was undertaken over the period from 1989 to 1992. Indeed, it goes against correspondence that this Minister for Industrial Relations sent to the employers of waterfront labour when he gave a commitment that in the future there would be an axing of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee. Senator Collins, the former minister, indicated the same thing and, indeed, the current Minister for Industrial Relations, I think it was, gave a commitment that there would not be the reintroduction of a register.

All of these things go against the reform process and against commitments made by the current minister and the former Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins. It is for those reasons that we have a concern about it and it is for those reasons that we will oppose the amendments. It is the rightful duty of this opposition to stand up for what it believes to be right and to stand up to people who have, over a long period, done enormous harm to Australia's export earning capacity, done enormous harm to the job creation potential of businesses right throughout Australia.

The trade union on the waterfront, now the Maritime Union of Australia, has really had the best of all worlds. Its members have had that $430 million and their 23 per cent pay rise. They have taken back the productivity gains they gave and now want to reinstate the job for life and full control of everybody who works on the waterfront. These people can only be described as selfish and greedy. We have seen through the 1980s some very selfish and greedy entrepreneurs make a poultice for themselves at the expense of others in this country. Those people are rightly vilified around this country for the greed they displayed and the costs they imposed on other people. If it is right to vilify those people, then it is right to vilify the Maritime Union of Australia which has taken so much from this country and given so little and now wants more than everybody else is entitled to and it is entitled to.

We oppose this bill. Indeed, I hope that through the processes in the Senate we will see this bill knocked out. I hope that we will see commonsense and decency prevail and the commitments that this government gave to the employers of waterfront labour, from 1989 right up to the last few months, fulfilled, as they were promised by various government ministers during that period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard it all before and we have heard it again today. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) got up on their trade union bashing exercise. Looking at the list of speakers, I see that we are to hear in this debate on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill from the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile). I have not heard the honourable member for Lyne speak on the waterfront previously, but I have most certainly heard the other two do so, and I could write their speeches now.

PARA.TAB: The waterfront today is in for the big bash from the opposition. To hear the opposition speak, as represented so far by the honourable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for Hume, one would think that the only people who occupy the waterfront were the waterside workers and that absolutely nothing has happened over the last few years.

I was on the committee which looked at the report Warehouse to wharf. That committee found that the reforms and restructuring on the waterfront had all been carried out by the Waterside Workers Federation. But the waterfront is a mishmash; there is a whole range of players on the waterfront. To listen to the crowd opposite—we heard the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), say some time ago that he would put troops on the waterfront—one would think that, if they took the wharfies out of the waterfront, lined them up against the wall and shot them, all would be peace, sweetness, light and understanding on the waterfront. If we are to start throwing blame around about what is happening on the waterfront, we should take a look at a few of the actors, the people, on the waterfront. The members of that committee spent over a year going around the various waterfronts in Australia. We found that there was a whole mishmash of players and conditions and that, on the whole, it was not the waterside workers at fault at all.

How many more times am I going to stand in this place and listen to what can be achieved at Felixstowe in the United Kingdom? I have been to Felixstowe; I was there last year. I kept hearing from the honourable member for Hume how wonderful it was. I went down there and had a look at Felixstowe, as I have had a look at the waterfront in Singapore. Sure, quite a lot has been achieved there, but look at the equipment they have. All one can see on the skyline at Felixstowe are cranes. We say, `Give us the equipment that other people have on the wharves in Singapore, Rotterdam, Felixstowe and various other ports of the world, and we will give you the same result.'

The honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) quoted from a study which was produced in March of this year. That study showed that the productivity of coal handling facilities in Australia was up to 50 times better than it was in comparable situations overseas. Why is that? It is because they have this new equipment. We cannot get world best practice if we have to work with clapped out equipment. We have been trying to get a heavy crane down at Port Kembla for the last 10 years, but it has not been provided—and at the moment it is not being provided through the New South Wales government.

It is too easy to blame the waterside workers for every ill on the Australian waterfront. It is only disguising some of the omissions of the people whom the opposition purports to represent. Take unloading on the waterfront with the three days which are allowed: people are not moving the stuff off the waterfront in the required time. Take loading: sending all the cargo at the very last minute instead of having it spaced conveniently over time. Take the mishmash of working hours. Take the tardy attitude of many people towards the use of electronic transfers. Take the whole stream, the whole host, of documentation: thousands and thousands of documents. Surely those opposite are not blaming the waterside workers for all these things. If we start to hurl blame around, let us hurl it perhaps a little wider and at where it should be most directed.

We have had raised here the old bogy of Australia signing an international convention—ILO No. 137. Why are those opposite so frightened of Australia signing international agreements? I really cannot understand it at all. In one breath, they talk about best practice or world best practice. But here is a convention that assumes we are up with the world, and the first thing they do is oppose it. In one breath, they speak for one thing and in the next they oppose it. I find it very hard to understand really what they are on about.

The honourable member for Hume made much of the dispute which occurred on the waterfront earlier this year when 55 workers were sacked. It was very interesting that he did not bother explaining how that was brought about by a try-on by the bosses which they have done before. He did not bother quoting the judgment which was handed down by Deputy President Williams. That judgment, in part, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Industrial relations at all levels involves people and people have an absolute right to be treated as human beings.
They were not being treated as human beings. It further states:

In the current industrial climate there is little that can be more dehumanising and demoralising than losing one's job. The effects are well documented. Almost as demoralising is to be paid not to work particularly in a situation where there is, at least on the face of it, an opportunity to do so.
That is true. There was the opportunity to do so, and that was what the judgment said. Indeed, there are still negotiations going on about that at this very moment.

PARA.TAB: I am quite pleased to speak on this important legislation, representing as I do the port of Kembla. The honourable member for Hume and I have been in this parliament for roughly the same amount of time. We tend to follow each other in speeches. Sometimes I go first, sometimes he goes first and we always speak about maritime matters and the waterfront. As I always say jokingly, I can give his speech and he quotes from my speech before I deliver it. We more or less know what we are going to say.

I actually know the honourable member for Hume quite well as we used to represent adjoining electorates, and I was quite amazed when he said today that he has visited the waterfront. From the speeches he has made here one would not believe that that honourable gentleman had ever put his foot on the waterfront. I do not know what waterfront he visited or how recently it was. He did say it was some time ago—

TALK.START.PARA: —Darling Harbour.
—Yes. He comes in here and makes these wonderful speeches and I always interject on him—
—Highly relevant, they are.

—You will have your chance next, comrade. I always throw out the invitation to him to come down to Port Kembla and repeat the speeches he makes here in this parliament to the waterside workers at Port Kembla. In the 10 years that we have both been here, he has not taken up that invitation. If he really does believe in what he says about the waterfront, why does he not come onto the waterfront?

PARA.TAB: He should come onto the waterfront down at Kembla. We will give him a wonderful day. I will even take him out to lunch. He can come and tell the waterside workers at Port Kembla, as he said here today, that they are selfish and greedy. It is interesting to note someone who represents the farmers of Australia talking about waterside workers being selfish and greedy.

The honourable member for Hume has said that waterside workers are taking home $90,000 a year. I challenge him to produce the pay slips of the waterside workers who are earning $90,000 a year. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who is at the table, looks around. We want genuine ones; we do not want any shonky ones. We want current, up-to-date pay slips. We want the pay slips which prove that they are earning $90,000 a year produced. I think they will be very hard to find.

As others have said, the purpose of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill is to repeal redundant provisions dealing with waterfront disputes and the general levy payable by waterfront employees. The bill will also reduce the size of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee and provides that that committee be abolished after its job is done.

The majority of the amendments reflect changes in the nature of employment on the waterfront. I think the opposition has not understood the changes in the nature of employment on the waterfront. I would suggest that no industry in Australia has responded to the challenge of reform and restructuring like the stevedoring industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Try the motor vehicle industry.

—As I said before the honourable member for La Trobe came into the chamber, I spent over a year going around every waterfront in Australia with the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) on the transport, communications and infrastructure committee and we produced the report entitled Warehouse to wharf. We actually went and talked to the whole mosaic of players on the waterfront. Even at that time, two or three years ago, members of the committee from both sides of the parliament were amazed at the changes and how the Maritime Union, or the Waterside Workers Federation as it was then, had accepted the challenge of restructuring and how it had in fact restructured. One would think from listening to the two speeches that have been delivered already by members of the opposition—I suggest there are some yet to come from the other side—that absolutely nothing had changed or that nothing had been achieved there.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that no player in the industry has been more prepared to take on the challenge of restructuring and reform than have the unions on the waterfront in Australia, yet the only thing we ever hear from those opposite when dealing with the waterfront is totally negative. It is as if nothing had been achieved. There have been achievements, there have been reforms and there has been great restructuring. In many cases it has been the waterfront unions that have led the way with reform and restructuring in Australia. Interestingly, not only on the waterfront but also in the other section of the Maritime Union, the former Seamen's Union, there has been tremendous change and restructuring there.

Those opposite really should look around for another simple throwaway theory on how they would reform the waterfront because their current policy, one of the few they have, is based on getting rid of the waterfront workers. They believe that then all would be well. As I said before, the waterfront is not a single entity. It is a composite of many parts. The waterfront worker is only one part of what makes up the waterfront industry.

Some claim that the Australian waterfront has had a history of inefficiency and delays compared with the world's best port. It is very difficult to compare the various ports. As I have said before, we need the equipment to put in our ports. If we are going to talk about world best practice and world best performance, we also have to have world best equipment, equipment that can give us that performance. Give us the cranes that they have at Felixstowe or the cranes they have at Singapore and we will give the results, but we cannot do it without the equipment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Auckland?

—Auckland is a good example. I was over in Auckland two years ago and went up to that port at the centre of the north island of New Zealand where one person was loading logs. It is one of the most dangerous occupations in Australia. When I was being told how wonderful it was, I asked, `What about safety? It would seem to me that loading logs is a very dangerous job.' I was told, `You have to understand, Colin, that having only one worker here is even safer because we have stopped the possibility of having accidents. The more workers you have on the site, the more likely you are to have accidents. If people went down the hole and went to sleep we might drop the logs on them, so that is why we have only one person with a front-end loader going around picking up these logs.' I would suggest that they have got quite a serious accident risk there. If people want to work to the conditions that exist in New Zealand today they are quite welcome to, but I do not particularly want to work with the industrial conditions New Zealand has, nor do the people that I represent.

PARA.TAB: The recently completed reform process had its origins in the Webber task force on shore based shipping, which handed down its report of 1986. This task force was, as many honourable members would be aware, followed by a comprehensive Interstate Commission report which was released in 1988. The Interstate Commission report recommended a three-year reform package to increase productivity focusing on changes in the way people were employed in the stevedoring industry, reductions in the work force and improvements in management, a significant area in the overall operation of the waterfront and an area that the opposition chooses to ignore. This followed the signing of an in-principle agreement by employees, waterside unions and the ACTU in September 1989 and a three-year program was introduced to reform and restructure this industry.

Before the reform program began, stevedoring employment was industry based. Employers drew from a pool of workers. The result was no direct link between the employer and the employee and the conditions of employment were standardised across the industry. Before the opposition starts making its usual rumblings, I point out that this arrangement reflected the history of the waterfront, an arrangement supported by coalition governments of many years standing. I listened to what the honourable member for Hume was saying and say that the opposition has supported the employment practices on the waterfront over many years.

The manner of employment changed under the reform program so that stevedoring companies directly employed their work force. The change had a goal of competition amongst stevedoring firms and a stronger link between the parties in the employment relationship. Stevedoring employers could now offer different conditions of employment and the incentive to negotiate changes which could improve productivity and offer both the companies and workers rewards. The change was implemented through 108 enterprise agreements. The agreements were approved and watched over by WIRA.

The reform process reduced the size of the waterfront work force. This was achieved by retirement and redundancy packages. I know that the amount that was paid galls honourable members opposite; nevertheless, these were negotiated between November 1989 and October 1992. The waterfront work force was reduced by over 4,000 people who took advantage of the retirement and redundancy packages but, because of the age process, there was also a recruitment to the waterfront.

As has been said, this legislation will reflect changes in the nature of employment on the waterfront. I am disappointed that the opposition has decided to oppose the legislation, but I am not surprised. As I said, sooner or later members of the opposition are going to realise that there are more than waterside workers on the waterfront; there is a whole range of players in that very important sector of the Australian industry; so they should stop bashing the waterside workers and have a look at some of the people they purport to support. If there are inefficiencies on the waterfront, for once they should do a bit of homework and trace the blame to where those inefficiencies really lie. They will find that, in most cases, it is not the waterside workers of Australia whose union has been massively reformed and restructured; it is many of those people that they stand up in this parliament and purport to support. I reject the opposition's amendment and support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we debate matters industrial, it is not unusual, I have found, for speakers on the government side of the House who follow to make reference to my remarks. In fact, it would be unusual if they did not. However, this is the first occasion on which I have risen to speak on an industrial relations bill before this House when the previous speaker, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), has already told the House what I am going to say. It was indeed most interesting to hear the honourable member for Throsby wax lyrical about how I am going to attack his precious waterside workers and their obviously excellent personal qualities. The honourable member may like to wait and see.

PARA.TAB: It is appropriate, I think, that this bill is before the House at this time, following as it does fairly immediately the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) yesterday afternoon on unemployment. The Prime Minister's statement was primarily about unemployment, not about employment. This Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill is also about unemployment; it is not about employment.

It is one more in a long series of bills brought into this place to fix up major legislation. We have had so many bills to add on to the poor Industrial Relations Legislation Act 1988 that the act hardly any longer represents what it was in 1988. In fact, it is very difficult for those who have to work in the bureaucracy with the way our employment bills operate in this country and with our legislation that determines the relationships between employers and employees. It is an indictment that the rules and regulations are so complex and occupy so many pages. Not only is a legal degree needed order to interpret them properly but probably also a whole host of clerks is needed to make sure that the proper procedures are followed.

The waterfront in Australia has a long, colourful history. I am not, despite the words of the honourable member for Throsby, going to deal at length with the old inefficiencies and enmities that have existed on the waterfront not only in this country but in other countries around the world for almost 100 years. That history is colourful and it is interesting. But I am not sure how relevant it is to the debate today except that this bill gives the government, and gives the industry itself, the opportunity to go back to the employment practices of the past, which were inappropriate, which were inefficient, which were costly and which placed a burden on all Australians in terms of the cost that they had to pay for imported goods.

The reform process, which other speakers have referred to, has been a long, slow process. Lasting several years and costing Australian industry and Australian taxpayers some $420 million, it was a process which had to be undertaken, but the mechanisms by which this government chose to undertake that process left a great deal to be desired.

The fact is that we have achieved some efficiencies in the waterfront with the so-called reform process. The fact is that there are fewer people now employed on the waterfront. The fact is that there are now two major companies in the five major ports which compete directly with each other. The fact is that we now have supposed enterprise agreements between the union and the employers. Those enterprise agreements designate the working conditions of the people who work in the industry at the ports and designate their pay rates and the totality of their terms and conditions of employment.

But those employees today are employed directly by companies. Before this process began, before the restructuring, we had for a very long time pooled employment. In fact, it was back in 1967 that we introduced permanent employment for registered waterside workers. Prior to 1967 all waterfront employment had been on a casual basis. Individuals were selected from a pool and put into their jobs on a particular day by the employers, but the pool itself was maintained and directed by the union. So if a person wanted a job on the waterfront then that person went not to an employer seeking to ask the employer to give him a job; he went to the union. He went to the union boss and did what was necessary to get the union boss to give him a job.
