That job meant that the person had the right to be registered and the right to stay in the casual pool, which meant that maybe he got work and maybe he did not.

The port pools were also at that time established for excess workers. They were for those who could not be used on the day, and those individuals either sat and waited for eventual employment or were told to go home and were still paid. The payment for that came via an industry levy which was administered by a separate organisation. In 1977 that organisation was abolished in five major ports and pool employees were allocated to employers. New levies were established at that time in order to pay for the pool employees whose labour could not be utilised on the day or on the shift.

It was in fact a jobs for life industry. If one wanted a job on the waterfront, one approached the union and one could be guaranteed employment forever. That was not unusual around the world, nor is it necessarily unusual in other industries in other countries. It had not been generally the practice in Australia that we had jobs for life, as it was not in the country which I came from many years ago, but there are countries in Europe where jobs for life have been part of the industrial scene for a very long time. Again, it is not part of the Australian experience. One of the problems with jobs for life is the fact that there is no real incentive to do better and to progress, to work harder or faster, because, no matter what one does or does not do today, one still is paid and one still has the job tomorrow. A job where performance is taken into account and one is paid appropriately tends to generate greater efficiencies for any organisation and for an economy than does a jobs for life type of scenario.

Following 1977, when the new levies were established and the pool employees were allocated to employers, we maintained that scenario until the most recent reform process. Now we have employees employed by the employers and no pool, because in effect the $420 million has been used to pay employees who have left the industry for their redundancy and has been used to help recompense others for disadvantage which they have suffered through the reform process.

This bill, firstly, recognises the role of enterprise agreements by repeal of division 9 of part 6 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988, which established port conciliators and coordinating committees. This bill finally recognises what has become fact, and that is enterprise agreements. We all know that enterprise agreements were not on the agenda of the Labor Party, were not part of any ALP platform. Enterprise agreements are finally seeing the light of day in our country because of the continued pressure put on government by my side of politics, by the opposition, to try to free up the labour market and to try to make more meaningful the employment contract between an employee and his employer rather than between some obscure body and the employer or, in the case of the waterfront, a pool of employees who owed their pool existence to the union bosses themselves. That part of the bill which recognises enterprise agreements is a positive part of the bill.

However, the bill then goes on and amends section 5, to reduce the size of the finance committee and to remove the general levy, but to allow special levies to be struck by the committee and to reintroduce an industry register of employees. It is these two issues with which the opposition takes exception today. The committee itself should have the right to determine its own members and the committee should certainly represent the interests and rights of the employers, who are those who provide the employment on the waterfront, as in fact they do in any other enterprise or any other industry. So we object to this reduction in the size of the committee and the inability of the industry to establish its members of that committee.

We vociferously object to the reintroduction of the industry register of employees. Pooling has been a fact of life on the waterfront for a very long time. But in fact the waterfront reform authority, the bills, the acts, and the $420 million that Australians have spent to change practice on the waterfront and to pay out excess people from their jobs for life, were to get rid of the concept of pooling and of the concept that employees were employed by someone who did not utilise their labour; notwithstanding that they were not paid by that organisation and that they were in fact paid by employers who paid levies in order to be sure that employees were paid whether they worked or not.

Any attempt to return to the pooling arrangements will break down the enterprise employment agreements which are in place and will break down the whole shift in emphasis that the government tells us it is so determined to push ahead with, and that is to re-establish relationships between those who do the work and those who pay for the work. Those relationships will become very important, both in a productivity sense and in a personal sense, so that those in work are able to feel that they contribute to a company's wellbeing—and to their own employment, if you will—by helping to make a company strong and competitive and by helping it to produce the products and services that that company was formed to produce and supply.

So the concept of jobs for life, which is inherent in pooling, must not return to the Australian waterfront; but this bill allows it to return. And the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) tells us he must do this because he is required to by International Labour Organisation convention No. 137, which Australia ratified in 1974. The date 1974 is particularly important, because I note that the requirement for all countries under conventions of the United Nations is that these ILO conventions may be dispensed with only once every 10 years, on the anniversary of signing and ratifying the particular convention.

I maintain that the need for Australia to ratify, to be part of, and to agree to, convention No. 137 has long passed. There are 20 other countries who signed that convention and are still on that register. The other subscribers are Afghanistan, Costa Rica, Cuba, Egypt, Finland, Greece, Guyana, Iraq, Italy, Kenya, Netherlands, Nicaragua, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Spain, Sweden, Tanzania and Uruguay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rwanda isn't there?

—No, it is not, actually. Also not there are the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Germany, Canada, Russia, Ukraine, Japan, Singapore, Korea, Taiwan, South Africa, Nigeria, Brazil, Argentina and Chile: a few of the major trading nations of the world. They are not on the register. They have not signed ILO convention No. 137, but we have. So the minister says that now we must have a register, because ILO Convention No. 137 says we must have a register. Why did we ratify convention No. 137? Amongst other things, the preamble to the convention says:

SPEECH.PARA: Considering that such changes, by speeding up freight movements, reducing the time spent by ships in ports and lowering transport costs, may benefit the economy of the country concerned as a whole and contribute to the raising of the standard of living, and—
that is because of roll-on, roll-off techniques with the introduction of containers to international shipping—
Considering that dock workers—
wait for it—

should share in the benefit secured by the introduction of new methods of cargo handling and that, accordingly, action for the lasting improvement of their situation, by such means as regularisation of employment and stabilisation of income, and other measures relating to their conditions of work and life, as well as to safety and health aspects of dock work, should be planned and taken concurrently with the planning and introduction of new methods—

And it goes on and on. Evidently, those are the reasons why Australia deemed that we should sign this convention. PARA.TAB: When the waterfront reform process took place, we transferred any obligation towards those pooled employees, firstly, by redundancy payments which were exceedingly overgenerous and which were accepted voluntarily by those in the jobs. As for the removal of some of the other rorts and practices, compensation of the remaining employees took place by way of very generous increases in hourly rates and further improvements in conditions of employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes before other matters commence, I will start my contribution. I have been listening to the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott) and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). As the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) said, they have forgotten nothing and they have learnt nothing. What we hear from them are the same old attitudes, the same old catchcries, the same old slogans of attack. All the problems on the waterfront are problems for people who work on the waterfront. In the ideal world, I suppose the honourable member for La Trobe would probably abolish people altogether on the waterfront.

PARA.TAB: If there were no people on the waterfront, most of the problems would still remain. The honourable member for La Trobe carried on about ILO convention 137. The legislation provides for the register to be maintained. If the honourable member looks closely at the legislation, he will find that the amendment that will be moved later in this debate does not bear any relationship to the re-establishment of the old financial arrangements or wage arrangements between the work force and employers. As I have said, each time these issues or the waterfront comes up, the same slogans are regurgitated.

To go back further: this legislation addresses legislation created by his colleagues in the conservative party. It is legislation of the conservative party; it has never been legislation of the Labor Party. I refer the House to the Hansard of 20 October 1977, page 2246. This is where it all began. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is part of a parcel of legislation designed to enable the introduction of new administrative, financial and industrial arrangements for the stevedoring industry.
The then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Street, foreshadowed it. He went on to say:
The Bills that I am now introducing give precise expression to the decisions of principle which I indicated the government would translate into legislation during this session of Parliament.
That is the opposition's legislation. He was going to reform the waterfront. He went on:

It will be recalled that up until 1967 the nature of waterside employment was almost exclusively casual. This resulted in a situation whereby the absence of employer-employee relationships which existed in most other industries adversely affected the performance of the industry.

The waterfront we had up until the waterfront reform of this government was the creation of the conservative governments—of the Fraser government's Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Street. I will not go through all the text. Members can read it. I will just pluck out some bits to drive the point home. On the following page, page 2247, he referred to the problem of surplus labour on the waterfront. He said:
The first step was to act in respect of the problem of surplus labour.

I mention this because the previous speakers on the other side made great play of the fact that there have been redundancy payments. Redundancy payments on the waterfront were not the creation of this government or Labor governments. They were the creation of conservative Fraser governments. Mr Street went on to say:

Arising from those proceedings, a special redundancy program was developed which was to apply for a limited period . . . This program had the immediate effect of some 900 men being induced to leave their employment.

That is the very point that was made by the previous speaker. People voluntarily accepted redundancy packages. According to Hansard, the voluntary packages were advanced by the Fraser government. Mr Street continued:

I might point out that since 1975 the work force has been reduced by almost 3,000. The total industry work force has declined since 1966 from 21,000 men to a position where today there are slightly more than 10,000 waterside workers. The cost of removing men from the industry has not been light. There was, however, an acceptance by those in the industry that the level of the labour force had to be reduced and I would point out that this reduction was achieved without disruption of any kind.

What has come from those on the other side today shows that they have no knowledge of the origin of the legislation, of the arrangements on the waterfront. Those arrangements were the creation of conservative governments. The Fraser government in 1977 offered the redundancy packages to buy people—surplus work force—out of the waterfront. It is there in Hansard, as I have mentioned, on page 2247. Instead of coming here today to try to make an effective contribution to this debate, as one would expect from them, those opposite have again launched an assault on the people who work on the waterfront.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, we have the performance from the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp). The honourable member for Hume has a habit of making a statement—how inaccurate it is does not seem to matter to him—then, having made that statement, repeating it whenever the opportunity comes. The statement he made this morning about the fall-off in crane handling rates in the ports of Sydney and Melbourne I can read to you also from Hansard on page 1993 of 23 March 1994—less than two months ago. The reference he made there to crane rates falling off in the port of Sydney from 19 TEUs—20-foot equivalent units—per hour to 14 per hour and dropping from 27 TEUs per hour to 19 TEUs per hour in the port of Melbourne is exactly the one he repeated today. That information appears to have been drawn from an article in the Australian Financial Review of 17 February which quoted from advice provided by a firm called Contships.

Other operators in the industry and other users of the industry took exception to that report and to the contents of it, but the factual information that destroys what the honourable member for Hume had to say earlier, that exposes the hypocrisy of it, is from the Department of Transport, which shows that the national weighted average crane handling rates for the container terminals in the September and December quarters of 1993, which is the period he referred to, in Sydney were 20.2 TEUs per hour; in Melbourne, 20.6.

In the case of Melbourne there was a slight reduction. That related to various industrial issues that arose and terminal development work at the Commonwealth facility. Time does not permit me to pursue my point. I will resume it, I hope, on Monday. I wanted to show that the information of the two previous speakers is wrong. They have been repeating old fallacies and not dealing directly with the positive things that are happening on the waterfront.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later date.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the public opinion of Australia's politicians deteriorating, it is now time to initiate some change to the system and to make citizens feel as if they are part of the decision making process. I daresay that I am not alone among honourable members in the chamber in having many constituents contacting me to express their concern over the way that government at all levels of this country currently operates.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, according to an article in yesterday's Canberra Times, there was a survey on multicultural affairs that showed that only three in 10 voters thought the government could be trusted and only one in five considered that it knew what it is doing. People were asked to comment on whether they think leaders and other politicians are untrustworthy or insincere. The survey says something about Australians' approach to politics and to the political world.

In other words, today I wish to place on record my very strong support for the principle of citizens initiated referenda. It is a principle of having a process where the public can initiate and then make or repeal a law by referenda. No-one of any political view could deny that such an approach would be democratic. There is a need to cut the disillusionment the public has with the current system.

Public opinion, of course, is understandably disillusioned with government and politicians. All of us looked at the policies announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) prior to the last election and at what he promised. However, he tricked the Australian people because no sooner had the election taken place than the government marched into this place to announce that it was unable to fulfil its election promises.

The people of Australia were disillusioned yet again by politicians saying one thing prior to an election and then saying another immediately after. Of course, that is a tragedy. It reflects very badly not only on the Prime Minister but on all politicians in Australia. Through CIR, citizens initiated referenda, Australian people would have the opportunity to participate in the process of law-making.

There are many arguments in favour and some arguments against this initiative which had been adopted in many other parts of the world.The important thing to note is that citizens would feel that they are having a very real and meaningful input into the decision making process that affects their lives and that they are not simply being subjected to rules and regulations enforced from above.

We have had a situation in the ACT where the Liberal opposition has put forward a policy for CIR—or DD, direct democracy, as it is also known. I understand that it is very likely that the Legislative Assembly in the ACT, with the support of the Independents, could well carry this proposal, and it could be that the ACT becomes the laboratory in Australia for citizens initiated referenda. As such, this would be a catalyst for the introduction of this initiative elsewhere.

Now is the time that we in the federal parliament should consider following the example likely to be enacted shortly in the ACT assembly. It ought to be noted that the CIR is not the property of the Liberal Party. Indeed, the ALP, as you would be well aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, until the 1960s had CIR as part of its platform. The Australian Democrats have supported it; the National Party government in Queensland prior to the election in 1989 looked at it. The Liberal Party in Queensland went to the people at the last state election supporting the principle of citizens initiated referenda.

At federal level the coalition has been investigating this concept for a number of years, and honourable members would be aware of the green paper released by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) in 1988 when he was then shadow Attorney-General. The coalition has not as yet adopted the principle of CIR but I certainly hope that it is going to be on our agenda.

Of course, one ought to look at some of the principles contained in the paper by the honourable member for Flinders. It is important that a very substantial proportion of the electorate indicates that it supports the initiative to be put to the people. About five per cent of the Australian electorate would be an appropriate percentage and I understand that would amount to approximately 500,000 signatures. If we use the precedent of the American situation, this should indicate that frivolous proposals are not put up. Frivolous proposals would waste the time of the community and indeed cost great amounts of money.

It is also important to realise that referenda ought to be held only on the days of state, federal or local elections. The last thing we would want would be for referenda to be held regularly every three months. The cost would be horrendous and, indeed, we could well have a situation where the system, which I believe is very worthwhile, could be brought into disrepute.

In looking at the federal situation, it would be wise to ensure that not only was there the necessary majority of electors in the Commonwealth to carry the initiative but also that there was a majority of people in the majority of states. Of course, that goes very much to accountability. It would also go very much to recognition of the fact that any referendum carried by the Australian people should have a broad consensus right across the Australian nation.

Opponents of CIR have pointed to a number of potential drawbacks. Some people say that there is a difficulty in identifying and verifying signatures: 500,000 signatures represent a lot of people. That could be approached through a sampling process and I think that it would be very unlikely that any group would look at bringing 500,000 signatures forward, if those signatures had been forged or rorted. A verifying process by sampling could ensure that the signatures were indeed genuine.

The cost is another matter which is regularly raised by those who fear the wrath of the people. As I said, if we ensure that the referenda are held only at the time that elections are held, we would certainly get around the problem. Those people who hold others in monumental contempt would suggest that the general public does not have any ability to draft laws. Looking at some of the shocking bills and amendments that the government has brought in, and remembering the discussions we have had over and over again on certain bills, I would have to say that the public certainly would not have a monopoly on bad drafting. Facilities could be made available to people to ensure that bills were of a very high standard.

Of course, there are solutions for all of the problems raised by opponents of direct democracy. We do have a good system currently. We have a constitution that has worked and that has ensured that, as a nation, we enjoy freedoms that are the envy of the world. I include the constitutional monarchy as being one of those institutions that really have helped us as Australians to be envied by people throughout the world. But we could make our system better and I would therefore look at CIR as being a supplement to a system that works well. It is working in 26 states in the United States. It has existed in Switzerland since 1874 and it exists today in various forms in several European countries and I understand that, in Canada, it is widely used at local government level.

It is very important that, as elected representatives of the people, we do whatever we can to restore the regard that people have for the political process. We have a situation where, if we continue on the road that we are on and people are disillusioned, we could well have social breakdown. I think that is really quite tragic.

We also find that there has been a suggestion that the government is going to seek to overrule the laws in Tasmania in relation to homosexuality. If CIR existed in Tasmania, the way to resolve any problem would be for those people who feel that the Tasmanian parliament does not represent the will of the Tasmanian people to bring forward a referendum that could be dealt with at the time of the next election. The will of the people of Tasmania would determine whether the government of Tasmania is in or out of step with the community.

We must do whatever we can to gather input from the community. We, of course, do not have a monopoly on wisdom and commonsense. Indeed, many of the bills that have been carried through this place have in fact been quite ridiculous and have helped to bring Australia as a nation and the parliament as an institution into disrepute. I think that there is no valid criticism of citizen initiated referenda or direct democracy which cannot be addressed. What we have to do, as parliamentarians of all parties, is to sit down and try to work out how to take this very important initiative and make this very important improvement to our Australian system work for the benefit of the Australian people—the people we are supposed to represent. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haviland Mr C.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I would like to recognise a great moment in world history. In particular, I refer to the incredible achievements, against all odds, in recent days of a great man. Of course, I refer to Nelson Mandela, the president-elect of the Republic of South Africa. Nelson Mandela will be elected president of South Africa; it is only a matter of time before that is declared. It is worth considering the events that have taken place over the last few days and the events leading up to that great moment in world history.

PARA.TAB: In 1910 the black people of South Africa were excluded from their country's parliamentary process, so for 84 years we have had an abhorrent, repressive system of apartheid—racial discrimination—whereby all except an exclusive white minority were denied basic human rights, including the right to vote, of all things.

It is significant also to point out the contribution made by the party which I am very proud to be a member of, the Australian Labor Party, in the process that we have seen in South Africa. Last year the national executive of the Labor Party decided that the party would assist the African National Congress, Nelson Mandela's party, in its election campaign. That was a very good decision, I believe, especially given the fact that the majority of South Africans would never have voted before or ever had any experience of elections. Certainly the ANC had never been allowed to take part in an election before. So I think it was very important for like-minded political parties and political movements like the Australian Labor Party to assist in that process.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to read out a letter to the parliament, a letter that I was very proud to receive as a member of the Australian Labor Party. It was a letter dated 24 April 1994. It was sent to every member of the Australian Labor Party. My letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Chris,

I am writing to you as a member of the Australian Labor Party to say thank you for the assistance the Labor Party has provided to the ANC. This week 18 million South Africans will vote for the very first time in an election that is not merely a contest between different political organisations but a contest about freedom. Since its inception the ANC has been committed to the creation of a non-racial democratic South Africa—a South Africa that will protect the rights of the individual while building a nation in which all are equal and secure. It is a commitment I know is shared by the Australian Labor Party. But the ban on the African National Congress was lifted a mere three years ago and, unlike you, we have never fought an election. It has meant we have had to instantly acquire skills that under normal conditions would have taken decades. That is why I want to take this opportunity to express my profound appreciation of the support our struggle has received from the Australian Labor Party and therefore from you—support not just in international forums but support for ANC endorsed activities through your federal government's aid program, and more recently your party's very direct assistance in providing campaign organisers. The campaign expertise that Ian Henderson, the assistant national secretary of the Australian Labor Party, is currently providing our campaign follows a long tradition of support from Labor's parliamentary leadership, support from leaders like Gough Whitlam, Bob Hawke and more recently Prime Minister Paul Keating. It is therefore reassuring to know that in these final days I can continue to rely on the support of the Australian Labor Party, and for this I thank you.
Yours in the struggle,
Nelson R. Mandela
ANC candidate for the president of South Africa.

As I said, I was extremely proud, along with most members of the Australian Labor Party in Australia to receive that letter from Nelson Mandela. It very rightly points out the support that the ALP gave. The ALP is, after all, a like-minded party having the same beliefs in equality and democracy and social justice as the ANC. It is quite right that our party is recognised for its support.

PARA.TAB: It is also fair to mention that there are others who have contributed. One should mention the contribution made by the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, for his role as an eminent person in the CHOGM process. Of course, at that stage most of the British Commonwealth countries were on board in the fight against apartheid and repression in South Africa, all except one, the British government led by that arch right wing reactionary, Margaret Thatcher. It was still holding out in support of apartheid. But every other country in the Commonwealth knew how abhorrent the apartheid system was.

I notice my colleagues in the opposition are still trying to argue the point about this. I would have thought they would be past that by now. Nevertheless, one needs to give credit where credit is due. I believe that Malcolm Fraser, along with the other former Labor Prime Ministers I have mentioned, deserves credit for his ongoing role in the fight against apartheid and the fight for freedom, equality and democracy in South Africa. Of course he, along with Bob Hawke, has been over in South Africa recently.

I suppose my first memory of South Africa was as a country in an atlas I would have had at school where all the British Commonwealth countries were painted pink. At that stage South Africa was a member of the British Commonwealth. It pulled out of the Commonwealth in the early 1960s after being condemned for its apartheid policies.

My other early memory of South Africa is due to my lifetime interest in cricket, and to a lesser extent rugby. I can remember Australia playing cricket against South Africa and the South African cricketers being a pretty formidable bunch. There were the Pollock brothers and Eddie Barlow and those people. I certainly remember South Africa as a cricketing nation long before I was old enough to understand dreadful things like apartheid and the political repression that went on in that country. That led to our no longer playing cricket against South Africa after 1969-70 and no longer playing rugby against them after 1971, after that dreadful tour by the Springboks in 1971. They are my early memories.

Let me once again reflect on the achievements of Nelson Mandela. He is a person who has spent almost 50 years leading the struggle, leading the group called the African National Congress which now can be called a political party in the democratic process. He led that fight against overwhelming odds in a situation where the very existence of his organisation was banned. As I said, against overwhelming odds he has continued to lead that struggle and to be in the position today of being elected president, the first ever democratically elected president of the Republic of South Africa.

Not only that, this is a guy who spent 27 years in gaol. Can you imagine how you would be if you had spent 27 years in gaol. Here is a man who not only survived that and kept his sanity and kept his faculties and continued to struggle, but he has come out of 27 years in prison to continue to lead his party. The culmination of that is his election as President of the Republic of South Africa. It is truly an amazing feat and truly one which must inspire awe amongst anyone who likes to think about it. The struggle that that man has gone through, together with many of his supporters, is monumental. After 27 years in gaol still to have all his faculties, his sanity, and more importantly his resolve strengthened, is an absolutely incredible achievement.

I suppose I have one reservation about the process that has happened in South Africa. Once again I hark back to cricket. If a whites-only South African team can give us a hiding in the 1960s and give us a run for our money in the recent series, imagine what a South African cricket team chosen from the whole population could do. When it happens, when the first ever fully representative South African cricket team is selected, imagine what it will do to the Australian team.

Seriously though, I think that the resumption of sporting contact with South Africa has been a very positive thing. It has assisted this democratic process. But the resumption of cricket and rugby and other sporting ties, as well as the removal of trade sanctions against South Africa, would not have happened without the endorsement of Nelson Mandela. And that needs to be stressed as well.

So I think it is a wonderful result for South Africa and a wonderful result for equality and democracy worldwide. I can only ask people to consider the enormous achievements that have been made in the last few days, being the culmination of the achievements of the last few years in South Africa. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.
SPEECH.PARA: They shall not grow old as we who are left grow old.
Age shall not weary them nor the years condemn.
At the going down of the sun and in the morning, we will remember them.

Less than two weeks ago Australia paid homage to the men and women who died on foreign shores for the sake of maintaining the Australian way of life. While we remember those who died, it seems that the federal government would rather forget those remaining. Despite the assurances of the new Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca), I grieve today for the veterans that returned.

PARA.TAB: Throughout the past 10 years Australia has been addressing the discrepancies which have occurred in the recognition of the returned service personnel. Recently, however, the federal government has turned around and is once again making the veterans suffer during their time of need. The role of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, as its name suggests, is to look after the interests of all veterans. This would suggest that it should be working with the Returned Services League to establish the most effective means of resolving veteran issues and concerns. The RSL is recognised as the main avenue of support for veterans. The league, however, is continually being kept out of important decisions which affect the lives of thousands of Australians.

It has been brought to my attention that in at least two major issues recently faced by veterans in Western Australia the government has ignored the wishes of veterans. This has left the veterans confused and often scared—scared at how the government is treating those who assumed they would be looked after by the country which they fought for. Firstly, there is the selling of Hollywood hospital. This is one of the many veteran hospitals which was sacrificed in the federal government's rationalisation process. Prior to the calling for tenders in the beginning of 1993, each state government was approached and offered control of the hospitals. The Western Australian government declined this offer. Since then the Hollywood hospital has been privately purchased by Ramsays, and, while part of the condition of the sale was that veterans would still have access to the hospital and its facilities, the men and women who have risked their lives for this country have put up with a changeover which is less than satisfactory.

This has coincided with the introduction of a scheme which invites veterans to use public hospitals as private patients. While many of the veterans would prefer to continue using the hospital which they have attended for many years, they are being `encouraged' to go elsewhere. This includes being informed that the treatment that they require is only available at a hospital other than Hollywood. This treatment has been available in the past at Hollywood hospital. Since part of the conditions of sale was the maintaining of the ability for veterans to use the facilities, surely the new owners of the hospital would have kept the various facilities which are required for service injuries and illnesses. Veterans are now faced with the trauma of new surroundings and staff.

The federal government, in its wisdom, neglected to ask the people who use the veterans' hospital if they wanted an alternative venue. The disbursement of funds, which increases the bureaucratic jungle faced by the department, would be increasing total expense, not decreasing it, as a rationalisation program should. No longer do the veterans have the sense of stability in the knowledge that the medical staff would be familiar to them and would know the problems of the patients. Those living within close proximity of the hospital have to face changes in the facilities available since the privatisation of the Hollywood Hospital. The radiography and pathology units are no longer under the control of the hospital. Indeed, the pathology unit is now situated at the St John of God Hospital, some six kilometres away.

The staffing levels of these facilities have also decreased significantly. For example, where radiography used to have between 12 and 16 staff members to cater for patients, under the new lease there are only four staff. Outpatients of Hollywood hospital are now not only facing the trauma of having their medical facilities altered greatly, but they are also facing an increase in the financial burden for necessary medication. Prior to the privatisation of the hospital, both inpatients and outpatients were able to use the registered pharmacist to collection prescriptions at a cost of $2.60. Since the change of owner, however, outpatients are required to pay the full cost of prescriptions dispensed from the hospital and then seek reimbursement. The only alternative they have is taking their prescriptions to another pharmacy.

Many veterans do not have their own transport and need to rely on family and friends to take them to the hospital. By having to go elsewhere for necessary medication, the burden, which is placed not only on the veterans but now also on their drivers, is increased. The veterans who have previously used the hospital are also facing psychological battles. The new administration of the hospital decided that new medical files would be issued to all patients. It was with horror that many veterans found, on arrival for an appointment with a doctor at the hospital, that their previous records had apparently vanished. This resulted in many of the veterans contacting the Department of Veterans' Affairs to determine where their files had been placed. The issue of the records was made more confusing when it was revealed that the department was not aware of what had happened to these files.

Most people prefer to have one doctor or centre which they attend. The alteration of hospital procedure is making the veterans relive the receiving of their injuries. This stability is of particular importance to many of the veterans who have been attending the Hollywood Hospital for decades. I can only begin to imagine the trauma which these people must have faced when they were placed under the impression that they would be required to recall their past problems to receive correct medical attention.

Not only are the veterans undergoing a battle to keep the security which they have found in hospital but they are increasingly having to fight for the right to compensation for injuries and illnesses which they received during their service. The involvement of the Department of Veterans' Affairs with the claiming of compensation has recently increased dramatically. People in the RSL, which assists the veterans in the procedure involved, are currently being retrained in two-day seminars.

A clear warning for what the federal government plans to install for the Australian veterans was highlighted in a case which was part of the Baume committee investigations. The Bushell case, which was recently resolved in the High Court, determined whether the Department of Veterans' Affairs had the right to overrule the decision of a medical specialist on a disability compensation claim. It had been determined that Bushell had started smoking through stress during the Second World War. The majority of state governments not only have legislation which bans cigarette advertising from sporting events but run comprehensive `quit' campaigns. Cases of businesses being sued for passive smoking are becoming a common event.

The federal government, however, will not admit that issuing cigarettes in military ration packs during the Second World War and the Vietnam War may have induced soldiers to start smoking and, as a result, they are now dying of lung cancer. A decision by the High Court, with only one dissenting judge, that the Department of Veterans' Affairs cannot override the findings of that qualified medical specialist was still not good enough for the government. In fear that it would have to give yet more money to the brave men and women of Australia, the government sought any legal advice which could override the precedent which had been set.

The Baume report, which is to be tabled next week in parliament, addresses many issues which are of grave concern to veterans. It would seem that the decisions made in this report, which will affect the lives of many thousands of Australians, have been made without referring to the Returned Services League.
I refer to the minister's comment yesterday in answer to a question, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Further, irrespective of any recommendations of the Baume committee, I can assure the House that all legitimate claims will continue to be recognised and that no significant changes will be made without consultation with our ex-service community.

In Western Australia, neither the state executive nor the chairman of the state veterans' affairs committee has yet seen the Baume committee report. Is it any wonder that veterans are fearful of the implications that this report has in store for them? In the past, veterans have had the RSL to reassure them in times of need. By keeping this organisation at bay on important recommendations, this security blanket is being taken away. The offer of assistance by the Department of Veterans' Affairs is barely a substitute. Like any other government department, the Department of Veterans' Affairs must abide by the rulings that the federal government brings down. I can only hope that the new Minister for Veterans' Affairs—good fellow that he is—follows what he has stated about not adhering to all the recommendations of the report. Although these veterans have fought long and hard for our country, it seems that their battle continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to grieve for the Aboriginal people who are victims of what I see as the Aboriginal industry which, while absorbing an enormous amount of taxpayers' funds, is clearly not benefiting the Aboriginal people. In my own electorate, there are many areas where housing is appalling. The last time I had a look at Jiggalong community, for instance, it needed 42 houses. The number today would probably be closer to 80. We will only ever build a few houses at a time—five houses this year, five next year. When the houses are built, they are overcrowded. They are often catering for 30 people, sometimes more. Because of this overcrowding, the houses deteriorate rapidly. Doors will only open and close so many times, the toilet will only flush so many times before a breakdown does occur. When the breakdown occurs, of course, we blame the victims. We say, `These useless blackfellows: we give them all this infrastructure and they destroy it.' I find that particularly offensive and it is certainly counterproductive.

PARA.TAB: There is a way around it and I believe it must be addressed. I am presently looking at a proposal—not a new one; one I put forward 12 years ago at least—to involve Aboriginal people in the construction of their own houses. It is interesting to note that where people are involved in the construction of their houses there is certainly a greater pride taken in them. They are not subject to the same vandalism and more care is generally taken of them. I think this occurs throughout society, in whatever country or whatever ethnic group we happen to be talking about.

In the present system of house construction, we bring in a house from outside. We say to a contractor, `You must employ Aboriginal people.' He promptly jacks his price up by 20 per cent to accommodate the cost. The training given to these people is minimal. It is simply, `Hold this. Stand there. Do that,' to the end of the program—usually about 16 weeks. Then they throw them back on the scrap heap. If we could change that to a system where we use local material and the cost is transferred from material to labour, we could build a much cheaper house. We could have a much greater degree of actual Aboriginal ownership of the property and we could have a continual process where people would learn real skills.

In passing, with the interest being taken in Australian heritage matters, there is going to be a big demand for stonemasons in the future. If we follow this program, maybe in 30 years time the only stonemasons available will be Aboriginal people and they will be able to demand a very high price for their labour. In the meantime, we can provide much better housing if we go about it this way. We do not need to build a four-bedroom house for a young couple starting out; a two-bedroom house is adequate. As a new child arrives, the building group comes back and puts on another room. If the design is appropriate to accommodate this, the growth of the house is quite easy and can be done without much disruption. This would enable us to house these people much more quickly than can be done at the moment and in houses in which they have a big stake. But that is not happening.

I believe this project has the strong support of Cedric Wyatt, the Director of the Aboriginal Affairs Planning Authority in Western Australia, but we are going to have to set a pattern. It is ironic that the much abused mining industry is the source of that funding. I am hoping that negotiations with the mining industry will be successful and we can get the mining industry to fund the trainer and the necessary vehicle. We have many communities picked out where we think this would be appropriate and would be welcomed. We would be looking first at one in the Wittenoom area in Western Australia.

When one sees the money being poured into Aboriginal affairs, one must speculate as to what is happening. Today we are spending on Aboriginal affairs money that would buy every Aboriginal family in Australia a new house every two years. Clearly, they are not getting it. The money is not doing what it is supposed to do. I have said before in this House that we should be asking ourselves: what is the point of the Aboriginal affairs policy? Is it to improve the lot of Aboriginal people? If that is the case, I do not think it has been a great success. I have Aboriginal communities that 30 years ago used to kill their own meat, bake their own bread and grow their own vegetables. Today that is all bought frozen from capital cities. The consequent cost and effect on their lifestyle and standard of living have been quite dramatic.

I believe that alcoholism in Aboriginal people is very much a result of sheer boredom and frustration. It is interesting to note that, in areas where we have been able to get genuine work programs going, alcoholism and absenteeism have abated considerably. I believe the great bulk of Aboriginal people want to participate in the wider community and are being thwarted because governments of both persuasions tend to listen to the self-appointed spokespeople.

I said in the House during the debate on the Mabo legislation that there was no consultation with the Aboriginal people in my electorate even though I represent more Aboriginals than any other member of parliament in this place. In fact, one of them wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and got a reply from the minister then responsible—the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Walker)—saying that because of the complexity of the issue and the distances involved the government had decided to consult only with ATSIC, the Kimberley Land Council and the Aboriginal Legal Service. None of these bodies are representative; certainly none of them have the support of the great bulk of Aboriginal people.

The situation now is that the government is looking at establishing a very large land acquisition fund. I have a letter here from the Chairman of the Kimberley Aboriginal Association, which I would like to incorporate into Hansard. If I have to read it I will, but I would like it to be incorporated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you shown it to the—
—I have not but I am sure he will not object.
—Provided it meets the guidelines set by the Speaker.

—Mr Cox is calling on the government to handle the land acquisition money through ATSIC. He is not a great supporter of ATSIC, but these Aboriginal people are terrified of land councils. They know the land councils do not represent them, and the Kimberley Land Council is a particular problem. It has very little real support amongst Aboriginal people, although it appears to have the ear of the media and of both major political parties in Western Australia. It is ironic that so often the voices of the people we should be listening to are so totally ignored. The government should heed the advice and demands of Aboriginal people that no new body be set up to handle the land acquisition funds but that they be handled through the existing body, which Aboriginal people think can be made much more accountable than it is today.

PARA.TAB: I just want to demonstrate, in the couple of minutes left to me, how the myth of self-management works. It is a process by which we continually blame the victim. We look at the budget for a station property which an Aboriginal community has acquired. Every station property needs a five-year plan. So we fund the first year, probably late in the year, and then we do not deliver the next year's money until much later in the year and the money cannot be acquitted in time. If the money is not acquitted it is rolled over so the same money is there for the third year. So Aboriginal communities then call in white contractors to do the work and we then say, `Look at these lazy so-and-sos, they get the gubba to come and do the work', when the only reason they do that is that they know they cannot acquit the money in time. We see stations which are in desperate need of capital for stock being denied this money.

It appears to me that there are people who realise that if the Aboriginal people had the stock they would be self-sufficient and would not be dependent; it seems to me that what is wanted continually by the Aboriginal industry is dependence, not self-sufficiency. The town of Roebourne is an example. Roebourne has been through its traumas. The Aboriginal community committee there decided that it would fund a children's wading pool to go with the very large new pool which the state government provided to the town. The committee wanted the wading pool because Aboriginal children are often charged with looking after siblings and they cannot take them into the big pool; young children are not allowed into the pool unless they are accompanied. The ATSIC committee in Roebourne saw this as a very good, socially useful expenditure of money that also would have very strong implications for health and welfare. The decision was thwarted by bureaucrats in Canberra, who said the proposal was outside the guidelines and that the funding should come from state government or local government—the state government has already made a massive contribution there. The population of Roebourne is 98 per cent Aboriginal. The Aboriginal people made a decision, but their self-determination was thwarted by Aboriginal bureaucrats in Canberra whose vested interest is in maintaining forever the massive industry which they have established. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The fundamental accountability and electoral processes in Australia are now being challenged at the federal, state and local government level. The most recent example of this erosion of Australia's democracy is the recent ruling by the United Nations Human Rights Committee that certain sections of the Tasmanian criminal code are in breach of international law. This is not an argument about the rights or wrongs of the Tasmanian criminal law, nor a suggestion that the Commonwealth should not have the external affairs powers granted to it by section 51 of the constitution for judicious use in particular circumstances.

PARA.TAB: For decades, the use of this power allowed the Commonwealth to make and enforce laws relating to shipping, international trade and various criminal matters having international ramifications. But, during the 1970s, the Whitlam government decided to use the external affairs power to implement international treaties which have had significant domestic effects within Australia but which were otherwise beyond the scope of Commonwealth power.

This power was tested in the High Court in the Franklin Dam case of 1983 when the High Court narrowly ruled against a Tasmanian government decision to construct a dam on the grounds that a piece of Commonwealth legislation—the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act—was a valid exercise of the Commonwealth's external affairs power. The four judges in the majority claimed that a Commonwealth law giving effect to a treaty was valid whether or not the subject matter of the treaty involved relationships with other countries or persons outside Australia. This decision opened the floodgates to an expansion of Commonwealth powers as evidenced by the following acts: the Racial Discrimination Act 1975; the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983; the Sex Discrimination Act 1984; the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Act 1986; the Ozone Protection Act 1989; the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992; the Disability Discrimination Act 1992; the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993; and the Native Title Act 1993.

The main issue is not one of the Tasmanian legislation, although I make the point that the Tasmanian criminal code was voted upon by a democratically elected body accountable to its electors in a way that remains a pipedream for the citizens of some of the countries which make up the membership of the United Nations Human Rights Committee. The people of Tasmania have the political power and the legal capacity to remove the current Tasmanian government from office at the next election, unlike the ongoing United Nations Human Rights Committee which is accountable to nobody.

The human rights committee consists of 18 experts who are nominated for four-year terms. They are not elected. It is not a court of law. It does not follow established legal procedures, and it does not advance reasoned legal opinions for its decisions. The human rights record of some of the countries which are currently members of the committee, and which have recently sat in judgment on the Tasmanian case, is beyond belief. A 1993 report published by Amnesty International on human rights violations that occurred during 1992, whilst the committee was considering the Tasmanian case, provides some interesting background material. The report was littered with such phrases as `mobilisation of troops', `disappearance and torture of suspects', `extra-judicial execution' and `arrest without warrant and detention without trial'.

Ecuador is represented on the United Nations committee which has taken Tasmania to task. The Amnesty report details the case of Victor Cadena, who was detained by the Ecuadorian police for three days in July 1992. He was suspended from a rope with his arms tied behind his back. He was beaten and given electric shocks. Other persons engaged in peaceful protest in Ecuador in October of the same year were also tortured with electric shocks and threatened with being thrown from helicopters. How do these examples square with the right to privacy guaranteed in the UN covenant which the human rights committee seeks to enforce? Will the Ecuadorian delegate turn his attention to matters closer to home when he has solved the problems of Tasmania for which he is not accountable?

Let me turn to another committee member—Senegal. During 1992, Senegalese government troops beat and killed civilians, including children, in the village of Bissine. Other detainees were reported to have had molten plastic dripped on their skin. The Senegalese government failed to investigate human rights violations, including cases of detention without trial, despite these very matters being referred to the same UN Human Rights Committee which dealt with the Tasmanian issue.

It is a particular strength of the Australian way of life that these abuses of power do not occur. We do not need to be instructed or supervised by unrepresentative committees who have only had a passing or theoretical awareness of genuine rights and freedoms. Australia has a strong tradition of due processes of law, free elections and government accountability, which is the envy of much of the rest of the world and which is not and has never been based on the approval of UN committees.

I now turn to Amnesty's comments about Venezuela, another committee member. Arrest without warrant and detention in cruel and degrading conditions were reported. Beatings and torture, near-asphyxiation with plastic bags and mock executions were also alleged. Investigation of these incidents made little or no progress. Yet the Venezuelan delegate condemns the laws of a democratically elected government for arbitrary interference with the privacy of Australian citizens who brought that complaint forward.

What a total sham. What a grotesque farce that the Australian government is so willing to hand itself over for judgment to extra-legal committees who have no constituency or accountability to the Australian people. What an extraordinary double standard that this government and this Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who so regularly lecture us about national independence and a move away from constitutional monarchy, are willing to grovel this way before a committee composed in part of very undemocratic regimes having no stake in Australia.

How can a treaty be interpreted if bald statements of opinion are offered in place of detailed logical reasoning? Why should Australia commit itself to international treaties cast in wide terms and in general language? No genuinely independent country should contemplate treaties or arrangements which do not spell out the full extent of their obligations and which leave that interpretation open to the whim and caprice of those member nations who for the time being are sitting in judgment.

The greatest shame of all is that the Commonwealth government is such a willing accomplice in allowing democratically elected state governments to be judged by these tribunals, who do not even allow the state government to appear before them. Australian states are not even recognised under international law and cannot put a case before the committee, which to many Australians is a denial of natural justice to the electors who vote a state government in or out of office. The absurdity of the situation is clear when four of the countries represented on the Human Rights Commission have laws against certain homosexual behaviour or practices similar to the Tasmanian situation.

The recently enacted Industrial Relations Reform Act relies on the use of International Labour Organisation conventions to override state legislation and establish minimum standards and provide coverage to non-union labour and persons working under state awards. This is another powerful reminder of the extraordinary influence that the use of the external affairs power is having on domestic policy within Australia to concentrate power in Canberra based on unaccountable external bodies.

The Basel Convention on the Movement of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal came into force two years ago. Leaving aside questions as to what constitutes waste and the part played by the Greenpeace organisation in promoting the convention within the United Nations, the convention ultimately rests upon the proposition that international solutions alone can solve local waste disposal problems and that they must always override the decisions of otherwise sovereign states. Such a treaty would seem desirable enough on the surface but the convention, about which there has been no domestic political debate, has had the effect of taking the control of the transport of waste materials out of the hands of national governments.

Our willing acceptance of international supervision of what constitutes waste and how it should be dealt with provides another example of how Australia can have views imposed upon itself by non-accountable bodies. In the final analysis, wastes have to be disposed of by local, state and federal governments. For political purposes within Australia this rampant new internationalism is a device for transferring power from democratically elected governments to foreign bureaucrats who have no constituency within this country. It portrays a total lack of nerve or confidence which is at odds with the government's newly found nationalism and independence.

Another example of this use of the external affairs powers, which also involves the Greenpeace organisation, relates to an attempt by that group to halt the construction of a power station in the Hunter Valley in New South Wales. Greenpeace has admitted that it is attempting to enforce an international convention, the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, and in doing so set aside decisions made by democratically elected bodies.

What do these issues have in common? They focus attention on the simple fundamental question: is Australia a master of its own destiny or do our democratically elected state and federal governments have to be constantly second-guessing whether or not their legislation is going to measure up to the wishes of some group of bureaucrats in New York or in Geneva? These people are not accountable to Australians through the ballot box. They often come from countries with besmirched reputations, countries which at best have but a nodding acquaintance with the democratic forms and procedures which have formed part of the Australian way of life for so long. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes available to me I want to address three things. I want to express concern about some statements made in this House both yesterday and today. I know that occasionally this House is referred to as cowards' castle, but I think it very important that we understand that despite our spats with each other, and despite the fact that this is a robust House, we are a fairly caring community and we do not indulge in sleaze all that often.

PARA.TAB: The late Bob Katter was a thoroughly decent and gentle man. He was the type of fellow who worked hard for this nation, and I think he earned the love of everyone who came into contact with him. Today I grieve for the memory of Bob Katter Sr. I would hope that his son, the present member for Kennedy, would look at his father's career and try to emulate the way his father behaved and the way he conducted himself. I hope that this House does its darnedest to avoid incidents of the nature that we saw yesterday and today.

Ignorance of the law is no excuse, but it is a great pity that we do not do more to educate people about the law and about the rules which operate. I am referring chiefly to matters of social security. In the last 12 months or so I have had numerous complaints from parents who could not have been expected to know that if they took their children overseas they would lose welfare benefits. I had the very sad case of a lone parent who had to undergo a very serious operation. When she came out of hospital she found it impossible to care for her nine-year-old daughter. So her sister in New Zealand rang and said, `Send Jenny across to me. You can't care for her. Send Jenny across to me for a month until you get back on your feet. I will look after her. I will pay her way across to New Zealand.' That arrangement was made but this lady, who exists only on welfare payments, discovered that she had to pay the Department of Social Security a couple of hundred dollars because she was not eligible for the family allowance she had been receiving for her daughter. There are many cases of that nature.

There is another matter I want the public to know about, and we have to publicise it. I cannot understand why the courts and solicitors do not make people more aware of this situation. I know that every member of this House would have encountered some poor being in their office telling a story along these lines: `I will never work again. I am a complete cripple. I used to have a good job, but I was injured in a car accident. I am 43 years of age. After I was injured in the car accident I was in hospital, had all any hospital debts—doctors fees, et cetera—and they told me that I would get compensation, through third party insurance. Finally, after a protracted period of maybe two years of hardship living on the social security payment, I got the princely sum of $200,000 compensation. So what did I do? I am 43 years of age with a wife and a kid, and was renting a house. So I bought a new house that cost $125,000. We have never had a car so I bought a car.' The money was spent very wisely, but what happened then? Nobody told this poor devil—and there are many poor devils who have seen me regarding these matters—that Social Security could send a great lumping bill and say, `Hey, mate, all those social security payments have to be refunded.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2.45 p.m., in accordance with the resolution agreed to on 4 May 1994 the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That grievances be noted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I add my congratulations to the National Party's Ted Malone for his win in last Saturday's Mirani state by-election in North Queensland. Not only is this win another feather in the caps of Joan Sheldon, Rob Borbidge and Queensland's Liberal-National coalition; it reinforces the wisdom of the end to three-cornered contests at the state level.

PARA.TAB: The strong Mirani win for the National Party under the recently announced joint Liberal-National arrangements clearly shows that the electorate responds positively to a concentration of efforts behind one coalition candidate. At the Liberal Party state convention next month, I will be supporting similar arrangements at the federal level. I hope that these arrangements and an appropriate Senate agreement will be in place later this year.

We need to win seats in Queensland if we are to assume the Treasury benches in Canberra. That will not happen while the Liberal Party and National Party continue to pay lip-service to a federal coalition and to three-cornered contests in Queensland. I therefore call on the Queensland Liberal Party state president, Bob Tucker, and the National Party state president, Don McDonald, to work to this end as a matter of urgency.

I also reinforce earlier remarks by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) that we need a dose of citizen initiative and referendum, not as a replacement for, but as a strong supplement to, our Westminster arrangements. We ignore direct democracy initiatives, particularly in this, the 50th anniversary year of the Liberal Party. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a statement of appreciation for those involved in the successful campaign to construct an international length runway at Badgerys Creek in Sydney's south-west. This campaign for the past three years has involved local government leaders, business leaders, members of the community and state and federal MPs. It has been a tremendous effort. But our appreciation and congratulations lie most substantially with the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), who has been able to turn this issue around within five months to do the planning and, most significantly, to get the allocation of $73 million in the white paper to build a 2,900-metre runway.

PARA.TAB: But this is not the first time that the minister, in a federal or state capacity, has produced the goods for Sydney's west. He has been at the centre of the great campaigns in our region over the last 20 years. The man who got the beds for the west as a state minister in the mid-1980s is now getting the jobs for the west in the mid-1990s through the Badgerys Creek airport project.

This is very significant, because the only other major campaign for our region has been the establishment of the University of Western Sydney. At that time, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith was a minister in the Unsworth government which produced the outcome needed to develop that regional facility. In the 1980s, there was growth in the number of hospital beds. In the 1990s, jobs are coming to the region through the development of the international airport. This is the sort of policy outlook that we have always needed in Sydney's west and south-west. I am very pleased that this quality decision has come from a quality minister. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will today tell the House about the extraordinary set of priorities of the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear). It now seems that students will have to learn how to pay tax, how to become identified through a tax file number and how to claim Austudy. We now have this wonderful thing called `Paying Tax', which is a kit that has been sent out to all secondary schools. It seems that the government's priorities are quite extraordinary. Where is the kit on how to earn a living, get a job or run a business? It seems that all Labor is interested in is teaching kids at school how to pay tax.

PARA.TAB: It ought to be remembered that it is not just in the dictionary that the word `employment' comes before the word `tax'. Clearly, it seems that the government has given up on tax simplification. The number of pages in the tax act in the last 10 years has more than doubled to 5,000. I defy even a university professor to understand exactly what is in it.

It clearly seems that the government has failed to make the tax system comprehensible. Now it wants to replace important learning time in schools with this extraordinary new kit. It comes complete with a video and overheads. It even has cartoons, just to make sure that people know what this word `tax' is. Maybe it should not be taken as seriously as some think. Is this what the tax office is about when it says `building a better Australia'? Some building; some Australia! What an extraordinarily sad set of priorities. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the comments of the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) about Badgerys Creek. What a great victory for the people of western Sydney and the Macarthur region. I note with interest that the Liberal Party of Australia is celebrating its 50th anniversary next month. Given the current state of the Liberal Party, I am not sure whether `celebrating' is the right term. It is not a term I would use.

PARA.TAB: When I was growing up and learning about politics, the Liberal Party supposedly stood for certain things. Apart from its economic belief in market capitalism, the Liberal Party was supposed to believe in freedom of speech, the rights of the individual and, in particular, the supremacy of individual rights over the power of the state. Everything to do with the power of the state was evil.

Let us look at the situation in Tasmania with the outrageous anti-gay laws. The United Nations has made some comments condemning the Tasmanian gay laws. As soon as somebody in the federal government suggests that perhaps we need to look at them, what do we hear from the federal coalition? All we ever hear from these people is states rights. We never hear anything about individual rights or people's rights. We never hear anything about the rights of Aboriginal people in Western Australia, or the rights of women, or the rights of people from non-English speaking backgrounds, or the rights of any other groups. All we ever hear is states rights. I think it is time the Liberal Party had a look at itself. Its 50th anniversary might be the opportunity to do that.

The line members of the Liberal Party are putting on the rights of individuals in Tasmania, in particular, about doing whatever consenting adults like to do in the privacy of their own homes does not sit well with the supposed individual liberties and freedoms preached by the Liberal Party. All we ever hear is states rights. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 May the present Australian contingent serving with the United Nations peacekeeping force in Somalia is due to return home after seven months in appalling conditions. United Nations travel guidelines require that the return journey be at the cheapest level, but only 10 economy seats are available on the direct flight back for 38 troops. Apparently no-one in the United Nations command thought to book far enough ahead. As a consequence, the other 28 soldiers would have to travel business class. They have been asked to personally pay the $150 difference from the economy fare. The only alternative is a round-the-world return journey, which could take up to three days. Although land force command in Sydney has some informal knowledge of the situation, the United Nations command has given no official advice of the problem. That Australian troops should be treated in this manner is a disgrace. The government must rectify the matter immediately.

PARA.TAB: The government should also move to end the prolonged indecision as to whether Australian troops serving in Somalia are to receive the Australian Service Medal or the Australian Active Service Medal. It would be most appropriate if members of the current contingent receive the medal decided upon as a group when they come home.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Liberal Party of Australia: National Headquarters

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) mentioned the 50th anniversary of the Liberal Party of Australia. I would like to continue with that topic. When I walk to work here of a morning, I pass the building in Barton which is the headquarters of the Liberal Party. Recently it has been tarted up a little bit. Bits and pieces have been added to it. What is happening there is very symbolic. What the Liberal Party has done to this old building—built in the 1950s or 1960s of nice red brick with little windows—is added nice red bricks and little windows.

PARA.TAB: What the Liberal Party has done is exactly what we expect from it. It cannot change; it cannot adapt. It continues with the same old thing—tarting up old policies and old buildings. I believe it will be opened on 23 June. This is very symbolic of the party. It wants the same old thing. It does not want any change. It does not want to adapt. Whenever a policy comes out, whatever it does, it wants to do the same thing and never change.

I always used to enjoy this little walk. The sign on the front has gone now. Members of the Builders Labourers Federation worked on this building. On the front of the building a sign read `no ticket, no start'. It was quite ironic that here was the Liberal Party constructing the same old sort of edifice with the same bricks, the same building, the same doors, the same windows, and it had to use good old workers—not like the Australian Labor Party: we have new buildings and new policies; we are prepared to adapt and change. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the grievance debate today, I heard the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) make an outrageous claim that the Bjelke-Petersen government was the most corrupt in this country's history. I should remind the honourable member that Western Australia is part of this nation, even though the federal Labor Party tends to ignore us—
—Carmen is here now!

—She certainly is. The former Labor governments in our state, the governments of Brian Burke, Peter Dowding and Carmen Lawrence, were more corrupt than any other. Millions upon millions of taxpayers' dollars was squandered by those governments in deals with their big business mates, many of whom have now disappeared overseas, and it is most disappointing that those responsible for losing the money—money which should have been spent on schools, hospitals, police, improving our sewerage system and so on—have not been brought to account.

PARA.TAB: The question must be asked: when this money was being squandered why did any cabinet minister not put his or her foot down and ask, `Where the hell has the money gone?' One must ask, when Burke and Dowding were gone, why did the next Labor Premier not have the guts to call a royal commission there and then? My office is often being called by people outraged at having to pay a WA Inc. levy. I say to them, `It is Burke, Dowding and Lawrence's fault. They lost your money. They didn't have the honesty to pursue the truth and Western Australian taxpayers are suffering in the hip pocket for the WA Labor Party's corruption,' which is the most corrupt government in this nation's history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talking about corrupt governments, let us have a look at the Kennett government. One has only to look at what it is doing in Victoria at the present time. Mr Jeffrey Kennett's mate Mr Walker is building the casino there and is having everything changed because it is not big enough for him. Then Mr Kennett's mate Mr Walker gets the Grand Prix down there. Where is the Grand Prix going to go? It is to be built and run on private land at Albert Park Lake, and it happens to be very close to Mr Walker's new proposed casino. So you can imagine where the people will be staying when they go to the Grand Prix, which Mr Walker—who owns the casino and is Mr Kennett's mate—runs. The Grand Prix will not go to Phillip Island where there is already a track or Sandown; it will go to Albert Park Lake. Who owns Albert Park Lake? The people. Who is going to give it to a private person? Mr Kennett. Why is he going to do this? Because he has his hand in Mr Walker's pocket or Mr Walker has his hand in the pocket of Mr Kennett—one of the two.

PARA.TAB: One also has to look at what Mr Kennett is doing for himself. He is spending $9 million on doing up his own accommodation. You did not see that on the front page of the Herald-Sun; you saw it a little bit in the background. This is what he is up to all the time. He looks after his own mates and looks after himself while charging people $100 poll tax and $33 on all electricity bills. I got a bill for a house down in Phillip Island. The electricity charge was $4.75 and the service charge was $33. He is doing this every quarter. (Time expired).

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the 50th anniversary of the Liberal Party of Australia and we are proud of it. We are not a party which has come into this parliament and is trying to rort the system, as the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) has chosen to ignore, by having Centenary House taken over by the Auditor-General's office as a means of funding the Labor Party. We are the party which now runs every state in this Commonwealth with the exception of Queensland.
