We are controlling those states because in every case the Labor Party was thrown out through the democratic process by the very people that this mob over here claims to be supporting.

PARA.TAB: Do not come into the House and try to serve us on the question of the Liberal Party having its 50th anniversary. You look to the fact that the Labor Party today is everything that Ben Chifley did not stand for. You have come in here in the last 48 hours with a white paper trying to claim that you hold the mantle of Ben Chifley. What rubbish! You have divided the Australian community to an extent never known in this century. You have brought poverty to more people than ever known since the days of the Great Depression. Yes, this is the 50th anniversary of the Liberal Party. The Liberal Party stands for independence, it stands for individuality, it stands for the rights of minorities, it stands for the rights of every Australian citizen; and we are proud of it in this year, our 50th anniversary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Friday evening the Hon. Neville Wran spoke at the Evatt Foundation annual dinner to commemorate and celebrate the 100th anniversary of the birth of Dr Herbert Vere Evatt. It is worth quoting from Neville Wran's speech:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a great pity that there are not more people in Australia imbued with the Doc's immovable conviction that our hard earnt civil liberties should be defended at all costs. On the contrary, too many of us in this country seem willing to jettison our civil liberties under the guise of the maintenance of law and order. These people—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.00 p.m., in accordance with the resolution agreed to on 4 May 1994, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister, and I must say how pleased we are to see him here today. It must be payday. I ask the Prime Minister: given the major expenditure commitments that are contained in the white paper, will he absolutely rule out any tax increases in the forthcoming budget?

—I was asked this question at the Press Club earlier today and I gave the very simple answer that on budget night all will be revealed about what the government is doing on these things. The question implies that in some way there is some discretionary spending on the government's part which it must be bound to cover by a tax increase of some kind. Any society which values all of its people having an opportunity to work and to participate in the growths, fruits and prosperity of the society will recognise that a program of the kind outlined yesterday satisfies both the criteria of economic efficiency and equity, that is, equity on the basis that unemployed people are entitled to participate in the labour market, and on the basis that to have 360,000 people unemployed for 12 months or more is a drag on the efficiency of the national economy and skills formation. As we go into a stronger recovery we will need that complement of skills. So I would regard the package, even from the opposition's point of view, as something that the government should reasonably have done and, therefore, the doing of it a legitimate cost on the nation and the budget of the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: The implication of the question is that we should not be doing these things and that, if we do them, why are we not paying for them, and how? The opposition has disagreed all the way along with the government's fiscal strategy, a strategy which has now produced four per cent growth for the year. We are growing as fast as, or faster than, any other industrial country. We have already seen an increase in job growth of 250,000 over the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about interest rates?

—By way of interjection, the Leader of the Opposition says, `What about interest rates?' Is he arguing that the marginally lower financing effect of $1.7 billion on the budget is not, in macro-economic terms, more than compensated for by greater efficiencies from the major micro-economic reforms of the labour market? Of course it is. The Leader of the Opposition is directing questions to me about interest rates. As he knows, at the moment there is not a lot of rationality in interest rate settings in the marketplace of this country and appealing to their vanity with a lower budget deficit, lower than it might have otherwise been, is simply not on.
—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Can he inform the House of the benefits to small business from initiatives in his portfolio announced in yesterday's white paper?

—I think I might be able to manage that. There are two particular initiatives in the white paper which will go a long way towards improving the lot of small business and its operations in this country. The first is an acceleration of the simplification program for the Corporations Law. This program, which has been operating since the end of last year, has been well received by the community generally, particularly by the small business community with regard to that proposal dealing with the simplification of the rules governing exempt proprietary companies. Those are the 800,000-odd companies which are predominantly the vehicles from which many small businesses take their form. Removing a number of the requirements placed upon those companies in terms of the paperwork, the returns and the forms they need to supply to the ASC takes a lot of the burden off small business and should do a lot towards reducing costs. Acceleration of the program will allow more targeting of areas within the Corporations Law for simplification and should allow us to achieve our goals at a faster rate.

PARA.TAB: The second initiative concerns major reforms to the way we deal with delegated legislation, that is, regulation. Many business organisations and individual business people often point to the unnecessary red tape, unnecessary regulation or regulation which may have had an aim at one point but which outlived its usefulness a long time ago.

The reforms announced in the white paper will, for the first time, create a comprehensive electronic database of all subordinate legislation in this country. This will complement the program announced in last year's budget concerning all Commonwealth primary legislation, all statutes. So for the first time we will actually have a single database of all Commonwealth law, in effect, which is a basic requirement of government to provide.

Combined with the establishment of the register, there will be provisions to periodically and systematically review regulation. Those provisions will ensure that when further regulation is made an adequate consultation process will be entered into, particularly with business. There will be effective analysis of the cost and benefit of the regulation and of whether there are alternative ways of achieving the same social end without unnecessarily putting a burden on business. There will also be improvements in the drafting of regulations so that it is consistent with the overall thrust towards plain English and simplified drafting.

Both these initiatives have been warmly welcomed by the small business community in particular. They are seen as positive developments in getting unnecessary government regulation and burden out of the way of business so that it can get on with the important job of initiating other involvement in the white paper programs and can get on with the job of creating more employment for all Australians.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to page 116 of his white paper, where it is stated:

QUESTION.PARA: In each full year around 160 000 jobs will need to be offered for those in the Job Compact. This will require a very large redirection of jobs . . .
Will the Prime Minister explain to the House from whom the very large number of jobs will be redirected?

TALK.START.PARA: —The very point of the white paper is to give those Australians who have been unemployed for 12 months or more, the long-term unemployed, a chance to participate in the prosperity of this country—not to be sidelined, not to be forgotten, not to be put back. The point of it is to give these people a chance to be case managed, to be assessed, and to understand what their work experience has been, what their educational attainments have been, where their suitability lies, what sort of training they might have, and what job placement might be available to them and where. This means that a group of people who would not otherwise be able to enter the labour market will be able to do so. They will have the chance to go into the mainstream labour market, the increase in which will be met from the product of the economy—employment.

PARA.TAB: I remind the House that in the period between 1983 and 1989-90 the economy grew, on average, by about 4 1/2 per cent a year. The prospect is that, with a more flexible economy today, the economy could grow even faster. Over that period, we have had a job growth of just on two million. So with a recovery of the dimension we have today and with the prospects of it continuing, with low inflation, the aggregate employment coming to the economy will take up the new entrants to the work force and those people who, as a result of the white paper yesterday, will be case managed, assessed, trained and given a chance to take a place in the labour market.

The notion about redirected jobs, by interjection and by inference from the question, is the notion of saying, `Leave them behind, don't worry about them.' In responding to me when I said, `We should leave an arm out and drag the unemployed up behind us,' this is the man—the Leader of the Opposition—who said, `If you leave an arm out and drag the unemployed up behind us, you'll drag the rest of us down.' That is the view: forget them, chop them off, do not worry about them, basically oppose them being given an opportunity and try to cloak the argument in saying, `Oh well, they'll take someone else's job.'
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left!

—The honourable member for Bradfield, when I came into the House today, was up railing about the compassion of the Liberal Party. He was up there telling us about how they stand for the rights of minorities and everything else—
—A 90-second statement.

—A 90-second statement, exactly—except for the unemployed and the long-term unemployed. This is the same person who, over 18 months ago, said that the aged pensioners had to mix it with the `riffraff' at the Social Security offices; these were the unemployed. The honourable member for Bradfield refers to them as riffraff. The Leader of the Opposition said, `If you try to pull them up, they'll pull you down.' Then they say, `Don't give them any jobs, you'll redirect jobs away from other people.' That just illustrates the absolute duplicity and indecency of members of the Liberal Party in their attitude to the unemployed and why so many Australians just will never accept the fact that we do not want a dog-eat-dog, survival-of-the-fittest society. When they ran that out at the last election they were defeated, as they would be again on the sentiments they are expressing in their question today.

—I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon members of a delegation from the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, directed to the Prime Minister, is in regard to regional development. Has the Prime Minister seen criticism that spending on regional development as outlined in the white paper is inadequate? Can he outline the government's strategy for regional Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The landmark reports which the government has commissioned and received—from the Kelty task force report into regions, which held the most extensive consultations around this country probably ever in the regions of Australia; in the report of the Industry Commission, which was a report into regional Australia; and in McKinsey's study of regional Australia—found that regions which had a sense of cohesion and a sense of leadership about them performed better economically than those which had not focused their attention on their future, on their capacities, on their ability to create opportunities within regions and actually fund infrastructure and development within regions.

PARA.TAB: As a consequence of that, the government adopted a policy of strategic assistance to industry, the formation of regional economic development organisations and funding those organisations where they seek to develop strategic plans for regions which commit the business community, trade unions, community organisations, local government, et cetera. It has also changed the tax treatment of instruments, such as infrastructure bonds and pool development funds, so that for particular classes of important infrastructure for regions it is possible for a regional group to actually raise some of the capital in the private finance markets of Australia through these instruments in yesterday's white paper.

That contrasts substantially with the policy of the opposition in regional development. We find there that the honourable member for Maranoa, who is the shadow minister for rural and regional development, in a paper written to the opposition states:

ANSWER.PARA: We should consider regional development policy matters from two perspectives: business and family. The family oriented policies are of course essential to win the mums' and dads' vote and are also critical in the battle to keep skilled labour in regional and rural centres.

We should consider a commitment to new and/or upgraded infrastructure. We need to set a figure—$1 billion, $3 billion; the actual number is insignificant—as an indication of our commitment to putting roads, dams, ports, airports, bridges, whatever into regional Australia. We should also then allude to some sort of assessment procedure by which regions can directly seek funding for these projects which are important to their development. A new bridge, road, et cetera, is a proven electoral winner. It is more concrete than a tax decrease because, unlike tax gains, it is very difficult to take away a new highway or a dam.
This is the motivation. He then goes on about community services:

We need to offer the people of regional Australia a commitment to the provision of community services. The commitment traverses several portfolios including health, education and telecommunications. But again the actual dollar value is not important.

He goes on to speak in those terms. That gives an indication of an infrastructure fund of $1 billion or $3 billion—the number is insignificant. Basically they are proven electoral winners, he says. They have to keep the mums' and dads' vote together and the actual dollar amount is not important.

PARA.TAB: One thing is very clear: now that the opposition has no policies, with the lid off the pork barrel, who is first in? The National Party. Straight in for $1 billion, $3 billion. Is it any wonder, because he is the shadow minister for rural and regional development? But, of course, the honourable member for Mackellar is the shadow minister for urban and regional strategy. So she has the strategy, and he is the shadow minister for rural and regional development. We know the policy of the honourable member for Mackellar. She said:

ANSWER.PARA: When we win government—and we will at the next election—that is when we will make policy based on our principles.

In other words, there are no policies now and, in the economic and policy void created by the honourable member for Mackellar, in hops the National Party with a policy of $1 billion, $3 billion—the number is insignificant—for roads, dams, ports, airports and bridges. It says, `They are proven electoral winners but we need the mums' and dads' vote so we have to keep talking to them. But again the dollar values are not important.'

PARA.TAB: Contrast that lowbrow, unprincipled approach to what the government has done in terms of the government's policy in regional development and the comprehension that is the work of the Kelty task force report, the work of McKinsey and Co. and the work of the Industry Commission. Those opposite should look at that comprehension and its consideration and the product of that work in the white paper. They should let everybody in rural Australia know where the value is. With a Labor government they will be helped and with the coalition they will be hoodwinked for base political motives.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister has stated that 504,000 unemployed Australians will be case managed. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has given case loads that imply this will mean 2,400 extra full-time case managers. Given that the white paper allocates only an additional $18.2 million for case management, can the Prime Minister advise the House where the remaining resources required for case management will come from?
—The government's approach to case management of the long-term unemployed is in itself a substantial and, indeed, revolutionary change to the social security system.
—But where is the money coming from?

—Order! The Prime Minister might wait for just a moment. The honourable member for O'Connor is starting to test my patience. Earlier this week, I suggested that he might contain himself. I am taking that a step further now and suggesting that he does.
—Thank you.

—In a system of rigid national assessment, it is not often practicable or effective to understand how each person has been affected by unemployment, to know what their qualifications and work experience have been, to know what their general aptitudes are and how they will respond to the prospect of being directed with training to a job. Hence, the government believes they need to be effectively case managed. That is why the government, in another important and milestone change, intends to establish a competitive market for the task of case management.

PARA.TAB: Just as with telecommunications and the competition among Telecom, Optus and the private providers of telecommunication services are managed in a market by Austel, the government will set up a body to manage a competitive market to complement the work of the CES in providing private case management in this country. Case management may have a particular focus on the metal industries or on the tourism industry. As a consequence, we could develop and find a very effective complement in the labour market to the provision of case management and job placement.

The government has made clear that around 500,000 people will be case managed in 1994-95. Over the course of the year the case load of case managers will, outside of the compact, be about 250 people and, within the compact, about 125 people. This will involve something like 2,500 people to 3,000 people in the process. From the top of my head, I cannot remember exactly how many additional people that requires over the case load which the CES currently undertakes, but it is a substantial and revolutionary change to the labour market, to the delivery of labour market programs and to the placement of the long-term unemployed into work and into training. It will be money well spent in giving this country equity in the labour market and a sense of social cohesion and justice that has always been denied by coalition governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Have other OECD countries established targets for deficit reductions which are less ambitious than Australia's? If so, will the government consider easing its own commitment in this respect?

—The government absolutely intends to fulfil the commitment that was announced last year to ensure that by 1996-97 the deficit is down to around one per cent of GDP. I think that is a very important target to impose upon ourselves for a whole range of reasons, but not least to ensure a continuation of the productive growth in the economy that we have had to this point. The government is confident that all measures, both in the white paper and in the budget, will ensure that those targets are met.

PARA.TAB: As a government, we are constantly being invited to jump through hoops by money markets, business commentators, the media and everybody else. Occasionally, in being invited to jump through those hoops, we have our attention drawn to what the situation is in other countries—those countries with whom we like to compare ourselves. So I appreciate the honourable member's question as an opportunity to point that out.

As a proportion of GDP, Australia already has the third lowest government outlays among OECD countries. Using comparable OECD figures, general government total outlays in this country amount to about 38 per cent of nominal GDP. About two-thirds of that would be Commonwealth outlays. Out of the 19 major OECD countries, only the US and Japan have lower proportions and they are at around 35 per cent. In other comparable countries, outlays are around 50 per cent of GDP or higher.

Canada—and I note that we are being invited to pay attention to its deficit reduction strategy—has something like 50 per cent of its GDP in the public sector. Italy has about 55 per cent, France about 55 per cent and Germany 50 per cent. To go to the Scandinavian countries, Sweden has around 72 per cent. If Australia had those sorts of outlays as a percentage of GDP, we would be increasing our outlays by another $100 billion.

Australia has not only the third lowest ratio of outlays to GDP but also one of the most ambitious deficit reduction targets. In contrast to our target of around one per cent of GDP by 1996-97, the United States aims to cut its deficit to 2.5 per cent of GDP in fiscal year 1995 and 2.3 per cent by 1999. The United Kingdom has said that it hopes to balance its books not by 1996-97, or even 1997-98, but by the end of this century. Canada—again, a country that we are being invited to pay attention to, because of its current deficit reduction strategy—is targeting a deficit of three per cent of GDP by 1996-97.

So the difference between our target and Canada's target in Australian terms would be some $10 billion. We are not going to walk back from our strategy of progressively reducing the budget deficit to around one per cent of GDP in 1996-97. We are proud that our target in that regard is vastly superior in effort to that of all those countries we like to compare ourselves with.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. As a result of the changes to social security under the white paper, unemployed persons who earn less than $100 per week in addition to their benefits will be worse off than they are currently. Why is this government introducing a system that financially disadvantages those unemployed persons who are trying to help themselves and unable to find substantial part-time work?

—The government made it very clear in the statement that it has changed the taper and incentives so we do not have a position where people who earn one dollar of income lose it from their unemployment benefit. In a milestone change, instead of income testing two people as one, we are giving the half married rate unemployment benefit to each partner of a couple. As a consequence of having a diminished taper of 70 per cent and couples being separately income tested, the person who is unemployed—the husband, if the wife is at home—will not be in the former position where an increase in private income actually diminished the total payments of unemployment benefit to the family.

PARA.TAB: What will happen now is that a breadwinner, a husband, can earn $230 a week above the benefit. As a consequence, not one dollar will come from the spouse's benefit. When earnings go beyond $230, 70 per cent will come off the spouse's benefit so that the family income will rise. That is the benefit of changing the taper arrangements. That is why 118,000 families will be $59 a week better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: this is all very interesting, but the question was specifically about an unemployed person who earns less than $100 a week being worse off. I was wondering whether the Prime Minister might be able to answer the question that he was asked and not just ramble on.
—There is no point of order. The Prime Minister was answering the question.
—I explained to them. They do not understand. They are so ignorant of the changes they do not understand how the two tapers of the joint income system work.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Would the minister explain how reforms to government purchasing policies announced in the white paper will assist small to medium business.

—Most of the attention to the white paper has been quite properly given to the labour market reforms. There are also included in that white paper some very significant reforms in respect of government purchasing policies. As all honourable members know, the government purchases something like $12 billion worth of goods and services a year. As the Bevis committee report—one of the most outstanding reports I think this House has seen in many years—points out, developing a proper industry policy in relation to government purchasing is going to have a very significant economic impact indeed.

PARA.TAB: Small to medium businesses were given a lot of attention in the Bevis report because they were complaining, quite rightfully so, that they were disadvantaged to some extent by the current guidelines on government purchasing policy. The white paper goes a long way to meeting those complaints by small business. I will summarise those provisions in the white paper that give assistance to small and medium sized enterprises in Australia. The first provision is the introduction of a series of arrangements to facilitate purchases from small and medium enterprises.

The second is the development of the two-envelope tendering system for acquisitions valued at more than $10 million. This is a system that will require people tendering for contracts to place two envelopes in the tender process, one of which has an industry development policy in it. This will focus the minds of those tenderers very much on the development of that policy. We feel that that recommendation of the Bevis report will be very advantageous indeed, particularly to small business.

Also there was a recommendation establishing an endorsed supplier approach for common day-to-day purchases of information technology and major office machines and a requirement that the government agencies prepare industry impact statements for major acquisitions valued at more than $10 million not covered by common use contract arrangements. The Bevis committee recommended that that figure be $30 million. I am sure it would be pleased that the government has actually decided to bring it in at $10 million. So there are a number of measures for small businesses, including a supplier development program that aims to further improve the understanding of suppliers about the Commonwealth government marketplace and to improve their skills in dealing with Commonwealth government departments.

Also there is a program of support for Australian suppliers which will give industry information on government purchasing needs to small businesses while also keeping the government itself informed of the potential of those small businesses to supply goods and services to government, particularly in areas like IT, communications products, electronics, building materials, furniture and processed foods.

The major beneficiaries of all these recommendations will be local firms, particularly small to medium-sized businesses that have always had difficulty getting into government markets. So, together with the various other measures that are already in place, the government feels that small business will be for the first time in some time getting a very good deal in this white paper. I bring this to the attention of the House because I think it might have been overlooked in recent media reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Yesterday honourable members from both sides of the House proclaimed their support for the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill. It was encouraging to learn that members of this House adhere to such high moral standards on the question of the exploitation of children. Given the bipartisan opposition in this House to the exploitation of children and in line with article 32 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, to which we are a signatory, is it not now incumbent on the government to institute legislation designed to either prohibit or impose severe tariff penalties on imports in circumstances where children are subjected to the kind of exploitation which this House would deem immoral?

—I am not certain that legislation will follow; it may. I think it is very encouraging that we are seeing in public debate a greater awareness of the interests of children, how they are treated, what they see and what influences there are upon them. The conventions to which Australia has committed itself, in this respect the one the honourable member just mentioned, are an appropriate guide to Australia's commitment as a community to the rights of the child or the rights of Australian children.

PARA.TAB: There is a great challenge facing us as a society, particularly with technological change and changed attitudes in some respects about how we relate to our children. Beyond simply the moral questions there are the material questions of how we treat children and deal with them so that their life's opportunities open before them. Part of what the government did yesterday was about that, particularly for adolescents. There is becoming an awareness in the community that in some areas of child abuse things have gone too far and society needs to check its values and pull things up as necessary. Whether that requires legislation—I am not familiar with the detail of the debate yesterday—I do not know, but I am happy to refer the question to the Attorney-General and seek his opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister advise the House on the government's response to the 4 May agreement between Israel and the PLO on Palestinian autonomy in Gaza and Jericho? What is the government doing to assist the Middle East peace process?

—I am sure it is a matter of great satisfaction to all honourable members that in the same week as we have seen a new democratically elected government emerge in South Africa there has also been an important move in the Middle East peace process—another international problem which has sometimes seemed dangerously intractable. Australia joins with other members of the international community in warmly welcoming the signature in Cairo by Prime Minister Rabin and PLO chairman Arafat of this agreement for autonomy in Gaza and in Jericho.

PARA.TAB: It is a real milestone in the quest for a peaceful solution of the Arab-Israeli dispute. The agreement is also a tribute to the leadership in Israel and the Palestinian leaders who continued to negotiate in the face of terrorist attacks calculated to disrupt the process. It is also a tribute to people like the Secretary of State of the United States, Warren Christopher, and President Mubarak of Egypt, who worked so hard to reinject momentum into the talks when they seemed to stall.

The agreement will now lead to the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Gaza and Jericho—not so long ago this would have seemed inconceivable—their replacement by a Palestinian police force and the release of 5,000 Palestinian prisoners in the next three to four weeks. This lays the groundwork for a better economic environment. It will be vital in the period ahead that both sides do all they can to restrain those who might seek to sabotage the peace process with further violence.

We hope that this agreement will lead to the resumption as soon as possible of full bilateral talks between Israel and its Arab neighbours. In this regard, Prime Minister Rabin's recent confirmation that Israel is willing to make serious concessions on the Golan for the sake of peace is very welcome and brings hope for real peace between Israel and Syria even closer.

I again take this opportunity of congratulating those two leaders. I make the point again that, while Australia is not a principal party in the Middle East, we have shown our willingness in practical ways to support the cause of peace through our three-year, $15 million contribution to economic development in the occupied territories, our participation in the peace processes and multilateral working groups on water resources and arms control, and our long support for peacekeeping operations, such as the Sinai MFO, which is now under Australian command.

Even with all the problems and complexities which lie ahead, the autonomy agreement signed yesterday has made an important contribution to the goal of peace particularly in that region of the world, so long beset by seemingly intractable problems, now overcome by leadership, generosity of spirit and real understanding.

TALK.START.PARA: —I happily concur with the comments of the Prime Minister with regard to the Middle East. I direct a question to the Prime Minister. Now that he has had time to reflect, is it not a fact that unemployed persons who earn less than $100 per week in addition to their benefits will be worse off than they are currently, as stated at table 6.4 on page 155 of the unemployment statement? Is it not a fact that this white paper has, in effect, created a new poverty trap and a new disincentive?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This does come from the party, as one of my side interjected, that wanted to kick people off the unemployment benefit after nine months. In other words, it would say to Australian families who are unemployed, `Out you go down to the soup kitchens of St Vincent de Paul and the Salvation Army.' This is the policy of the opposition as enunciated in the Fightback document.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left will come to order.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Under standing order 145, even the Prime Minister is meant to be relevant. Would you ask him to answer the question or else say that he does not know the answer.
—The Prime Minister is answering the question. He is in order.
—This is the party whose leader has said—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left will come to order.
—I know you hate it, but you are going to get it. Therefore, it decided to cut those benefits off after nine months.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition went on to say, `In doing that, of course, we have a very clear idea that some people are unemployable.' This is the humbug with which that question was asked.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—The opposition knows what the government did yesterday. It knows that the government has introduced a totally changed arrangement. By providing half the married rate of pension to each partner and income testing them, we have provided a much greater incentive for unemployed couples to earn more money. One of the changes was a change to the free area, so that these people can be given the opportunity of earning more as a couple and not having particularly the wife's component diminished.
—You don't understand it.
—I just said to you that we have changed the free area, but you do not even know what that is. In other words, the opposition's paltry point—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister will resume his seat for a moment. The House will come to order. The Prime Minister will be heard in silence.

—The opposition is raising the paltry point that, because the free area at the bottom has been changed so that these couples can earn far more money and maintain—the income of the spouse, unaltered by the capacity of either one of them to raise income, somebody who previously in the free area at the bottom who had X now has Y, so you should ignore the huge potential benefit of the change. This comes from simply the callous disregard of the unemployed by the coalition parties. The Leader of the National Party would push people off the unemployment benefit after nine months, yet he had the hide to stand here and ask me a question about the unemployed. It is unbelievable.

—Mr Speaker, my point of order relates to standing order 145 on the issue of relevance. My question was quite specific. It was about the creation of a new poverty trap detailed in table 6.4. The figures are there. I asked the Prime Minister whether he has in fact created a new poverty trap. Will he answer the question!

PARA.TAB: Mr Beazley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the House might be quiet.

—Let me go back to where I started. At the moment there is a 100 per cent withdrawal rate. Do you know what that means? A taper of 100. Every dollar you win is a dollar you lose. That has been changed so that people can earn more, particularly in part-time work. Unemployed couples can go out and take on part-time work and increase their family income. As the same table shows for someone on $350 under current arrangements, a couple can earn $399—another $50 a week—
—Here it is—page 155. Look at the table.
—Order! The Prime Minister has the call.

—That changed arrangement to give couples a chance to earn something more comparable to a living wage is being attacked by the opposition because of a change to the free area, which, of course, accompanied by a 100 per cent taper, means that these people can never be better off and can never take on part-time work because they lose under the dead cut-off of the 100 per cent taper.

PARA.TAB: They are so little interested in the unemployed, they do not even know about the interaction of the tapers, the separation of the payments, and the fact that one member of a couple can earn more now without affecting the income of the other until he or she gets over a certain amount of money. Then a diminished taper comes in. For God's sake, read the book. It might explain it to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts and Minister for Tourism and Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology in this House. Can the minister advise the House of the initiatives being taken by the government to develop industry and investment and how these will specifically assist industries within his own portfolio responsibilities?

—I thank the honourable member for Richmond for his interest in creating jobs. In the last decade this government has worked hard to create a very positive climate for Australian industry and investment. If we look back at the reforms that have taken place, we see that we have a more open economy because this government has been prepared to float the dollar, to allow new banks into Australia, to lower protection and to carry out the micro-economic reforms that were needed. These are all the things that he was telling the honourable member for Bennelong to do—but you were always afraid to roll it up to the Fraser cabinet to try to persuade it to implement these reforms. It has been the Labor government that has been prepared to carry out the tough reforms in aviation, telecommunications and all of the other areas. As a result of this, we can claim that inflation, interest rates and, of course, corporate tax rates are lower than they have ever been.
—And unemployment is up!
—One million!
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo! The honourable member for Bennelong!
—It is all right. It was a friendly exchange.
—The minister has the call.

—Because of that, we can be sure that, with the continuing high level of corporate profits, the nearly unprecedented level of corporate confidence and the high capacity utilisation of capital, we can expect that the climate will continue to improve for investment in industry in this country. All the conditions are right. There are already some signs that investment, by manufacturers in particular, will improve.

PARA.TAB: The March balance of payments is showing strong recovery already. Imports of capital goods, which mainly consist of machinery, industrial equipment and data processing equipment, were up by 35 per cent. So there is already a clear indication that things are improving. The white paper contained a whole series of measures that will also help to improve the climate for investment. We have changed the regime for infrastructure bonds so that aviation projects such as water and sewerage infrastructure projects can be eligible.

The Premier of Queensland, who is in the gallery, might be interested to know—I am sure he is already aware—that we have extended the eligibility for electricity and gas distribution projects for infrastructure bonds. Wayne Goss has been working very hard to try to get natural gas into the Carpentaria province to get a number of new industries up and running in his state. It is a pity the Liberal and National parties were not working as hard as a Labor premier is in encouraging new investment and new jobs throughout Australia.

The white paper also proposes a revamping of pooled development funds to help spur investment. It also includes new initiatives to attract multinational companies to make Australia their regional headquarters. We are going to look at and reform the way withholding tax applies to offshore income, we are going to provide new deductions for certain relocation expenses and we are also going to streamline immigration processes.

There are already a number of examples where companies have relocated to Australia. Data General has made Sydney its headquarters for all of its data processing for the Asia-Pacific region, and that has been worth millions of dollars not only for Telecom, which is providing the company's communications hub, but also for Australian software suppliers, as it is generating more jobs for Australian software engineers. The white paper also seeks to ensure that we are improving the regime for EFIC. We are establishing Ausindustry, a new one-stop shop, to try to ensure that companies can get advice on government assistance.

Finally, we can also say that the white paper provides a bonus to the tourism industry by, for the first time, allowing the bulk of the tourism industry—those that provide single services—to have access to export market development grants. This will provide an extra boost to the tourism industry in promoting Australian holidays offshore. It is worth $9 million after the third year. That should ensure we have more Australian holidays marketed under Australian brand names on foreign shelves, and that has to be a good thing for jobs in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware that the effect of the white paper has already been to increase interest rates and that the 10-year bond yield has increased significantly? As a former Treasurer of this country who boasts constantly that he deregulated financial markets, why did the Prime Minister this morning claim that `the markets have gone crackers' when he must know that a big spending document like the white paper will always be followed by increases in interest rates?
—That is the sort of question you get in first-year economics at university.
—You have not been there; you would not know.

—No. Had I, I would have been a failure like you. I could have ended up like you. What has happened in the bond markets in the last few weeks has been that the United States of America economy has been growing quite strongly—
—And have interest rates gone down?

—Listen to the answer. Unemployment is around 6 1/2 per cent and the view of many people in the US economy is that the US is reaching its potential in terms of employment—there is near full employment. As a consequence of this, given the fact that American fiscal policy plays a relatively small role in public policy because of the incapacity of the Congress to change it, much of the load has fallen to American monetary policy. Therefore, observing the growth and inflationary prospects, the Chairman of the US Federal Reserve Board, Mr Greenspan, and his board have increased interest rates from three to 3.75 per cent.

PARA.TAB: That is just slightly above the inflation rate, whereas in Australia the 90-day bill rate was 4.75 to five per cent off an inflation rate of under two per cent. We had a real rate on the short end of around three per cent; the US had a real rate on the short end of around one per cent. Therefore, it was not unnatural for the United States to increase its interest rates in an environment where it believes its resources are more fully employed. This is not so in Australia, with employment around the levels that we have them and with a lot of plant and equipment underused and not near full capacity. We had two totally different circumstances.

So what happened? The lemmings of the bond market sold their bonds. When people sell a bond—let me explain this in ABC terms—and the price goes down, the yield goes up. When the bond gets less valuable, the yield rises for a given coupon. Do you understand that? Therefore, out of absolute failure to understand the differences between the two economies, lemming-like, they sell their bonds and the yields rise.

The government is supposed to say, `Oh well, in that case we will go over the cliff with the lemmings. We won't worry about the half a million people who are unemployed; we won't worry about a more efficient micro-economic change in the labour market; we won't worry about skill shortages in a recovery; we won't worry about complements to skill formation. We'll spend the money reducing the budget deficit.' Meanwhile, there is no guarantee that there will be any change in interest rates. The people who are now talking their book, having sold the bonds cheaper, are no longer going to commit themselves to the fact that they can take a lower interest rate. If they take a lower interest rate, it means the price of the bond rises. So that magnifies the mistake which they have already made. So they are talking their book. You want to regard the fact that they are talking their book as some sort of highly spiritual mystic science. But the rest of us have to say, `Oh well, they're a free financial market. They must have got it right.' Grow up! For God's sake, grow up!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The white paper that was brought down yesterday in this House by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is all about spending, training and politics; it is not about jobs. I put it to you, Mr Speaker, that the response to unemployment, the most significant social problem confronting this country today, by the Prime Minister yesterday was fundamentally flawed on four major counts. Firstly, it does nothing to create real jobs; it just worries about protecting one job, and that is his job. Secondly, it will only shuffle the unemployment queues and, unfortunately, it will probably work to lengthen those queues. Thirdly, it is unfunded. Fourthly, it will inevitably lead to higher interest rates and higher taxes, which will ultimately cost jobs. The response shows yet again that the Labor Party cannot solve the unemployment problem which it created because, quite simply, the Labor Party itself is the problem.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister tried desperately yesterday to put himself alongside Ben Chifley. I put it to you, Mr Speaker, that he failed and he failed abysmally. Forty-nine years ago Ben Chifley's white paper clearly committed his government to full employment. Ben Chifley put the light on the hill and committed his government to full employment, yet yesterday our Prime Minister gave up on full employment. The white paper was his white flag of surrender on full employment. Ex-Senator Peter Walsh got it right when he said that the Prime Minister is once again mouthing Chifley rhetoric as a poor substitute for sharing his beliefs, especially his belief that economic growth has a paramount role in improving the life of ordinary Australians. Chifley's voice is once again being muffled by the Zegna suits.

The strange thing about the Prime Minister's failed attempt yesterday to associate himself with Ben Chifley is that I remember not all that long ago, just a few years ago, it was the same Prime Minister who was happy to cause something of a brawl within his party by calling Ben Chifley a plodder. We will all remember when Placido Domingo called Ben Chifley a plodder. Now it suits the Prime Minister to associate himself with Ben Chifley because he is absolutely desperate to win back the so-called true believers who have left the Labor Party since the last election.

The fact is that the white paper has nothing to do with the Chifley Labor tradition, but it has everything to do with the Whitlam Labor tradition. Gough Whitlam has been his tutor, not Ben Chifley. The Prime Minister has been introduced to the idea that when he does not have a policy he pretends that the problem can be solved by throwing more and more money at the problem. That white paper in the House yesterday was all Whitlam, and I have to say that it was Whitlam without style. The Prime Minister has been boasting for months how innovative and how clever this statement was going to be. There was nothing innovative in it at all. It was just a lazy Whitlam copycat—another big spending spree—and, as the Prime Minister would say, it was low altitude stuff.

The white paper has been made necessary by one single fact: this Labor government has presided over the most disastrous failure of economic policy in the postwar era. It was Labor's policy failure that resulted in the worst recession and the highest rate of unemployment in Australia since the Great Depression. But beyond the raw statistics, the Labor policy failure has also had a devastating set of social consequences in terms of family breakdown, homelessness, rising crime rates, and the creation of a permanent underclass. The legacy of Keating's Labor is the permanent underclass of unemployed.

These facts, and these facts alone, explain why there is a white paper at all. It is all about Paul Keating the Prime Minister trying to make up for Paul Keating the Treasurer. It is the Prime Minister's belated and, I would have to say, totally inadequate response to the social and economic disasters that he personally caused. No-one should ever forget that fact. I do not believe that anybody ever will.

This white paper is not what the government has been promising to deliver for quite some time because, as is usually the case, it has once again fallen well short of the expectations that the Prime Minister and his ministers set out to create. Last year, for example, we were promised not one but three major statements—three separate big bang statements—one on industry policy, one on regional development policy, and one on unemployment policy. After all that hype, what did we get? The new industry strategy and the much vaunted regional development strategy have been tossed by the wayside. We now simply have an employment statement, with industry policy initiatives that are nothing short of a total cop-out, and with a regional development initiative that looks more like taxpayer funded public relations exercises on the government's behalf rather than any genuine attempt to reinvigorate the desperate and neglected areas of regional and rural Australia.

The attempt to deal with Australia's unemployment crisis in this white paper will take us, I believe, one step forward but two steps back. It is not a white paper about employment. It is not a white paper about growth. It is a white paper about training schemes and it is all about hiding the unemployed. This is absolutely classic Labor in terms of its response to the unemployment problem. Labor created the problem, then ignored it, tried to fudge it, tried to conceal it, and then threw money at it but, of course, Labor cannot and never will solve it. It will never solve the unemployment problem it has created.

The tragedy is that this white paper tries to address a national unemployment crisis that should have been avoided. We did not need to have the recession. Australia—with our people, our talents and our resources—should never endure entrenched mass unemployment as it is at the moment. There is only one reason for unemployment in the 1990s: the total mismanagement and the total policy failures of this government under Paul Keating's policies as Treasurer and Paul Keating's policies as Prime Minister.

As the Secretary to the Treasury, Ted Evans, said recently, the record levels of unemployment and the social consequences being endured by Australians were a clear matter of choice. Let me emphasise it, `a clear matter of choice' by this government. The government chose 10 per cent plus unemployment and it chose to put almost half a million Australians out of work for more than a year. It made that choice in preference to putting other policies in place that would have brought about different outcomes. Yesterday, most disturbingly, it reconfirmed that choice because it failed to change the policies that caused the problem in the first place. Once again the arsonist Keating would have us believe that he can now play fireman. Nobody is going to be fooled by that. Having lit the raging fires of unemployment, he is now making a big man of himself by trying to put them out with buckets of other people's money and buckets of words. I was amazed yesterday he did not drown in all that rhetoric.

It is very important that we recognise that this is a longstanding approach by this government. In fact, this is Labor's 25th attempt in a bit over 10 or 11 years to actually deal with the problem. It has had 11 budgets, nine May economic statements, three prime ministerial statements, and the notorious One Nation statement. This Labor government can look back on a record that is a disgrace for a so-called Labor government, and on a record that has been a clear-cut disaster for Australia. It has given us the worst recession in 60 years. It has given us record levels of unemployment and it has given us a decline in real wages for Australian workers. How can they call themselves a Labor government? What an amazing trifecta for a so-called Labor government. This Prime Minister recently condemned himself and his government out of his own mouth when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will never be able to say that we have succeeded as a nation so long as we have several hundred thousand men and women and their families unable to find work.
He has been damned out of his own mouth because that statement, that quote, provides a clear-cut benchmark against which this Prime Minister's unemployment record and this white paper must be judged.

PARA.TAB: The facts are very clear. Under the Prime Minister's policies Australia already has, and has had for some time, hundreds of thousands of people unemployed. There are 200,000 people who have been unemployed for two years or more, 350,000 people who have been unemployed for one year or more and 360,000 women who are unemployed. Just over 900,000 Australians are unemployed. This Prime Minister has failed utterly by his own standards of assessment of his government's performance.

But the consequences of Labor's disastrous employment record go well beyond those very bland economic statistics, devastating as those statistics are. It is the social consequences of Labor's mass unemployment that will always be what this Labor government is remembered for—and I believe it is what they will be condemned for. Creating one million unemployed and then virtually doing nothing about it has had the effect of significantly increasing some of our worst social problems: family breakdown, homelessness, health problems, drug and alcohol abuse and crime rates. We are facing, I think, the possible creation of a permanent underclass in this country. ACOSS, the Salvation Army and the Brotherhood of St Laurence all agree that poverty in Australia is created—and I emphasise `created'—by unemployment. The despair, financial strain, family problems and loss of personal dignity caused by unemployment lead to chronic social problems that undermine our basic Australian values of equity and a fair go for all.

The government is always avoiding addressing these issues. It never wants to talk about the social consequences of unemployment. The white paper yesterday had precious little to say about these at all. If, indeed, we go back to the bigger document, the green paper on unemployment that was released late last year—a document of some 240 pages—only one paragraph dealt with the social consequences of unemployment.

In a broader sense, this white paper must be seen in the context also of the cynical abuse of the people's trust that this Prime Minister has made his hallmark. The government has always promised the earth and consistently failed to deliver. It has always made, and knowingly made, claims about its own policies which it knew would be misleading and which it knew to be wrong. The Prime Minister, for example, is always saying that our problems are about to be solved and that he has a solution that will cost little or nothing and we should not worry about the detail. What he has delivered, of course, as I have said, is a recession, unemployment, more taxes and less investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is he?
—Good point; the Prime Minister has not even had the decency to come in and listen to my remarks. I remember that back in 1988 the current Prime Minister was telling everyone:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are now well on the way back to prosperity.

In 1988 he told everyone that we were well on the way back to prosperity when, in fact, we were in nothing more than a boom-bust cycle. It was a time when he was boasting that his budget was the one that would bring home the bacon—another porky from the king of porkies. He told everyone then, in February 1990, that there would be no recession and that we were going to have what he called `a soft landing'. This was at a time when the number of unemployed people already stood at over half a million. Only six months later in the 1990 budget, when the number of unemployed then exceeded 600,000, he told everyone that economic policy was working—and I emphasise what he said—`without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession'. That, without qualification, is a disgraceful lie. What callous insensitivity from the man who yesterday spoke of fairness and compassion, and berated us in here today about the issue of compassion.

PARA.TAB: He went on later and surpassed himself. He said, `These are definitely the golden years of change.' `Of course they were the golden years of change,' he said. They certainly were not the golden years of change for the 840,000 Australians who were out of work at the time of the next budget in 1991. Indeed, it took until the 1992 budget—by which time there were 940,000 Australians who were unemployed—for Labor to finally acknowledge the reality of mass and retrenched unemployment. By the time it did, Australia was already in a national crisis of unemployment which it has not yet recovered from. Yesterday, the man who has been responsible for more political confidence tricks than anyone else put his hand over his heart and did it again: he made another great promise to the people of Australia. Mark my words, it is another promise that he will break as soon as it suits him.

This white paper is more about positioning Paul Keating politically than having anything to do with any genuine attempt to fix the unemployment crisis that his policies have created. For him, the main purpose of the white paper is very clear: to fudge the reality of Australia's unemployment problem and to devise ways of moving people from unemployment out of the labour force altogether and, thus, to artificially reduce the measured level of unemployment. The Prime Minister made a lot of promises yesterday, but the fact is that nobody believes our Prime Minister any more. You know something: they are dead right not to believe him.

The white paper is the One Nation document all over again. It is the document which the Prime Minister hopes will let him lie his way through the next election, just like the One Nation document allowed him to lie his way through the last one. Just like the One Nation document, this white paper is unsustainable and undeliverable because, like One Nation, the government will fudge its growth forecasts simply because it cannot afford what it has promised.

You will remember that One Nation promised $8 billion worth of tax cuts. They were entrenched in law, I remember, l-a-w tax cuts, for those who doubted the Prime Minister's word. He promised an investment avalanche. He promised that the budget deficit would rocket back into surplus by 1995-96. Straight after the election, of course, the magnitude of that con became very clear: over half the tax cuts were immediately ditched, investment hit a 40-year low—hardly an avalanche—and the budget was firmly back in deficit for many years to come.

This white paper will go exactly the same way. Isn't it interesting? Just notice the way the government has structured it. Only $1.1 billion of the $6 1/2 billion worth of promised expenditure is going to be delivered in the next 12 months. True to form, the Prime Minister wants the credit for the $6 1/2 billion, but he has to make his budget look responsible. He knows he cannot, and he never will, deliver the $6 1/2 billion. Just watch him. He will talk his head off in coming months all over Australia about his great promises and his great spending—always talking about the $6 1/2 billion. But get ready. If he were to win the next election, it would not take long before he would be looking for the backdown. He would be looking for the backdown straight after that election. Just like more than half the tax cuts promised in One Nation and a host of other promises, much of this white paper would bite the dust because the government would not and could not pay for it.

Moreover, this government has made an art form of distracting people's attention from the reality of Australia's unemployment problem. For years, the government has created a smokescreen of acronyms, name changes and pots of gold at the end of any rainbow to obscure the real problem. We have had one grand labour market initiative after another. We have had CEP, SEP, EIS, special youth employment training, the adult wage subsidy scheme, jobstart mark 1, jobstart mark 2, jobtrain, ATS, NEIS, labour adjustment assistance, jobsearch, training programs, post-placement support, LEAP, CEEP, ATI, CAP and LAPs—and all of this is just the tip of the iceberg. If acronyms were jobs, there would not be an unemployment problem in this country. Since the government came to office over 11 years ago, it has introduced 45 new programs, all accompanied by the same hype, all being said to be saviours and all failing in the end, of course, to deliver what was promised. In this white paper even more unemployment schemes and acronyms have been created with the same hype and the same promises, if we know how to read them.

After years of denying the reality of Australia's unemployment crisis, Labor has again decided to fudge and conceal the fact that it is not prepared to change its policies to solve the problem. The priority for Labor is to conceal the true extent of Australia's unemployment crisis. For Labor, as long as the unemployed are out of sight, they are out of mind. This is Labor's whiteboard strategy for the unemployed: list them on the whiteboard as unemployed, move them across to a job compact or training scheme, and then rub them out so they do not get counted in the unemployment numbers. Ben Chifley, I reckon, would turn in his grave.

With what was announced yesterday in terms of the new programs and schemes, we estimate that a couple of hundred thousand people will be dropped out of the unemployment statistics; they will be hidden from the unemployment statistics. The reality of the magnitude of the unemployment problem will be hidden because schemes like the job compact, the ATS entry level training and the mature age allowance take people out of the numbers—they make the numbers look better—but with no prospect of a job.

TALK.START.PARA: —They'll be back.

—Of course they will be back. It will just be a matter of time. They will probably start to come back towards the end of 1995. And when is that? Not long after the next election. That is the way—a cynical manipulation of the whole exercise.

PARA.TAB: As I said before, this white paper is essentially about training and so it falls well short of a complete strategy to deal with unemployment. An effective response would be a strategy that would accelerate and sustain growth as well as train, retrain and place those presently unemployed in real jobs.

In respect of training, we recognise that more money needs to be spent but with a couple of qualifications. We want to make sure that the money presently spent is effectively spent. From what we have heard about DEET and its mismanagement and fraud in recent days, we have real doubts. Secondly, we know that these problems cannot be solved by throwing more and more money at them. We are not going to create jobs simply by throwing money at the problem. If it were that simple, the problem would have been solved long ago.

Unless the jobs are created, no amount of training will generate the extra private sector jobs that are required. The jobs will be generated only if they are underwritten by necessary business investment, yet every time this government does something it erects another impediment to investment or it does something else that would otherwise increase the cost of business employing more staff. If the growth is not forthcoming, the unemployed face the prospect of not only increasing in number but also going onto a needless merry-go-round, being moved from one training scheme to another but with no prospect of a job at the end. In the absence of appropriate growth we are just going to get shuffling and reshuffling of the pack of unemployed.

This will clearly discriminate in favour of the long-term unemployed at the expense of others. I can see some of the newer unemployed having to wait almost 18 months to get on a job compact to have six or nine months work experience rather than the chance of a job. The Prime Minister in fact conceded today that there is going to be a redirection of jobs, but as long as the jobs are not created in the end it is not much of a prospect for these people.

The government has also said that it is feasible to reduce the unemployment rate to five per cent by the year 2000. I think it is important to understand the magnitude of that task. An unemployment rate of five per cent by the year 2000 will require the government to generate something like 2 1/4 million jobs between now and then. That growth rate of five per cent has to be sustained in every year of the rest of the decade. Every time it falls short by one per cent, or 100,000 people, the government will fall short of its objective.

I think it is important to set that figure in context. What is 2 1/4 million jobs? It is roughly twice the total number of tradespeople in Australia and nine times the number of school teachers in Australia. It is twice the number of people employed in manufacturing, five times the number of people employed in agriculture and 25 times the number of people employed in mining. It is therefore absolutely amazing that the white paper did absolutely nothing to underwrite the sort of growth thrust that is absolutely essential if we hope to achieve an unemployment rate of five per cent by the end of this decade.

Although we are as concerned as the government to avoid a huge and dispirited mass of unemployed people, we should recognise the reality of what the Prime Minister did yesterday by not having a growth strategy. In failing to put proper policies in place to stimulate investment and to stimulate growth, he is guaranteeing this nation the prospect of something it does not want; that is, the reputation of having the best trained and best educated dole queues in the world.

I think we should be pretty pessimistic about those growth numbers because whatever way we look at the white paper, it is $2 billion of additional expenditure in every year. That is $2 billion that, unless it is properly funded, will be added to the deficit. By properly funded—we will not know, of course, until next week's budget—I mean by cuts in other expenditure or by increases in taxes. If it is not properly funded, the budget deficit will be $2 billion higher than it otherwise would be and interest rates will increase without a doubt. We do not need the first year economic lesson the Prime Minister tried to give us. Interest rates will go up if this is not properly funded. Interest rates going up works against the recovery, stifles investment and starts to destroy jobs that would otherwise be forthcoming. That is the downside of what was done yesterday.

I think it is also important to note from yesterday's announcement that there will be a massive new bureaucracy in the Department of Employment, Education and Training. As most of us know, DEET has experienced a phenomenal expansion in recent years; in fact, its staffing levels have virtually doubled since it came into existence in 1987. There will be an expansion of DEET's programs.

The government has a commitment to individual case management of half a million Australians. The term `individual case management' worries me. I do not think of these as cases; these are people. The only case that has to be managed around here is the Prime Minister. Can honourable members imagine the expansion of resources that will be necessary to handle the half a million people that the government described as cases on an individual basis? There is absolutely no doubt: we are in for a new army of bureaucrats in DEET as a result of this decision.

Considering the way DEET has operated in the past, we have to have real concern. The evidence of fraud and abuse just cannot be ignored and the public cannot have any confidence in DEET's capacity to manage these labour market programs until there is a full, independent, judicial inquiry to get to the bottom of the extent of the mismanagement and fraud in that department. The government is going with a much more complex response and is expecting us to believe that DEET can handle it.

There are some things in the white paper that we welcome. Why should we not? The government pinched them off us. I think it is a shame that it took a couple of years; it is wasted time. The introduction of training wages for young people and for adults, the parenting allowances, the shake-up of the Commonwealth Employment Service and the suspension, and hopefully abolition, of the training levy are all good things. I think it is remarkable, though, that it took two years for the government to do it. I think it is a particular pity when we think back to what it said about some of those initiatives. Members of the government described those training wages as slave labour and exploitation and they told a host of other lies.

Let me conclude with a couple of comments on an appropriate growth strategy for unemployment. The centrepiece of any growth strategy has to be to improve the climate for medium and small sized businesses to begin to invest and to employ labour. I do not want to downplay the significance of big business, but the focus must be on small to medium sized businesses. If the Prime Minister wants to be champion of the unemployed, then he has to be champion of small business. Right now, for example, there are about 800,000 small businesses in Australia. Imagine if all of those businesses created just one job. That would make a substantial dent in the 900,000 unemployed. If we could get the system working and growing and new small businesses opening, there is no way we would fall short of what should be our objective; that is, anybody who wants to work in this country should be able to.

The essence of a successful small business strategy will be to get the government off their backs and to reduce or eliminate the imposts levied by governments which increase the costs of employing labour or discourage them from investment. For example, we should not only scrap the training guarantee levy, we should also freeze the superannuation guarantee levy and streamline its processes. Steps should be taken to reduce the impact of other taxes like payroll taxes and others.

Small businesses desperately need a break in capital gains tax so that they are not disadvantaged when they trade up their business, they get a proper recognition for goodwill and they can use their business as an appropriate way to build a nest egg for their retirement. Moreover, small business desperately needs to be freed of the excessive regulation of government that would discourage just about anybody from having a go.

Small businesses suffer in terms of cost and access to finances. We have to do something about that. Not only do interest rates have to be kept down and bank margins reviewed, but I think it may also be necessary to do a bit of innovative thinking. What about the idea of a small business bank, perhaps by hiving off the Commonwealth Development Bank from a fully privatised Commonwealth Bank? Over and above that, the investment climate for small business must be reinvigorated and cost disadvantages from transport, shipping, waterfront, communications and power must be reduced by accelerating the pace of reform.

The Industrial Relations Amendment Bill that has just been introduced is an absolute disaster from the point of view of small businesses. It has had a very significant negative effect on their attitude to hiring staff. For example, many small businesses now find it preferable, and disturbingly so, to get their existing staff to work overtime rather than contemplate the possibility of hiring new people. The industrial relations legislation clearly has to be set aside if small businesses are to play the part they are entitled to play. Small business desperately needs a more flexible labour market if it is to survive, let alone expand.

If the whiteboard stands as Labor's monument to fraud, waste and inefficiency, this white paper will equally stand as a monument to the Labor Party's total inability to deal with the problem of unemployment. Most of all, this white paper will remind the Australian people that this government has been in office for far too long. Yesterday, I noticed that the Prime Minister boasted that the white paper was Labor to the bootstraps. Only Labor could conceive it and only Labor could execute it, he said. I happen to agree with him.

Only Labor could deliberately create the worst recession in 60 years. Only Labor could tolerate one million unemployed Australians. Only Labor could effectively consign so many people to the unemployment queues and care so little about them, as it has done nothing about them for years. Only Labor could make promises about doing something for the long-term unemployed, as it did at the time of the last election, and then delay its response for so long. We still do not know where some of these measures will take their effect. Only Labor could so blatantly resort to fudging figures to artificially reduce the unemployment rate as the white paper does. You are dead right, Mr Prime Minister: only Labor could do this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can sum up the reply of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) pretty briefly: `You are there, we are here, and on that effort you're going to stay there.' This Labor government can be quietly proud of the initiatives included in Working nation—the white paper on employment and growth. Despite the incoherent bleatings from some sectors of the financial markets, which appear to have little knowledge and experience of the real world of work, this white paper on employment—the first in 50 years—reflects Laborism at its best.

PARA.TAB: As Ross Gittins correctly pointed out in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning, the white paper is not a quick fix and results will come over a period of three or four years. The white paper has resulted from consultation with many Australians over the last 12 months. It is balanced, pragmatic, flexible, creative and imaginative. Economic absolutes are taken into account and social and environmental imperatives quite rightly acknowledge our most precious resource—the skills and energies of our own people.

The white paper recognises more than just cold, analytical, economic number crunching. It acknowledges and recognises the dignity and the right of all Australians to have the opportunity to obtain the prerequisite training and education with which to apply for skilled work. The white paper quite properly acknowledges the needs and aspirations of the most disadvantaged in our community.

Three major themes are evident in the white paper: sustaining high economic growth, training the work force and getting the unemployed back to work. The government quite clearly is committed to sustainable and high rates of economic growth and the creation of jobs. The white paper projects that more than one million jobs will be created by the year 2000. In the last 12 months, some 230,000 jobs have been created.

Economic growth alone will not solve the unemployment problem. It is a national problem and national solutions are required. The white paper initiatives will boost industry and regional productivity, enhance international competitiveness and drive higher growth, which will translate into increasing job opportunities.

The second key theme is a renewed government commitment to training reform. For Australian firms to compete more effectively in the modern world marketplace, they need a flexible and skilled work force. There is therefore no doubt that access to training for all needs to be improved to generally widen the opportunities for skill formation.

Training needs to be focused, relevant to industry needs and demand driven. Training needs to lead to portable qualifications, and it needs to take into account not only current employment needs but also future employment needs. Training must not be buried in the past with outdated technology and methodology. Not only do we need to streamline arrangements for the recognition of training and improve the school to work transition; we need to consolidate the foundation years of schooling on which this is built.

Long-term unemployment has costly consequences—economic, social and environmental. Skills are diminished. Social and personal alienation, crime, suicide, substance abuse, poor health and a more inefficient economy result from these factors, and they cost this nation billions of dollars each year.
