The third theme of the white paper quite rightly commits the government to ensuring that the long-term unemployed are not left behind during the current economic recovery. In previous recoveries, the vast bulk of new jobs—six out of every seven—went to new entrants to the labour market and not to the long-term unemployed. That must never be allowed to happen again. Without new programs and policies to assist the long-term unemployed, they will be left behind again. That is totally unacceptable to this Labor government.

The employment and growth white paper is a substantial and responsible package of assistance that totals $10.3 billion over four years. It will provide for job placements totalling 1,070,000 over those four years. These job placements are made up of approximately 560,000 jobs under the job compact, 420,000 under other subsidised job placements and 90,000 jobs under the youth training initiative.

The long-term unemployed are particularly disadvantaged when seeking employment because employers prefer employees to have some recent work experience. The job compact will provide individual case management and access to a range of labour market programs, leading to a firm offer of a job placement for all people aged 18 years or over who have been receiving the jobsearch or newstart allowance for more than 18 months.

A major feature of the job compact is the principle of reciprocal obligation; that is, the government will be required to offer a suitable employment place to each long-term unemployed person eligible for the job compact. The unemployed person in return will be required to accept a reasonable job offer or lose entitlement to income support for a period.

To meet the special needs of unemployed people where existing labour markets offer few job opportunities, the government is introducing new work opportunities. In 1996-97, almost 50,000 positions are expected to be provided. The environment sector will provide key new work opportunities. The training and work experience of participants will assist in creating future job opportunities in the environmental repair industry, green product industries and ecotourism.

I welcome the extension of funding to the Australian Conservation Foundation for research into the future of green job opportunities in the areas of waste and water management, ecotourism and energy auditing. The potential of so-called green jobs in environmental management and technology should not be underestimated. There are also new work opportunities in the community sector and in education. The local human services employment program will provide structured training and flexible employment opportunities for up to 10,000 unemployed people. These placements will include personal care of the aged in nursing homes and workplace assistance to people with a disability.

I particularly welcome the recognition that the successful transition of young people from school to work is, in part, dependent on their literacy skills. I also welcome that a national survey of Australia's literacy skills will be conducted over the next three years. This government is also committed to assisting all unemployed people and will maintain and improve current labour market assistance to the non-job-compact unemployed. The number of places available for non-compact unemployed in a full year will average at 360,000.

I also welcome the youth training initiative. There is no escaping the fact that the labour market for unskilled youth has collapsed. In the future, young unemployed people under the age of 18 will be provided with individual case management assistance to find suitable work, training or education placement rather than remaining out of work.

Fifteen- to 24-year-olds make up over 25 per cent of the long-term unemployed. The total youth package will provide 50,000 places per year for 15- to 17-year-olds when fully implemented. This nearly doubles the current level of 26,000 commencements for the under-18s. There is a need to substantially expand entry level training opportunities if young Australians are to be provided with the skills needed in a modern economy. The white paper incorporates changes to increase entry level training places by 50,000 by the end of 1995-96.

A civilised society looks after its disadvantaged. Indigenous people in this country still face longer periods of unemployment than any other group of Australians. They are three times more likely to be unemployed than others. The white paper will increase levels of labour market assistance to nearly 26,000 places by 1995-96, as well as a further $190 million over the next four years to some 25,000 people under TAP. In addition, there will be a further 3,750 places in the community development employment projects.

Women will benefit from this white paper. Over 200,000 places in labour market programs from 1995-96 are expected to be taken up by women. The disabled will benefit. The government will provide over 80,000 labour market programs for people with disabilities. Migrants will benefit. By 1995-96, the number of ESL places will more than double the 22,000 commencements in 1993-94.

The white paper provides incentives for business—increased access to capital for business, particularly small business; the suspension of the training guarantee; a training wage for juniors and adults; reform of the CES and private competition for the CES; import replacement through an effective government purchasing policy; and increased access to research and development. Working nation, the white paper on employment and growth, is a document that is a watershed in Australia. It is pro-business, pro-people and pro-Australian. I commend the paper to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do.
—Please proceed.

—Yesterday, from the safety of the Senate chamber, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) chose to criticise me and attribute certain statements to me which are incorrect. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Mr Tuckey, who is the shadow minister, has issued only two or three press statements on small business in the whole 12 months he has had the portfolio.

Senator Schacht has a background in political bureaucracy and obviously measures administrative excellence by press releases. But if this is so important, let me correct the number. I have issued over 50 press releases on small business since undertaking my responsibility in that area. He also said:
This is not possible with Wilson Tuckey or with most of the rest of the opposition because they are not up to score with what is happening in small business.

Unlike Senator Schacht, whose personal and present background has no small business involvement, I am still actively involved in the small business arena, dealing directly with all the regulations and charges such as increased fuel tax and sales tax that Senator Schacht has imposed on that sector. My contribution to the long-term unemployed is to give them jobs. I employ five apprentices and provide regular work experience opportunities to the unemployed. Numerous other opposition senators and members have a similar involvement. Senator Schacht also said:
He—
meaning me—
actually said to small business people, `Don't invest in your business.'
He went on at a later date to say:

PARA.TAB: We do not need `Iron Bar' Wilson Tuckey to go around telling small business, `Don't invest.'

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier in his speech, Senator Schacht claimed that he had a transcript of the television interview I gave on Meet the Press last Sunday to which he referred. Had he read that transcript he would have seen that I specifically rejected a suggestion from a journalist that I was discouraging small business to invest. In fact, I said that I would encourage it provided small businesses use their own money.

PARA.TAB: However, what I did say, which was in line with comments by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser, was previously published in one of those press releases that Senator Schacht said I did not send out. That release said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Shadow Minister for Small Business, Wilson Tuckey, today warned Small Business against contracting any debt while the Keating Government continues its high deficit policy.
He said both rising economic activity and increasing small business confidence was the obvious trigger for small business operators to go back in to debt to fund expansion.
I think that is positive. The press release continued:
'All three—
meaning those items I just mentioned—

would normally be a welcome progression, but as Prime Minister Keating continues to ignore the current need for a pro-active economic policy and a consequent substantial reduction in the deficit in the May Budget, it must be obvious to even the least economically literate, that in traditional style he will be obliged to react to any excessive economic growth with the only other economic policy available—higher interest rates.'
Mr Tuckey said that `Small Business simply cannot afford the risk and should certainly await the Budget . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think the honourable member for O'Connor has made his point. He can now conclude his personal explanation.

—That is the press release. I conclude by saying that that press release was put out in order to warn small business and to ensure that it was not the chopping block for government economic policy, as it was in the last recession.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have enjoyed listening to the speech by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford). You could be forgiven for believing that we were entering a new golden age. The trouble is that we on this side of the House have heard it all before. We have heard it time and time again. This paper is not a jobs paper; it is a training white paper. It has some fundamental problems that I will spend my time discussing.

PARA.TAB: The first concerns the nature of the training that people are being given. Secondly, this is only half a solution, because the other half of the solution that is missing is growth. Thirdly, where is the investment? Finally, we are paying for it on Bankcard. Although we have to wait till next week, we have a pretty good idea from the draft of the budget that was leaked by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) yesterday that this is all being paid out of growth.

There are also a couple of fudges involved here. There is a fudge on the unemployment figure—there is a fudge on the number of the unemployed themselves—and there seems to be a fudge on case managers, which clearly the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) could not address in question time today. Finally, I want to talk about the fact that in 11 years of Labor we have had these sorts of promises, we have had these sorts of overly optimistic expectations time and time again, and they are never met.

It is most important to remember that training does not equal a job. If training was all that was required to have jobs, we would have no unemployment in this country at all. I guess as a country we have never really come to grips with what we do with 15- to 19-year olds. So we kid ourselves now that people without adequate training can suddenly take some short cut, that they can suddenly do some short six- or eight-week training course, and that we can churn out program after program and make up for years; we cannot. The nature of the training that is being offered will be necessarily short term.

The government has not come to grips with the nature of the regional problem of unemployment. The fact is that between Coffs Harbour and Noosa there are well over 100,000 long-term unemployed Australians. That is not going to be fixed by any amount of job subsidy because the jobs are not there in the first place. We have also been told that after the period of training they will be offered a job.

That is a bit optimistic, because what they will actually be offered is work for a period between six and 12 months, if they can find it. If it is not there, they will do some community work. That in itself may achieve very worthwhile social ends. Care for the aged or personal carers for the disabled will do a great deal of good in this country. But let us not kid ourselves that after this the long-term unemployed will suddenly have all their problems fixed. They will have a job for a period until it runs out, and then it will be up to them.
The second problem concerns growth. We have never said that growth alone will fix the problem; it will not. The government's own green paper recognised this. The top of the second chapter states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . with suitable policies to promote economic growth, unemployment might be reduced as low as 5 per cent by the year 2000-01. In order to achieve a higher growth rate, policies would need to be directed toward increased flexibility in the labour market, income restraint, accelerated micro-economic reform and stronger productivity growth. Active labour market programs would also have a part to play in this process.

That is the trouble with the Public Service. When it does not like what we are doing it slips in those sorts of things in the report somewhere; they are buried. That is absolutely true. Without strong and sustained growth this is just a charade because the number of jobs is fixed.

PARA.TAB: Yes, you can churn the jobs between the long-term unemployed and the short-term unemployed and that might actually achieve some social ends. But there are no more jobs, and there are losers, and the losers are the short-term unemployed who will become the long-term unemployed because of this.

In the end, this problem is going to be fixed by investment. It is going to be fixed by businesses being prepared to spend money—not BHP, not CRA, but small businesses; farms and other small business people spending the money to re-equip, to retool. But it is not happening. Coming out of the last recession our investment was up 23 per cent. That saw a surge in growth, a surge in employment and a drop in unemployment. Coming out of this recession, investment is not up; it is down. Compare this to the United States. The US is coming out of the recession and its investment is up 12 per cent. Business is not stupid. It just does not have confidence in the future. It is not going to have confidence while the problem is massaged, while the problem is tinkered with, while part of the problem is fixed but the fundamental causes not addressed.

We are paying for this on Bankcard; that is quite clear. We are paying for it on the never-never. Again, there may be very fine social ends that we are trying to achieve. But we do not achieve them if the net effect of what we do pushes up interest rates. That in itself will cost jobs. So in a perverse sort of way a white paper supposedly on jobs could end up costing jobs.

The timing of this is all very interesting. We are 14 months into this parliament. Last year when the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean), before he was Minister for Employment, Education and Training, was talking about this package he said that it would be in before the end of the year. It is in in May, but we have to wait another seven to 14 months to see a lot of it implemented. The centrepiece of it, the jobs compact, really does not crank up until next year. Some of the benefits, such as the partners benefit, will not start until July 1995.

If unemployment is such a social problem, as is said by speaker after speaker on the other side of the House, why the hell are we waiting between 21 months and 24 months after the election to do anything about it? It does not take that long to make the decisions and the changes. The reason is pretty simple: next year is an election year. If we take long-term unemployed off the queues, put them onto training and give them a job for nine months they will vanish from the figures next year, but I tell you what—they will be back in 1996. So the length of time to respond does not match the urgency of the problem.

We are also concerned that the figures themselves may be fudged. One occasionally gets leaks. We had a tip-off some time ago. It said, `Watch the numbers very closely; they are going to be massaged.' Here is the massage. The jobs compact—160,000 in a full year lasting six to 12 months—will take about 120,000 at any one time off the figures. In regard to the parenting allowance, itself a worthy consideration, if half the 118,000 families come from the presently unemployed that will be 59,000 off the figures. An extra 1,250 places for CDEP will mean 1,250 Aborigines off the figures. A thousand new places for NEIS—they will come off the figures. There is to be an increase in the entry level training places of 25,000. Let us say there is a 70 per cent take-up of that. That is 17,500 people off the figures.

In regard to the partners allowance, on the March figures there were 4,800 potential people eligible. Let us say that two-thirds of them are married and take it up. That is 3,200 off the figures. In regard to the mature allowance, introduced on 20 March, we do not know how many but the Department of Social Security newsletter tells us that 30,000 people have applied. They are people over 60, the long-term unemployed. They do not have a job and, quite frankly, under the current policy settings they do not have much prospect of a job. And what do we do? We redefine them.

So what we are going to do here is reduce the participation rate in the labour force artificially, reduce the numbers of unemployed artificially and massage the figures. I make it as much as 232,950; that is what it adds up to. Those Australians do not have a job but they have vanished until 1996.

In the end this is going to come down to credibility. Looking back over 11 years of Labor, the rhetoric does not match the action. In the 1983 election campaign we had the opposition leader berating the fact that one in 10 Australians was out of work—in his words, `a figure no Australian would have believed possible and which no Australian government should ever be forgiven for'. That is true; the government will not be forgiven. Over time we have had a raft of programs and promises. It is important to run through them because it forms the basis on which we have to judge whether we are going to trust the present rhetoric.

In August 1983 we had a YEAST program, `youth employment and skills training'—40,000 places were promised and 30,000 places were created. But only 35 per cent of them still had a job three months later. In August 1985 we had Priority One. That offered some real hope for young Australians. It was the youth traineeship system. We were going to have 100,000 youth trainees. By February 1986 we did not have one. In the end, 20,000 were created. A lot of money was spent on advertising and lunch with executives.

In December 1985 we had the launch of jobstart. It was predicted that we would have 85,000 places. By the end of the financial year we had 42. In January 1988 we had jobsearch training for young Australians. The boast was that it was modelled on the Canadian program, which had a 60 to 90 per cent success rate. We got an 18 to 29 per cent success rate. In June 1991 we had newstart. This was going to coordinate Commonwealth employment and income support services—exactly what we are being promised today. In August 1991 we had a budget. Treasurer Dawkins allocated $200 million for labour market programs. He used these words:

SPEECH.PARA: While the job market is not expected to dramatically improve in the short-term, the Government's labour market measures will ensure that, when the recovery comes and employment begins to grow, the unemployed will have the skills and training necessary to get back to work.

That was 3 1/2 years ago. That could be said today. Half the speakers on the other side of the House are going to get up and say that, but we have heard it all before. In the budget of 1991 Treasurer Keating said:
We are going to see a small fall in unemployment.

We did not see a small fall in unemployment. It went from 9.5 per cent to 10.5 per cent. I must say that I missed budget 1990. Treasurer Keating then said that the economy had `paused for breath'. I would not want to be under him as a doctor. He said, `We can expect unemployment to rise a little.' The government predicted 7.5 per cent; it hit 9.5 per cent the next financial year.

PARA.TAB: I could go on, but the one that has to be mentioned is One Nation, in February 1992. It was going to bring about a significant reduction in total unemployment. It was going to have investment going gang busters; $13 billion worth of projects. It had pooled development funds, which half the speakers on the other side of the House are going to talk about today. We never saw the $13 billion worth of investment. Unemployment went up to 10.7 per cent and the pooled development funds the government is having a third go at getting right this time.

We genuinely will support any assistance to help long-term unemployed Australians; that is important for this country. But we will not be conned by yet another promise or by any more overblown rhetoric, because it is cruel to raise expectations when one knows one cannot meet them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to support the proposals contained in the white paper—the most comprehensive plan ever put to this parliament to deal with the problems of the labour force and, in particular, the problems of long-term unemployment. It is a plan about our people, about our future and about what sort of nation we want to be. It is very much concerned with solving long-term unemployment by further increasing growth, by having sustainable economic growth and by having a job compact to break the cycle of long-term unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The opposition's contribution in this House today has been so disappointing. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) came into the House and said that unemployment is a really important problem, but the coalition is not going to do anything about it. The coalition does not have any current proposals. Fightback is dead. Those opposite have no proposals to attack the problem of long-term unemployment or to get the economy growing strongly. What is the opposition's policy when it comes to the young unemployed? What is the opposition's policy when it comes to carers of children in the home who have unemployed spouses? What is the opposition's policy when it comes to training, vocational training and so on? Nothing. We have nothing from the opposition to indicate how it would deal with these problems.

This government will deal with these problems because it has a commitment to government intervention to solve the problem of long-term unemployment. We will do that in two ways: by getting the economy growing strongly and by bringing in the job compact to break the cycle of long-term unemployment. This leads me to the reason why the opposition's contribution has been so disappointing.

When we think about the opposition's policy, we really have to go back to Fightback because there is currently no policy that the opposition admits to. If we are going to have a constructive debate about the economic future of this country and about how we are going to create jobs for this country, we should spend a few minutes looking at what the opposition has had to say. The conclusion of Fightback states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal and National Parties are proud of this program and confident of its success . . . It is, we believe, irrefutable.

What did Fightback say about unemployment? Fightback said that labour market programs should be abolished. Fightback said that the unemployed should not continue to receive unemployment benefits after nine months. That is what the opposition wanted to do, simultaneously bringing in a 15 per cent GST on all the goods and services in our community, which would redistribute income from middle and low income earners to the well to do. That is what the opposition has had to say about a policy of economic growth and about how we create jobs.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition dropped the GST shortly after the election. He went public and said, `Of course we are dropping the GST, but we are not dropping other elements of Fightback.' On 30 November, the Leader of the Opposition told Kerry O'Brien on Lateline:

SPEECH.PARA: John Hewson's still committed to the basic sense and direction of the policies we took to the last election—
Kerry O'Brien then asked:
But when you say the principles and the directions of Fightback still prevail, what are the principles of Fightback that still prevail?
The Leader of the Opposition responded:
Well, we stand by the need to cut government expenditure.
Kerry O'Brien probed him a bit further and said:
Massively?
The Leader of the Opposition replied:
Well massively is your word.

He later said that what he wants is cuts to government expenditure so that we get `a smaller and more efficient and more responsive public sector'. As recently as November last year, the opposition was committed to very substantial cuts in public expenditure. What would that mean for the unemployed? It would have to mean that things like unemployment benefits would be terminated after nine months, as proposed in Fightback, and that we could not have massive expenditure of billions of dollars on labour market programs, the type of which are proposed in the white paper.

PARA.TAB: We need to go a bit further to examine the opposition's statements on this question. I am pleased that the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) has entered the chamber. What has been his contribution to this debate? He has said that if we as a nation want to grow, we should adopt Asian levels of taxation. What would it mean if we were to do that? If we were to, say, move to the Korean model, it would require a cut in revenue of something like $33 billion. What would a cut in revenue of $33 billion mean for jobs and for government programs? It would mean the abolition of all the programs for labour and employment, plus education, plus health, plus industry assistance and most of the other areas in our program budgets.

The opposition clearly stands for massive cuts in public expenditure. When the opposition comes into this House and criticises the government for having a balanced program to generate growth through industry policy and for having labour market programs to make our work force more adaptive and productive, it really has not got a feather to fly with. There is no alternative economic policy emerging from the opposition. The Leader of the Opposition says that we cannot spend money on labour market programs. We ask the opposition, `What is your solution? You do not believe in labour market programs. You are going to cut unemployment benefits after nine months. You do not believe in targeting to industry. What do you believe in?' The opposition says, `We believe in cuts to real wages. We believe in abolishing the industrial relations safety net, abolishing the award safety net and cutting real wages.'

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just a lie.

—It is not a lie. That is the only policy the opposition has left. If it does not believe in spending money on labour market programs and if it does not believe in supporting the unemployed through unemployment benefits—
—You are lying about unemployment benefits, you are lying about wages, you are lying about cuts to spending.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! The honourable member will withdraw the accusation of lying.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw.
—This guy feeds on lemons.

—The honourable member for Mayo is trying to cultivate a new cuddly, compassionate image. Because Fightback was such a lemon, because the whole of the Australian community collectively held its nose at the stench of Fightback and rejected the coalition at the last election, the honourable member has been out there, in his leadership campaign, trying to cultivate the idea that he is some sort of warm, cuddly, new age Liberal. What did he say in the Sunday Mail a couple of weeks ago? He said that he really enjoys mowing. He appeared on Four Corners, talking about mowing his 3,000 acres with his little Victa, getting his exercise. He said in the Sunday Mail that he believes in the arts; there he is mowing the lawn pirouetting behind his motor mower—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. There are standing orders dealing with relevance to matters such as legislation and matters such as white papers. I fail to see that the recreational activities of the honourable member for Mayo have anything to do with the white paper on employment.
—I must say that the same thought was crossing my mind. The honourable member for Lilley might get back to the matter.

—The fact of the matter is that the opposition has only one policy to supposedly create growth and to deal with the problem of long-term unemployment, that is, to cut wages. It does not believe in labour market programs and it does not believe in targeted assistance to industry. It does not believe in the sorts of changes we are talking about in the area of social security.

PARA.TAB: What does Professor Barry Hughes have to say about the sorts of wage cuts we would require if we were going to generate even more substantial job growth? He said we would have to cut wages to the tune of 30 per cent. What would that mean to the average wage earner in this community? It would mean a cut in average weekly earnings in the order of $10,000. The economic program put forward by the opposition is very little different to what was in Fightback at the time of the last election, except the opposition will not call it Fightback any more. But it is still committed to massive cuts in public expenditure and it is still committed to the low wage route. It wants to take this country down the low wage, low skill, low service, no safety net Asian route. The debate in this country over the next few months will focus on what alternative the opposition is putting forward to this government's policy of growth plus. The opposition's alternative is the low wage, low productivity, no government safety net alternative. That is not really an alternative at all.

If the opposition really admires those Asian countries and if it wants us to adopt Asian levels of taxation, why is it not honest enough to tell the electorate? If it wants developing countries' levels of wages, developing countries' levels of spending and revenue, it should stand up and say so. Those on this side of the House will take the time to explain that to the electorate of Australia over the next few months. The opposition simply cannot get away with the rank hypocrisy it has demonstrated in the House today and elsewhere in the community.

The opposition prefers to stick its head in the sand and say that there is nothing governments can do about unemployment. That is the essential philosophical and policy difference between the government and the opposition. We believe that there is a very strong case for government intervention via the job compact to break the cycle for the long-term unemployed, to ensure that we do not develop the inherited underclass that the Leader of the Opposition referred to today and to ensure that poverty traps do not exist in our welfare system. When I heard opposition members talk about a poverty trap before, I nearly fell out of my chair, because for most of them a poverty trap is a place where one loses a golf ball at the end of the ninth fairway. They would not know a poverty trap if they fell over it.

Those opposite do not talk to people in poverty. They do not have policies to deal with poverty. They simply have policies to withdraw government from the provision of essential services, to abolish the social welfare safety net and to bring down wages. This government has put forward a constructive plan for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly ironic that the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) should ramble on for 10 minutes and, as he often does, vent positions of the coalition and barely mention his own government's policies. It is not surprising, because those opposite have now been in power in this country for 11 years. After 11 years in office, yesterday they decided to come up with a strategy to deal with unemployment. After 11 years, they decided it was time for some sort of historic white paper on unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Over the last 11 years, who has presided over high unemployment? It has been the Labor Party. Who deliberately engineered a recession and put one million Australians out of work? It was people like the honourable member for Lilley, who went around Queensland and other parts of Australia with his colleagues boasting about the record of the Labor Party and oozing compassion from every pore. Yet these are the people who put one million Australians out of work.

The hypocrisy of the Labor Party is simply sickening. It keeps running this line that somehow it is the political party of compassion. A look at the figures on average weekly earnings over the last 11 years of this Labor government shows that 10 per cent of the lowest income Australians have suffered a fall in their real take-home pay in that period. In other words, the Labor Party, which professes to be the friend of low income Australians, is the party that has reduced the living standards of those people.

The remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at question time show that it is obvious he has not read the text of this white paper. As a result of this white paper, living standards of the unemployed who earn less than $100 per week will be reduced. It says it in black and white. There is even a table, which the Labor Party has obviously never looked at, illustrating how it plans to reduce the living standards of the poorest unemployed people in this country. This party talks about care and compassion, oozing all this unctuous nonsense from every pore. Its hypocrisy is really quite sickening.

From our perspective, when coalition governments have been in power, we have aimed at quite simple things. We have aimed at not reducing wages or boasting that the accord has reduced wages—hooray!—or that the living standards of Australians, particularly lower income Australians, have fallen while we have been in power. We have had the ambition of increasing living standards. When we have been in government, we have achieved that. We have also aimed at achieving high rates of economic growth. In the main, when we have been in government, we have achieved that. The Labor Party always quotes the 1982-83 recession, which was a global recession, but it apparently never bothers to quote all of the many years when coalition governments in this country built up living standards.

I have heard the Prime Minister say over and again—he was reported as saying this in the caucus—that this white paper is a Labor document. It is. It is a defeatist document. It is an apology for a policy from a party that has put one million Australians out of work. It is defeatist, unlike the work of Ben Chifley. He decided to introduce a white paper when he first became the Prime Minister, not years and years after he had been in power. The likes of Ben Chifley aimed to eliminate unemployment.

But members of today's Labor Party say, `By the year 2000 we hope that only 500,000 people will be out of work.' I do not suppose they think that matters. I suppose they think those people are just 500,000 statistics. It just does not matter. Those opposite talk about compassion when it suits them, such as when they are out in Werriwa or somewhere talking to a group of Labor hacks and trade union officials in some Labor Party branch meeting, and ooze all this compassion, but they do not care that 500,000 people will be out of work by the year 2000.

The Labor Party does not care about people. The honourable member for Lilley has a gutter mouth. At a doorstop interview this morning, he decided that all people who work in financial markets, one of the growth service industries in Australia, are yuppies and ghastly, uncompassionate, cruel, wicked and nasty people. What sort of person takes that point of view about fellow Australians? Most of us have at least a more reasonable view of our fellow country men and women. But not those in the Labor Party. By the year 2000, they will leave 500,000 people out of work, and they call that an achievement.

This white paper is also a Labor document because it contains the old tax and spend formula. If the Labor Party sees a problem, it throws money at it. It happened in South Australia. Mr Bannon was in power there for years. He saw problems, and he had grand plans and schemes. Masses of money were shovelled out, and the state went broke. It happened in Western Australia with the current Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and her various predecessors, such as Mr Dowding and Mr Burke or whoever. It happened in New South Wales and, par excellence, it happened in Victoria.

There is always the same formula. There are lots of glitzy plans and wonderful sounding programs, but Labor never cares where the money comes from. In the end, the consequence of not caring where the money comes from is that the economy will be wrecked.

We are now experiencing a boom or recovery period. A good government would try to manage it. But those opposite are threatening this country with a boom-bust cycle. They are spending too much money and pushing up interest rates. They will make home loans, bankcard bills and personal loans more expensive. Guess what they will also do? They will make small business investment—not so much big business investment, because it does not borrow in the way that small businesses do—more expensive.

Where are the real jobs—not six-month jobs, which come and go—going to come from in the next 10, 20 or 30 years in Australia? Those opposite would not know. They will not come from government programs; they will come from small businesses. They will be the big job creators in the years ahead.

The only thing those opposite know anything about is the smoke-filled rooms of Labor hacks. That is all they know about Australia. But if they knew anything about small business, they would know that they should encourage small business investment by reforming their iniquitous capital gains tax, cleaning up the administrative costs of the fringe benefits tax and doing something about easing the pain of sales tax and payroll taxes, not continually jacking them up year after year. The Labor states always jack up payroll taxes, but fortunately there are not too many of them left. There is only one. Those opposite would probably desperately want to count the ACT. If so, that makes two.

The simple fact is that Labor does not want to do that. Its alternative strategy is the tired old strategy that one always gets from Labor in Australia and its mates in the International Socialist Federation all over the world, such as the British Labour Party. All these political parties always do the same thing: when they see a problem, they spend taxpayers' money or borrow.

That is what the Labor Party is doing here. It will run a budget deficit. I suppose that there will be the rabbit out of the hat trick. The deficit will come in below $12 billion—we all expect that—which, as a proportion of GDP, will be around three times as large as the budget deficit at the same stage in the last economic cycle in about 1985-86.

We can be sure of one thing flowing from this white paper: whatever good initiatives are in it—and some of them are good—they are essentially unfunded. The consequence will be that interest rates will rise and business investment will not be as substantial in the years ahead as it would have been had the government not spent so much money.

If business investment had been greater than it is now inevitably going to be, more jobs would have been created, not fewer. But the government cannot understand business investment; it is antipathetic to people who invest. It hates fund managers and people who invest. The government wants the Labor Party to spend taxpayers' money and solve the problem that way. It just will not work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —Shortly after the 1993 election, while honourable members opposite were in the spotlight, like rabbits, handcuffed to Fightback, together with some of my colleagues, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) and the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan), I was a member of the government's caucus employment task force. We embarked upon work to present a submission to the expert committee on the green paper, which is headed by Dr Michael Keating, the head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It was our task to present a submission on what we regard as Australia's most pressing economic and social problem, long-term unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Before I move to some of the items in our consideration, I think it is worth reminding the House what honourable members opposite stand for when they remain handcuffed to Fightback. At the moment we are not quite sure whether the key has been turned in the handcuff and the handcuff has fallen off or it is about to be slammed shut. In Fightback mark I, the attitude of honourable members opposite to long-term unemployment was that after nine months people were to be tipped off the dole. In Fightback mark II, when they became very wishy-washy, responding to opinion polls, when we looked at the fine detail we saw that they were committed to reducing outlays in spending on unemployed people by $800 million. In addition to that, we have their Jobsback package, which of course is simply a code for slashing wages.

I was very amused to see the honourable member for Bennelong, little Johnny Howard, traipse up to the front of the House the other day with his 1955 white picket fence firmly clutched under one arm and his copy of Jobsback clutched under the other. He said, `They're taking up our training wage. Our training wage is their training wage.' That is not true. The training wage in Jobsback was not a training wage at all. It contained no requirement or provision for training; it was simply a device to do what those opposite want to do. Their solution to any economic problem, their solution to unemployment, is to slash wages.

The solution of the caucus employment task force that I was a member of was fundamentally based on the following premise and policy: the solution to long-term unemployment was a growth-plus solution. In other words, economic growth by itself was not sufficient to take up the pool of long-term unemployed; we needed to maximise economic growth, but we also needed to take special steps and special measures to ensure that in the course of economic recovery long-term unemployed people were taken up.

My colleague the honourable member for Port Adelaide has dealt with many of the measures that we could place under the `plus' heading. They include the job compact, the training wage, the removal of disincentives to work through our changes to social security and the parenting allowance, case management by the CES and private organisations, and voluntary or community work.

The area that I want to concentrate on in the limited time available to me this evening is the growth area. It is important that we maximise economic growth. Let us look at the sorts of measures and steps that the government has been taking to maximise economic growth and to ensure that we are on a path to sustainable growth. I then want to turn to some of the measures we have taken in the industry policy area.

In table 2.1 on page 19 of the white paper, the measures for growth and the sound basis for growth in the future are listed. I want to refer to some of them for the benefit of honourable members opposite. The white paper states:

SPEECH.PARA: The economy is growing strongly—around 4 per cent through 1993—under the stimulus of the lowest interest rates in two decades, and the lowest inflation rates in three decades
-interest rates on long term Government bonds are currently approaching 8 1/2 per cent, compared with around 13 1/2 per cent during the investment boom of the late 1980s
-the increase in the CPI over the year to the March quarter was 1.4 per cent.

It is worth adding that we also have the lowest rate of industrial disputation in this country for over 30 years. The white paper goes on to refer to low inflation, our increased productivity, the corporate profit share being at a near all-time high, business confidence in manufacturing being at the highest level for more than 30 years, and world economic growth—particularly growth in east Asia—supporting further strong growth in our exports. Honourable members would be aware that currently one-third of our exports goes to these markets.

PARA.TAB: When we look further in the white paper, we see references to those things that the government's policy has ensured have occurred in the last decade, such as higher productivity, introduction of enterprise bargaining, and our accord commitment with the ACTU to ensure that wages outcomes are consistent with an inflation rate comparable to that of our major trading partners. We also see reference to the incentives for investment and the changes that we have made to the tax system, which include dividend imputation, accelerated and expanded depreciation, and a corporate tax rate reduced from 39 per cent to 33 per cent. Of course, at the last election those opposite wanted to jack up the corporate rate from 39 to 45, plus a 15 per cent GST.

I now refer to exports and industry policy. At table 3.3 on page 55 of the white paper we see reference to the substantial improvements that the government policy has made to our export performance. Services exports have sustained real growth rates of over eight per cent, on average, from 1983 to 1993. Our export propensity in manufacturing rose from 14 per cent to 24 per cent between 1982-83 and 1992-93. Our exports of elaborately transformed manufactured goods have grown at an annual rate of 17.3 per cent from 1984 to 1992.

It is the area of exports, which of course is a direct result of our industry policy, to which I now want to refer. I was very amused to see a reference in this morning's Australian to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) lamenting the fact that there was nothing new on industry policy in this statement. Let me refer briefly to some of the initiatives in industry policy in the statement. I compliment the Minister for Industry (Senator Cook) on the fine work he has done in this area.

The initiatives in the industry policy area include improved access to finance for small and medium sized enterprises, substantial improvement in research and development of a 150 per cent tax concession, major improvements in the prospect of small and medium sized enterprises commercialising good ideas, removal of oncosts and administrative burdens from small and medium sized enterprises by the removal of the training levy, improvements in government purchasing, and further facilitation of export and trade.

It is very interesting to see what the Liberal Party has had to say about industry policy. I refer the House to comments made by the President of the Liberal Party, as reported in the Australian Financial Review on 5 January 1994 under the heading `Lib president rejects economic rationalism,' which was taken as a direct rebuff of the Leader of the Opposition's policies. He is reported as saying:
"To be blunt, we would not be seeing the present growth in manufactured exports if the Federal Government had butted out of its responsibility for the development of industry policies.
"Industries in which this is evident are the car industry, computer exports, exports of hardware and systems in the telecommunications area and the chemical industry."
"None of these things could have happened if we'd just `left it to the market'.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, that is precisely what those opposite want to do. In the Sydney Morning Herald on the following day, 6 January, in a further story, reported by Bernard Lagan of the Sydney Morning Herald, the comment goes as follows:

PARA.TAB: Mr Staley surprised many Liberals on Tuesday when he said at the Young Liberals' Sydney conference that he supported much of the Government's industry policy and called for his own party to adopt similar policies.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague from Western Australia the member for Bunbury, the shadow spokesman for industry, is reported in that same piece as saying:

PARA.TAB: "I think what Tony Staley was saying was that the Government had been `you beaut' in industry policy. . .

SPEECH.PARA: Absolutely! Then we have the coup de grace. In the Canberra Times during the same period, Mr Staley is reported as follows:

PARA.TAB: He said the present growth in manufactured exports would not have happened if the Federal Government had not accepted responsibility for development of industry policy in areas like cars, computers, telecommunications and the chemical industry. There was a need for government to encourage industry in research, development, innovation and exporting.

SPEECH.PARA: That is precisely what the industry policy section of the white paper envisages, and it is precisely what those opposite would oppose. The white paper reflects this government's ambition, and the ambition of those on this side, to ensure that Australia becomes a society and an economy which has high growth, high employment, low inflation, high productivity and high wages. This stands in stark contrast to those opposite, who say that the approach we should take in terms of long-term unemployment is either to do nothing or to present the solution to all our problems as the slashing of wages. We on this side say that we can and will achieve a society in Australia where long-term unemployed people share in the benefits of the economic recovery and where in the next decade we can maintain a high growth, high productivity and high wage society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 5.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I give my public congratulations to the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), who is the government member at the table. I was very pleased to see that she was promoted to the position of Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development in the most recent—
—In part due to you.

—She is kind enough to say this was part due to me. I like to take a bit of credit because, just before the end of the last session, I had occasion to say in the House that I thought it was a pity she had not been promoted. I am pleased she was.

PARA.TAB: This is highly appropriate because the subject I am going to very briefly talk about this evening is a topic which arose in Queensland and in fact came from a Labor representative. I do not very often have occasion to stand in this House and praise a public representative of the Labor Party; however, I am going to do that tonight. The person I am referring to is Councillor Paul Tully, who is the only Labor councillor in the Ipswich City Council. The Ipswich City Council was formerly overwhelmingly a Labor council but, with the exception of Alderman Tully, all the ALP councillors on the Ipswich City Council lost their positions in the local government elections on 24 March this year.

I would not like to say that it is as a consequence of that enormous anti-Labor swing and the fact that perhaps Councillor Tully finds himself in a rather more vulnerable position than he might have imagined he was in prior to that election, nevertheless I am very pleased to see that he is now taking a very keen interest in the subject of the public perception of the dignity of women.

A couple of weeks ago, Councillor Tully raised an objection with Queensland Rail about a billboard that I believe appears at one of its railway stations. It is an advertisement for women's underwear. It is a picture of a woman from about the armpits to the waist wearing only a brassiere, and the caption is `making mountains of molehills'. Councillor Tully objected to Queensland Rail accepting payment for advertisements of this nature on the grounds that it really does demean the dignity of women.

I have been very interested to follow the debate—I have followed it silently until now—that has ensued. I have read letters on the subject to the editor of the Courier-Mail—the newspaper that the Parliamentary Library unfortunately does not think too much of—and other newspapers that are available to me, and I have listened to talkback radio on the subject. It has been very interesting. I will give you a very rough breakdown, Mr Speaker, of the public reaction. Unanimously, men have disagreed with Alderman Tully, and they have used a variety of terms in their disagreement. Women's views have been split but, on the whole, the great majority of women have supported him. On the radio talkback programs on this subject that I have heard—so far as one can discern age from someone's voice—it always sounds very much to me as though it is younger women who say they do not think he should have raised this subject.

I have been interested to hear the comments of those who have disagreed with Alderman Tully, particularly men who have disagreed with his views, because I was looking to anticipate a couple. I was waiting to hear the term `politically correct'. I was waiting to hear people say, `Oh, he is only saying this because it is politically correct.' `Politically correct' seems to have become the latest term of abuse for people who raise issues in relation to women. Once upon a time, the terms used in this particular topic that Alderman Tully has raised would have been `Mother Grundy' or `blue nose'; all those terms of abuse that women have had to put up with for years when they have raised objection to the public demeaning of women's dignity by advertisements such as this.

There is a place for these sorts of advertisements. I would not mind them in a women's magazine or even in a newspaper lingerie advertisment. I would not mind them in their proper context but I, along with Alderman Tully—and I know many women of all ages would agree—object to this sort of advertising in a very public place such as a railway station. I am therefore very pleased to get up publicly as a Liberal and say that I agree with the Labor councillor from Ipswich. All strength to his arm. I hope he keeps at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to speak very briefly tonight. I have been thinking about this for a long time since we changed the hours in this place and I must place publicly on record my total opposition to this 8.00 o'clock finish. I know the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) will not agree with me, but I think it is an extraordinary waste of this parliament's time for us not to sit and I think it is an extraordinary waste of members' time. There are very few members—in fact, I can think of only two and they are the Canberra based members—who do not live outside the Canberra region. That means that the rest of us are here—not under sufferance but as part of a job—and my view is that there is absolutely no reason why we could not be sitting until 10.00, 10.30 or 11.00 o'clock at night, even until 10.00 o'clock with a half hour adjournment debate and then finishing at 10.30 p.m.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of reasons why I would prefer this. My understanding is that staff losses have been involved in the catering section of this place, and I am deeply concerned about that. In many cases, that has been young people, people who are studying and people with part-time work. I believe other staff have lost hours and are losing income. That is one important part of my objection. I also believe that the culture of this place is changing and I am extremely concerned about that. I think it is not changing for the better, but for the worse. It might be all very well for the eating houses around Canberra; they might be quite happy with the 8.00 o'clock finish, but I think the culture is changing to the extent that the relevance of this place is diminishing and diminishing very dramatically.

We have a situation now where it is virtually impossible to catch up with anyone in the dining room. As you know, Mr Speaker, it is bad enough trying to catch up with people in this place anyway, but now we have effectively lost the dining room facility. Very few people are eating there; they are wandering off at 8.00 o'clock at night, disappearing into the Canberra night, never to be seen again. There is just not that chance for any interaction between members of the same side but, I think equally importantly, between members from opposite sides of politics. The great thing about the dining room was that there was an opportunity to speak to colleagues on the other side of the political fence.

I implore the House to review this. I think that we have made an absolutely dreadful mistake. There are some members who, like me, do not leave here at 8.00 o'clock and stay through until 10.30 or 11.00 and, quite frank

SPEECH.PARA: ly, there is no reason at all why the House could not be operating through that period. Mr Speaker, I implore you to change what I think is an atrocious mistake.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

(4) What was the cost of (a) travel and (b) travel allowance under sub-program 1.3: Environmental planning in 1992-93.
(5) What was the (a) date, (b) destination and (c) purpose of each instance of travel undertaken under sub-program 1.3 in 1992-93.

(7) Does sub-program 1.3 include the examination of national accounting and valuation practices to ensure environmental costs are incorporated and available where possible to facilitate better decision making involving environmental policy aspects; if so, (a) what sum was spent for this purpose in 1992-93, (b) what outcomes and results have been achieved and (c) how does the work differ from that undertaken by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Running costs for 1992-93 expended under sub-program 1.2 were
(b) Travel Allowance—$61,669

(2) Compiling the detailed information in the form requested from the data held by the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories (DEST) would entail a very high administrative cost which cannot be justified in view of the information already provided in this answer. The travel costs indicated in (1) above include both domestic and international travel by officers of DEST and in some instances, relevant experts concerned with this sub-program including, for example, attendance at negotiations of the Climate Change convention, various Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change meetings and various OECD meetings.

(b) DEST is supporting a joint project by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) and the Centre of Policy Studies, Monash University to quantify the energy system-wide and economy-wide economic effects of introducing greenhouse policies. Final output from the project will be a new, fully documented computable general equilibrium model of the Australian economy with a highly detailed energy sector, available for public use.

Reports produced as part of this project include: a system-wide analysis of the costs of alternative Australian energy sector greenhouse response measures; an analysis of the effects of alternative greenhouse policy options in the road passenger transport sector; and assessment of the prospects for new and renewable energy sources in meeting Australia's greenhouse commitments. Further projects outputs are due for completion in 1994 and early 1995.

The modelling assumptions used in the project are those of the MENSA model (which is a variant of the widely used MARKAL linear programming model) and the MONASH general equilibrium model (based on the ORANI model of the Australian economy). The technology data used in the MENSA model of the Australian energy sector are principally drawn from that in the Ecologically Sustainable Development Working Groups. ABARE's own biennial projections of Australian energy supply and demand have also been used extensively.
(4) Running costs for 1992-93 expended under sub-program 1.3 were

The travel costs indicated in (4) above include domestic and international travel by officers of my Department concerned with this sub-program including, for example, attendance at a range of multilateral (UN, OECD), regional, (South Pacific Regional Environment Program) and bilateral (Japan, Indonesia) meetings related mostly to the development of trade and environment policy and follow up to the many initiatives agreed to at the UN Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED) in June 1992.
(6) Yes (a) approx. $51,000

(b) (i) publication of a paper outlining some Australian experience with economic instruments, demonstrating practical implementation issues, broad lessons, and frameworks for considering and analysing economic instruments;
(ii) seminar of State, Territory and Commonwealth Governments to review experience and encourage practical steps toward use of economic instruments;
(iii) active involvement of Australia in development and compilation of OECD database of economic instruments, and analysis of this data;
(iv) establishment of strong links with State and Territory Governments on this issue;
(v) internal seminars and information for DEST officials on the use of economic instruments in environmental policy, outlining potential and risks.

(c) This work is designed to develop a broad base of experience and knowledge with which to consider implementation of economic instruments for environmental management in a broad range of areas, with a solid understanding of the practical problems of implementation. As such, it is quite different from the work of the Industry Commission, though fully compatible with parts of that work.
7. Yes (a) approx. $29,000

(b) (i) Joint project with the Resource Assessment Commission and the Department of Finance to develop a policy-makers' handbook on techniques of environmental valuation, including consideration of the rationale for, and limitations of, valuation. Preliminary drafts of this report have been received.
(ii) Consideration with Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) officials of problems and prospects for development of "Green GDP" indicators.

(c) Work in this area has focused on valuation techniques and making policy-makers aware of the need for methodologies associated with these techniques. This is very different from the work the ABS has done in developing satellite accounts which seek to measure changes in some forms of national capital and also in collating more general information on the environment.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Union for the Conservation of Nature: Meeting

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 8 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many of the Australian delegates to the 19th General Meeting of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) held between 17 and 22 January 1994 were officers from the Minister's Department.
(2) What was the total cost to the Commonwealth Government of sending delegates to the IUCN meeting.
(3) What are the implications for Australia and the management of Australian natural resources of the resolutions passed at the meeting.
(4) Which resolutions were voted on by Australian delegates.
(5) Was there an agreed Government position on the resolutions before the meeting.
(6) Did Cabinet give approval to the position taken by Australian delegates on each issue they voted on.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories (DEST), which is the Australian State member of IUCN, sent 3 delegates to the IUCN General Assembly, held in Buenos Aires from 17-26 January 1994. In addition, the Australian Heritage Commission, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, which are all Government Agency members of IUCN, were represented by 1, 3, and 4 delegates respectively. The Northern Territory and Queensland Governments had 7 and 2 representatives respectively. Approximately 25 Australian non-government organisation representatives were also in attendance.
(2) Approximately $92,000.

The expenses of two of the four delegates from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority were fully paid for by the World Bank Environment Department as part of a consultancy being undertaken for the World Bank by the Authority. These costs are therefore not included in this figure.
In addition to the above amount, the Commonwealth provided a grant of $3000 to the Australian Committee for IUCN, to enable the Chair of that Committee to attend the General Assembly.

(3) Resolutions of IUCN are not binding on governments. They may be taken into account, if considered appropriate, by the Government in relation to issues concerning the management of Australian natural resources.

(4) By convention IUCN seeks to adopt resolutions by consensus. However, the Australian State Party member (DEST) indicated that in relation to a number of resolutions, particularly those dealing with domestic issues concerning Australia or another country, that it would have abstained or opposed such resolutions if brought to a vote. Significant resolutions which were brought to a vote were those dealing with Tibet and whaling. The Australian State member voted on these resolutions in accordance with existing Government policy.
(5) Yes. Briefing on all draft resolutions was prepared by DEST in consultation with relevant Commonwealth Government Departments and Agencies.
(6) No. Cabinet approval was not necessary as the position taken by Australian delegates was in accordance with existing Government policy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 9 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: Did Australia sponsor a symposium in Germany on matters relating to multiculturalism and immigration; if so,
(a) on whose initiative was the symposium conducted,
(b) whose approval was required,
(c) what was the cost to the Commonwealth of the symposium,
(d) how were Australian speakers at the symposium selected,
(e) what qualities were required for selection,
(f) were any speakers critical of Australia's policies on immigration and multiculturalism at the symposium; if not, why not,
(g) were Members of Parliament informed of the symposium; if not, why not,
(h) will any similar events be held,
(i) will the Minister ensure that in future Members of Parliament are notified in advance of similar events and
(j) will the Minister provide me with copies of papers delivered by Australians at the symposium.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: I am advised that the 1994 Australia Day Symposium "Immigration and Integration: Germany and Australia" was held in Berlin on 3 February 1994 and Potsdam on 4 February 1994. Sponsorship was on a joint German/Australian basis, but came principally from German agencies; namely, the Berlin Government Commissioner for Foreigners and the Brandenburg Commissioner for Foreigners. On the Australian side, the symposium was sponsored by the Australian Consulate-General in Berlin and Australian Embassy in Bonn. Support was also provided by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (DIEA), including its Bureau of Immigration and Population Research (BIPR); the Office of Multicultural Affairs (OMA); the Queensland Bureau of Ethnic Affairs; and the University of Melbourne.

(a) The symposium was the second `Australia Day' symposium held to compare policy and practice in Germany and Australia; it followed the previous 1993 Australia Day symposium in Berlin which had focused on town planning and urban development in Germany and Australia. The proposal for the 1994 symposium was jointly developed by Professor Dr Gerhard Leitner of the Free University of Berlin and the then Australian Consul-General in Berlin, Dr David Charles. The choice of themes for the 1994 symposium was reached after consultation with the Commissioners for Foreigners in Berlin and Brandenburg.

(b) On the Australian side, the symposium was authorised by the Australian Government's representatives in Germany, after consultation with DFAT, DIEA and OMA, as part of the on-going work program of the Australian Consulate-General in Berlin. On a visit to Germany in September last year, I personally discussed the proposal with the Berlin Commissioner for Foreigners who saw Australia as providing a positive model in the area of immigration and multicultural policies. I was kept informed of developments with planning for the symposium.

(d) & (e) Australian speakers were nominated in consultation with the German organisers of the symposium. They were selected for their subject knowledge and ability to contribute to the exchange of information and experiences on the themes of the symposium.
(f) Australian speakers addressed the range of issues arising from both the challenges and the achievements of Australia's multicultural society.
(g) I informed the Senate on 13 December 1993 of the plans and purpose of the symposium. I provided an up-date to the Senate on 2 February 1994.

(h) The Australian Consulate-General in Berlin has reported that the Association for the Promotion of an Australian Institute in Germany, which is co-chaired by the Consul-General and the Rector of Potsdam University, will continue to hold symposia on a range of topics in association with the Institute, which it is hoped will be inaugurated in early 1995.
(i) See (g). I will continue to advise Parliament of significant developments in my portfolio.
(j) I will arrange for Mr Campbell to receive copies of papers delivered at the symposium that emanated from my portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 10 February 1994:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 24 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Prime Minister in March 1993 announce an initiative to compile an indicative list of cultural sites; if so, what progress has been made.
(2) Did the Prime Minister also indicate that nominations of cultural sites would proceed in 1995; if so, will nominations proceed in 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) On Tuesday 9 March 1993, the Prime Minister, in an environment policy statement said in part "In consultation with the States a World Heritage Indicative List of Cultural Sites will be established . . . "

Officers of the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories have begun a process of consultation with the States and Territories on the consideration of places for inclusion on the Indicative List.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 23 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What will the Government do to constrain medical costs.
(2) Will the Government act to reduce charges made by doctors.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) Australia, like other industrialised Western nations, is facing a number of issues and challenges in sustaining a high quality health care system which is affordable to both the nation and the individual.

As a proportion of Gross Domestic Product, health expenditure has been relatively stable over the last decade ranging from 7.7 to 8.6 per cent, and averaging 7.9 per cent, around the average for countries belonging to the Organisation of Economic and Co-operative Development.

The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare considered that the rise to 8.6 per cent in 1991-92 did not reflect an acceleration in health costs. Rather it reflected the impact of the recession on GDP.

Health expenditure has been growing at an average annual rate of about 10.4 per cent in current prices, or 3.9 per cent at constant prices, comparable with population growth and rates of growth in GDP over this period.
In 1991-92, total health expenditure was $33.2 billion, or $1,904 per person.
Most Australian households spend very little of their after tax income on basic health care. For example, nearly half make no payment and about 75 per cent spend less than $4 per week.

Safety nets are in place to protect individuals and families from unnecessarily high out-of-pocket expenses, and the socially disadvantaged are provided access to a range of allied health services such as dental care free of charge or at little out-of-pocket cost.
Commonwealth involvement in medical costs is mainly in the areas of the Medicare benefits arrangements and grants to the States and Territories for access to public hospitals.
Increases in the level of Medicare expenditure are a product of:
the ageing population of Australia, which is significant because a comparatively high proportion of the health budget is spent on older people;
increases in the number of doctors billing under Medicare and the stimulus this provides for additional services;
cost shifting and changes in treatment regimes (for example, ulcer drugs rather than surgery);
new and expensive technologies and rapid growth in their use;
the increasing range of services subsidised by the Schedule; and
patient expectations.

The Government's health policy and reform agenda is already acting to constrain medical costs through a combination of strategies, including macro-level cost controls and structural changes and incentives to improve the micro-economic efficiency of the health care system.

Expenditure restraint has been applied to public provision of health services, largely through the capping of public hospital budgets. To a lesser extent cost containment in private provision is exercised through the monopsonistic power of the Government's Medical and Pharmaceutical Benefits Schemes.
Specific strategies adopted include:
providing every Australian citizen with an entitlement to hospital treatment at no charge as a Medicare patient;
ensuring that Medicare Benefits Schedule fees are appropriate by means of the service and pricing review process of the medical insurance component of Medicare;
maintaining the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme listing, pricing and authority processes;
restructuring the way general practice is organised and financed;
developing casemix based information systems in the public hospital system to improve efficiency in management and resource allocation;
providing incentives to develop efficient alternatives to acute hospital care such as early discharge programs and post-acute and palliative care to reduce admissions and bed-day use; and
developing research and peer review processes to establish best practice guidelines to assist the medical profession to make cost effective clinical decisions taking account of the needs of patients.
Bulk billing also serves to moderate increases in doctors' fees by encouraging price competition:

in the December quarter 1993, over 67 per cent of Medicare services were direct billed. That is to say, 67 per cent of Medicare services were provided at no direct cost to the consumer and the Government subsidy was the full cost of the service;
in the period 1984-85 to 1992-93, the level of direct billing in Australia increased by 19.8 per cent.
The level of Medicare Benefits Schedule fees also serves to moderate increases in doctors' fees:
in the December quarter 1993, 80 per cent of Medicare services were direct billed or patient billed at or below the Schedule fee;

Schedule fee observance increased by 2.2 per cent between the December quarter 1993 and the December quarter 1992. This shows a continuing trend of increase in Schedule fee observance in recent years.

However, while the Government sets the fees on which Medicare benefits are based, it has no direct power or authority to determine the fees charged by doctors in private practice, nor can it compel them to observe the Schedule fee for a particular service. Medical practitioners are therefore free to set their own values on their services and the actual fee charged is a matter between the doctor and the patient.
A discussion paper containing proposals for the reform of private health insurance was released in December 1993.
At this stage, it is too early to make any definitive comment on how the reforms will eventually look.
In addition the Government has:
adopted a policy in relation to high cost technology such as Magnetic Resonance Imaging;
restructured pathology in co-operation with the profession; and

agreed with State and Territory governments to review outpatient services with the objective of having the focus placed on the provision of cost effective high quality care rather than on cost shifting.

The Government will continue to promote efficiency in the delivery, pricing and funding of health care, and at the same time, continue to seek to improve the quality and appropriateness of care and health outcomes for patients.
